name: Martin SCHULZ
text: Ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has On Friday morning, a coach collided head-on with a truck on a country road near Bordeaux. Both vehicles went up in flames and burned out completely. In one of the most serious bus accidents ever in Europe, 43 people – mostly senior citizens who were on a trip to the Pyrenees and were just a few kilometres from their home – lost their lives. Precisely because we are here in France, on behalf of the European Parliament, I wish the injured who survived the accident a speedy and complete recovery, and I offer our deepest condolences to the families of the victims. Our thoughts are with the bereaved and wish them strength in coping with the terrible loss of their loved ones.

name: Lola SÁNCHEZ CALDENTEY
text: GUE/NGL Group. – Mr President, 6 November marks the fortyth anniversary of the Green March. Forty years of Moroccan occupation of Western Sahara, territory to be decolonized according to Article 73 of the Charter of the United Nations. Forty years of abandonment by successive Spanish governments. The European Union does not pay political attention to this conflict and thus contributes to consolidating the status quo and maintaining the paralysis of United Nations plans for this territory. If the European Union really wants to be the human rights defender it seeks, this issue needs to be put on the table. More than ninety thousand people have been out of their land for forty years because of the Moroccan occupation. These same people are now victims of the recent torrential rains that have devastated refugee camps in the Tinduf region. This issue needs to be addressed. We can't keep looking the other way. name: Markus FERBER
text: Rapporteur. Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has said. Today is the first time that we have discussed concrete legislation following the LuxLeaks affair. That is why I think it is a very important debate, because it is a question of us as a Parliament sending out a clear signal here, for clarity, for transparency, for fair tax competition in the European Union. In the area of tax rulings in particular, the Member States are already obliged to exchange information, but it has not yet worked – to put it bluntly. At the beginning of this debate, I would like to express my thanks to the Commission, in particular the Commissioner for Competition, for addressing the issue of fair tax competition, also from the point of view of state aid. Because in the end it's nothing else. That is why it must be taken up here. The Commission has put forward a proposal to make all tax assessments of cross-border importance available to Member States in an automatic procedure. I believe that this Commission proposal is a first good approach. However, we in the Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs have also made a clear support for including a large number of measures. I would just like to mention a few key words: scope. We have argued that all valid tax rulings, in so far as they do not concern natural persons, i.e. legal persons, should be included in this procedure within the scope of application. So all tax rulings for legal persons, a significant extension! We have argued that the information should be exchanged immediately, not every three months, as the Commission has proposed. We have also called for additional information to be included here: a tax identification number, different tax rates, information where deviations from normal tax law are applied, and so on. We have expressly stated that the Commission can also apply this information in the context of competition law. We believe that this is a very important point, because only in this way will we be able to exert pressure to ensure that tax law is not applied here against the Member States or against neighbouring states, but that everyone is aware that they must also deal with the rules on competition and aid when they issue a corresponding tax ruling. I am disappointed – and I want to make this very clear – that on 6 October the Council agreed on a proposal that falls well short of what the Commission has proposed. In fact, only cross-border tax rulings and transfer pricing agreements are to be named here – without knowing exactly what that means. The Council remains unclear. The entry into force is to be postponed for another year. effect over five years – not, as we say, all valid tax rulings. That is why I am disappointed. I want to make it very clear that the finance ministers of the Member States have not fulfilled the promise that has been made here in Parliament, which has been repeatedly made in the Special Committee, but also in the Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs, that they want to make a contribution to clarity and transparency here. That is why I urge the Member States to enter into serious negotiations with the European Parliament here in order to achieve the best possible results, namely that we arrive at a clear, transparent European model in the area of tax rulings and tax price agreements, which does not make tax law at the expense of the neighbour, but ensures that everyone is taxed according to its capacity where there is added value. I am pleased that this has received broad support in committee, and I hope that it will also receive broad support in plenary.

name: Elisa FERREIRA
text: alternate rapporteur. – Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner, I would like to begin by greeting the rapporteur and thanking the spirit of commitment that has been given to the collective work in the European Parliament in this matter. Later today, in the TAXE Special Committee, which was set up after the Luxleaks scandal, we will also vote on another report and hope that the spirit of compromise will also prevail. In fact, it has been a year since the Luxleaks scandal and the problem of exchanging information is just one of those that needs to be dealt with urgently and seriously, through a compromise, not only within Parliament but also in the form of an interinstitutional agreement, including the Commission and also the Council, in order to introduce , in European culture, a new way of addressing taxation. It is in this sense that I would like to begin by greeting the Commission on the number of initiatives that have already brought to light, and to ask the European Commission not to give up this fight.  It is essential to have a strong position in this Parliament, which we are building. The strong position of the European Commission is indispensable. But there must also be a credible position on the part of the Council. In this regard, I also endorse what my colleague Mr Ferber has just said about the disappointment of the ECOFIN Council's decisions of 6 October, not only with regard to the date of entry into force of the new procedures, but in particular at 3 other levels. Firstly, it is unacceptable that the agreement to exchange information on so far secret agreements, which favour multinationals in the field of taxation, should allow them to be adopted and exchanged between Member States, without giving the European Commission the role it has to play. The European Commission must be the platform on which this exchange of information takes place, so as to prevent what has been the scarcity of all the compromises between states that have existed so far remains the European standard. The European Commission must be the exchange platform. Secondly, it is unacceptable that governments have limited this exchange of information to the rulings granted in the last 5 years, when the European Commission's proposal was 10 years old, with numerous agreements still in place and therefore having to be made accessible to tax administrations, whatever the period in which they began or at least , that all those that are still in force are the subject of this exchange of information. Finally, I would also like to mention the fact that all the rulings, all these exchanges, all these agreements, have to be transmitted, because, in the internal market, the advantages that are attributed in a single Member State to a multinational automatically have an impact on the tax base in all other States. It therefore makes no sense to limit the obligation to exchange information to exchanges between States, when, in fact, the agreement ultimately creates, in the internal market with free movement of capital, a risk of tax loss for all other States.  In short, there is a new European agenda on this. Parliament is working in good faith. The Commission is working intensively, and we want it to continue. But the Council must act with fairness, with determination, in order to correct the situation of fiscal injustice in Europe and restore the confidence of Europeans, citizens, who are those who pay taxes, in tax matters, in the seriousness of the work of the integrated project in which we all believe.

name: Molly SCOTT CATO
text: rapporteur. – Madam President, the Green Group believes that we are in a tax crisis. We see governments – not just of remote tropical islands, but within our very own Union – agreeing bargain deals with multinational corporations. Our citizens pay the price for this: seeing the public sector starved of investment and our SMEs losing out because they simply cannot compete with the low rates of tax that multinationals can arrange for themselves. Taxation and, more importantly, tax justice is of the utmost importance for European citizens. As we approach the anniversary of the Luxleaks scandal, I wish to focus on a key issue of this debate: the question of who should know what about tax. So how much do we know? The answer is that we know a lot less than we need to in order to be able to develop policies that reassure our citizens that corporations are paying the taxes they should. As an elected representative and member of the TAXE Committee, there are still a great many vital documents that I do not have access to. Last November, people across Europe were horrified to find out that the Commission President himself had been the architect of a secret system of sweetheart tax deals for some of the world’s most powerful corporations. Yet, without the actions of the brave whistleblower, Antoine Deltour, they would have known nothing about this. So how can it be right that it is Deltour who is facing legal action whereas the architects of the dodgy tax deals do not face redress? Very few of the people I represent think that Deltour is the guilty party on the issue of tax avoidance. The first real sign that the Commission means business came last week with the announcement of the results of the inquiries into the tax affairs of Starbucks and Fiat and the demand for tax to be recovered. Such inquiries still have a long way to go and, while I congratulate Commissioner Vestager on her activities so far, I would encourage her to widen and deepen her investigation. In March this year the Commission presented a tax transparency package, which included the files that we are focussing on today. They proposed the repeal of the 2003 Savings Tax Directive, which provided tax authorities with the information they needed to ensure tax was not avoided, but has now been superseded by a new directive that has wider scope. I was the rapporteur on this repeal and I undertook a thorough investigation of the risk that it might open up loopholes to facilitate further tax avoidance. I had excellent support from my shadows, and we agreed jointly that we would support the repeal. The Directive on Administrative Cooperation is now being extended to call for automatic exchange of information on tax rulings. So important was this piece of the package that the Council, in a break with tradition, proceeded without hearing Parliament’s position. This is extremely disappointing, as we have made some significant improvements on the Commission proposal, notably extending the scope of tax rulings considered. However, returning to my central point, we do not believe Parliament has been ambitious enough on how information will be made available. As Greens we call for the Commission’s central directory of rulings to be made public not only to the Commission and other Member States, but for European citizens as well. This call for public information will be reintroduced as an amendment before plenary, as we believe it is what the people of Europe wish to see. As I said at the start of my speech, the central issue of the Luxleaks scandal was the lack of public information. Senior politicians, tax accountants and corporate bosses knew exactly what was going on in the cosy world of what they call tax rulings, but as a parliamentarian I knew nothing, and those I represent knew nothing. It is for this reason that the Greens in Parliament will settle for nothing less than full publication of tax information. It is only when politicians know that their deals with corporations may become known to their electors that they will act in the interest of those electors, and it is only when corporate lawyers consider the reputational damage that might follow shady tax deals that they will stop spending so much time devising these elaborate webs of tax avoidance. (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8))

name: Tibor SZANYI
text: Blue card question. –Although I could have asked all three reporters this question, only to inform the public as much as possible, the Commission's estimate of the size of the annual tax rate that large companies do not pay? How much damage is being caused to European citizens? We hear a lot of songs. Can you give me an approximate number, Congresswoman?

name: Molly SCOTT CATO
text: blue-card answer. – Thank you very much for that rather challenging question. I have not brought the data with me today and I realise that you do not have a chance to blue-card the Commissioner, but the Commission has actually prepared information. It is, though, obviously extremely difficult to estimate this because we do not have the information there. Part of the point of calling for publication of tax rulings is that it will give us more information, enabling us to estimate how much tax has gone astray. I again congratulate Commissioner Vestager, as she has made an estimate of how much has not been paid by those two corporations, and I think we need further investigations of that type in order to have a real sense of the scale of this problem and the loss to the public exchequers of our Member States.

name: Pierre MOSCOVICI
text: Member of the Commission. Madam President, ladies and gentlemen of the rapporteurs, aggressive tax planning has become a major concern within the Union and at the global level, particularly in the context of the work of the OECD and the G20.  Increasing transparency in tax rulings between Member States' tax authorities is an important step - I would say major - to combat this aggressive tax planning and tax evasion. Indeed, the decisions taken by the Commission last week in the case of Fiat in Luxembourg and Starbucks in the Netherlands are in line with this. My cooperation with Ms. Vestager and her services is excellent.  Member States now have room for discretion in deciding whether a tax anticipation decision can be relevant in another EU country, known as on-demand information exchange. However, this lack of transparency on tax rulings is being exploited by some companies in order to artificially reduce their tax contributions! This has become simply intolerable for our fellow citizens who have been called upon to make a strong contribution to solving deficits during the crisis and who have civic behaviour. That is why we presented an ambitious proposal in March 2015 to introduce an automatic exchange of information on tax rulings between all Member States. I would like to thank Mr Ferber for the quality of his report on this proposal. We have always had fruitful exchanges on this subject. On 6 October, the Member States reached a compromise, a political agreement which I think is quite appropriate, given that we had the publication of the OECD BEPS recommendations the day before, which were then adopted by the G20 in Lima as part of the IMF meetings. I agree with Mr Lamassoure, who is still chairing the special committee TAXE: Parliament's work in this area has put - and I want to thank you on all the benches - a decisive pressure on the Member States to reach an agreement. Parliament was not around the TABLE of the ECOFIN Council, but the spirit of Parliament weighed on its decisions. This political agreement, which we must take for what it is, is a strong and strong signal from the European Union: it has enabled us to present, in Lima, a common and ambitious front of the European Union for greater fiscal transparency, and I was able to encourage, at the G20 meeting, our partners to do the same and turn this European initiative into a global or global standard.  Mr Ferber expressed a disappointment, somewhat mitigated by Mrs Ferreira, and I would like to respond to that. Of course, you have raised three points: first, the desire to go beyond cross-border tax rulings to include all tax rulings, then a regret that the period of retroactivity was not longer and finally, a nuance on the fact that we could have gone faster in the implementation of this text. To tell you the truth, the Commission does not disagree with you, Mr rapporteur. It is true that the Commission's original proposal went further than what was adopted by the Council, but ladies and gentlemen, you know how the Council works. The procedure is very complicated, we must be able to adopt the tax decisions unanimously and, in this case, we have done so not only unanimously but very quickly, since it took seven months between the tabling of the Commission's proposal and the adoption of this text by the ECOFIN Council, and the Commission has agreed to this compromise.  What for? Because our feeling is that the main principles of our proposal are maintained in this text, including the automatic exchange of tax rulings, including the wide scope covered, including the exchange of information between all Member States, including the Commission's involvement - and this could have been discussed at some point. There is a good dose of retroactivity, ten years would have been better for me than five, but five - forgive me this lapalissade as they say in French - were better than the three years we were offered for a while and which would have started to be problematic. Finally, there is the implementation timetable. I had hoped that the text could come into force as early as the end of the first quarter of 2016, but the States have argued - which is not entirely false, honestly - the deadlines for transposing and voting such texts. In the end, I would say that this is a reasonably ambitious compromise that does not lead - it was essential for me and the Commission, and I can assure you that we would not have consented to anything else - to distort our proposal; it is a good quality compromise, which marks a very significant step.  I would like to stress that the Commission's involvement has been maintained in the compromise text. This is good news, I think, for the Commission, but also for the general interest and for the European Parliament, because this involvement is essential to monitoring the functioning of the directive, it increases the credibility of the member states' commitment, and it is fully supported, I know by you, the European Parliament, and I wanted to thank you for that. If we had remained in a pure exchange between Member States, without the Commission's involvement, the risk - how to say - that the administrations between them would not work in collusion but sometimes with some accommodations could not have been completely ruled out. Let me tell you a few words about the other two reports that are being discussed today. Firstly, the agreement signed on 27 May between the European Union and Switzerland on the automatic exchange of financial information is a historic agreement which marks - and I believe that for our fellow citizens, it is symbolically extremely strong - the end of Swiss banking secrecy for THE residents of the Union. This is a major step in the fight against tax evasion, in line with the objective of ensuring fairer taxation for our citizens. I am pleased that this analysis is shared by the rapporteur, Mr Kofod, in his draft resolution in favour of the conclusion of the agreement and, of course, I urge this House, your Parliament, to follow the opinion of the Committee on Economic and Financial Affairs and to fully support this initiative.  We have also proposed the repeal of the provisions of the Savings Tax Directive, as a result of the entry into force, from next January, of the measures adopted at the end of 2014 on the automatic exchange of financial data. I have some experience in this field, having been minister of finance in a not-so-distant past life. It is regrettable in the first place that the Directive on the taxation of savings was adopted so late, so much so that it fell into obsolescence immediately after its adoption. This must be a lesson for us on the fact that we must move quickly and decisively in this area, but it turns out that the new standard exceeds what the Savings Tax Directive could bring and, therefore, I welcome Mrs Scott Cato's report, which I thank, which calls for the withdrawal of this directive. I allow myself, and she will understand this, to make a small point: I think that the way you have spoken of the President of the Commission, Jean-Claude Juncker, is a bit expeditious and I will defer to what the TAXE committee will say, which, I recall, has heard the President who has come before her. I think it is, when we talk about the head of such an important institution, words that we must be able to master and adjust.  The Commission will report, in the report to the Council and Parliament, on the effectiveness of the measures it is required to present on the operation of automatic exchange of information on the basis of the obligations established by the Directive on Administrative Cooperation in the Tax Field. In the meantime, the Commission will take advantage of the opportunities provided by the structured dialogue with Parliament and its Committee on Economic and Financial Affairs to inform the members of your institution without delay of any significant development. In summary, I think we are now debating what is a major and innovative approach. I call it the transparency revolution: on the one hand there is public pressure, on the other hand the evolution of technology and the media, but also the role of your Parliament, the will of the Commission, and the fact that the Member States also feel committed to action. I am convinced that with our joint action - and we thank the rapporteurs and the various parliamentarians once again - this revolution of transparency will not stop.  I would add that the political will of the Commission, and mine in particular, is, during the five-year term of this Commission's mandate, to continue to move forward resolutely. I am also thinking of the principle of effective taxation, which is that the profits of companies, especially multinationals, are taxed where they are created, I am thinking of reviving the ACCIS/CCTB project, which is important for both transparency and economic efficiency. Finally, I am thinking of the question of the publication of country-by-country information, on which the Commission is moving forward and on I also had the opportunity to express my will. This is indeed a revolution of transparency and today we are recording a stage, but it is not, for us, the end of this fight.

name: Andreas SCHWAB
text: Mr President, i.e. the Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats Madam President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has The subject of the debate today is not only about the report by Mr Ferber, whom I would like to congratulate most warmly on his successful work on this important dossier, but also about the automatic exchange of information with third countries on financial accounts as a whole in the European Union. This is an incredibly complex issue on which we must be careful not to lose sight of the basic logic of cooperation in the European Union, the fundamental logic of the European internal market. For many, the details of the legislation we are talking about here are not really crucial, but it is crucial that the European internal market remains the home market that we promised them years ago for workers and for businesses. And here I think we must be careful, Commissioner, that with the example you have just mentioned, so-called country-by-country reporting, we are not now falling back into the logic of before 1993 and forcing companies to take the individual member's rules more seriously than the European whole. However, I would, of course, deny that the events relating to the Luxleaks affair have called for rapid and decisive action, and that Mr Ferber's report is therefore absolutely in the right direction, namely to speed up the cross-border exchange of tax rulings. In my view, however, it remains to be seen whether we can actually leave the cross-border significance of such rulings to the assessment of the Member States, or whether it does not create a path of incursion that will bring this whole system out of balance. That is why, Commissioner, I would like to urge you to continue and continue this process, which began with the Gibraltar ruling of the European Court of Justice. We are not at the end of this. Third countries, such as Switzerland, naturally also belong here.

name: Peter SIMON
text: Mr President, I would like to make a mifful son, mr President, I would like to make a ido to the S&D Group. Madam President, Commissioner, I would like to thank the Commissioner for her excellent work and for the work she has done. For me, last week's decision against Starbucks and Fiat is no less than a turning point. Because so far we have heard from so many that the behaviour of the past may have been illegitimate, but not illegal. With last week's decision, the European Commission made it clear that we are dealing here with illegal action by states together with companies. If the Member States are serious now with their outwardly so widely postulated request to get changes into the tax rulings, more transparency, fair tax competition, then one wonders if the European Commission is not fully involved in the automatic exchange of information at this point.  The Commission has been so successful in that state aid procedure because, as guardian of the Treaties, it has been able to act directly on competition law. If the Member States now prevent the Commission from being fully informed, then they deliberately do not want to sharpen this sword any further. They have to ask themselves why?  The same applies to the question: to what extent will the tax rulings be exchanged retroactively? If you look at the now well-known, even decided procedures, when the tax rulings come from – yes, these are periods that go back further than the five years whose tax rulings are now to be exchanged. One wonders: is the purpose of this short period perhaps only that more light should not come into the dark? We in Parliament must not let up on this, because we support the Commission at this point in terms of a full exchange of information, a demand for full information – including on past rulings. I believe that without transparency, without this exchange, we in Europe will never be able to change these practices. That is why, Commissioner, you can count on our support at this point.

name: Sander LOONES
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. – Tackling tax fraud and tax avoidance is crucial. If we all want to pay lower taxes, we must also ensure that everyone pays their fair share. We are debating three dossiers today. Two of them are good, technical dossiers with which we adapt our regulations to international standards and eliminate unnecessary legislation. That is a good thing. We are also discussing a third dossier, namely that of the automatic sharing of information about tax rulings. I do have some questions about that. I was very pleased with the European Commission's proposal. Transparency and information sharing is crucial in this area. That is also why our Finance Minister, Johan Van Overtveldt, will actually start passing on this information to other EU Member States from 1 January. But after that, the European Commission's dossier went to the European Parliament, and I think something may have gone wrong there. In a number of amendments, Parliament seems to opt for more bureaucracy and logger procedures. I don't think we need that. If we want to tackle tax fraud seriously, we will also have to focus, then we must choose where to use our resources in the most efficient and most effective way. This is the same as parliament's amendments. If I may give one example: why should we share information about all tax rulings instead of focusing precisely on rulings with an international effect and a link between different Member States? Finally, I am very pleased that the European Council has taken the sensible decision to approve the better regulation.

name: Petr JEŽEK
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Madam President, well, first of all, without trying to encroach on the Commission’s powers, I would like also to endorse the decision outlawing tax rulings that allow big companies to avoid taxes in certain countries of the European Union. This verdict sends a strong signal not only to companies trying to exploit loopholes in tax systems and mismatches between national rules to avoid paying their fair share of taxes, but also to EU Member States, which also have their share of responsibility when it comes to tax fairness. I think this investigation proves once again that it is essential to give the Commission a central role in the process of automatic exchange of information so that it can ensure full compliance with EU law. I really hope Member States will draw the lesson from these cases and agree to give the Commission access to the documents it needs to ensure European companies are treated on a true level playing field. The text of our report goes in the right direction and allows for balanced transparency provisions. Although I can understand some people would like full access to the rulings, I think what matters is to have the key information made available to the Commission. I would like to thank the rapporteur and other shadows for the work done. It resulted in a good report, in my opinion, with a fairly limited number of amendments to be voted and I am glad that it goes against the sort of current trend when we often vote separately on almost every point.

name: Marisa MATIAS
text: gue/NGL Group. – Madam President, I come from a country where nineteen out of twenty listed companies pay taxes in other countries. The tax competition and the laws of elimination of so-called double taxation generate a race to the fund that will only end when the taxation of capital income is equal to zero. The legislation we are discussing here today does not solve this, but at least it can lead to minimum conditions of loyalty between Member States and help governments and citizens become aware of the scale and severity of this phenomenon. Ensuring the automatic exchange of information between tax authorities is of the most elementary justice, that is Mr Ferber's proposal. The tax abuse of multinationals results in a loss of tax or tax income, estimated at 50,000 to 70 billion euros. If we also count on other issues, such as the amount relating to tax avoidance and special agreements, this amount could reach one hundred and sixty thousand, eur 190 billion. This fraud results in an burden of the tax levied on other national economic agents, in particular workers, in the non-fulfilment of civic and social responsibility on the part of businesses, while depriving sovereign states of key resources to comply with their social policies, combat poverty and social inequality and promote economic development. For all this, economic and social inequality increases. One of the main dimensions of transparency is free access to information by the general public and that is why I call on colleagues to support the amendments we are making to allow civic and democratic scrutiny. As for The Report by Scott Cato, I fully support her.

name: Eva JOLY
text: on behalf of the Greens/FTA group. Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner Moscovici, the European Parliament is doing its job. Since 2009, he has been voting on ambitious reports against tax evasion and optimization. When it can, Parliament speeds up its procedures so as not to slow down the progress towards better legislation. When a scandal breaks out, it is in its chamber that majorities are created to put pressure on those who have the initiative.  What is not acceptable is that Parliament is prevented from doing its job. When it supports the urgent transparency, country by country, for multinationals, the Member States barely respond, and you, Mr Moscovici, let the discussion get bogged down. When the TAXE Commission requires access to essential documents to understand who has allowed all these years to do so, its right is flattened and, ultimately, it is the exercise of democratic control that is prevented.  Parliament is not the cash register for other people's arrangements. Polite letters are no longer enough. The battle for fair taxation turns out to be a battle for democracy. It would be nice for the European Commission to take the measure.

name: Marco ZANNI
text: Mr President, president, ladies and gentlemen, i.e. the european Union, the European Union and its Member States are Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I believe that the LuxLeaks scandal has unfortunately served little to change a totally unfair and shameful system. It is from situations such as this that we understand how, within Europe, the Member States are still trying to take advantage of the advantages of their European partners, to the benefit of the large multinationals, which are the only ones who really gain from this absurd rush for tax concessions.  The text we are debating today, which is already unsatisfactory in itself, has in fact been bypassed by an even worse agreement reached by the Council at the beginning of this month. Not only is there no public access to documents, as would be necessary and necessary, but the Member States have decided to limit the automatic exchange of information to cross-border agreements, delaying the entry into force of these rules and throwing everything that has happened in the past into obliviousness. European countries have no will to really resolve this issue and prefer to attract multinationals by making them pay ridiculous taxes. It is, of course, the citizens who are always asked to make sacrifices.

name: Barbara KAPPEL
text: Mr President, I would like to like to take a iendled with the ENF Group. Madam President, Commissioner, I would like to thank the commissioner for her work and for the work she has Competition Commissioner Vestager certainly made a landmark statement last week on fair tax competition, saying that in the first two cases of the LuxLeak scandal, namely the Fiat financial subsidiary and Starbucks, the tax rulings were ruling tax subsidies. In total, however, there were more than 350 tax rulings, tax arrangements and companies which have concluded special agreements with the Luxembourg tax authorities. Many of these companies have paid less than 1 percent tax. This has led to huge tax losses across Europe. The question has arisen today: how high were these failures? There is a study carried out on behalf of the European Parliament, which assumes that up to EUR 190 billion is lost every year in the European Union through profit shifting, special tax arrangements, inefficient tax collection and similar practices. But there is also a similar analysis by the Monetary Fund, which says that it is five per cent of annual corporation tax income that we lose. The OECD shows how unfair this system is. Namely, that multinationals have a strategy of paying only 5% on average, while small medium-sized enterprises pay an average of 30%, while cross-border enterprises pay on average 30% less köSt than exclusively national enterprises. Today's report by Markus Ferber is particularly important because it is the first concrete step towards an automatic exchange of information in the field of taxation. The first concrete step is that tax rulings and transfer pricing agreements need to be exchanged, that there is more transparency in the area of taxation and that there is tax competition and fairness. But that is not enough. There must be more action, as well as country by country reporting, the fair taxpayer seal of approval, the common corporate tax base for entrepreneurs operating in the various Member States. But also patent boxes with preferential arrangements, that tax is paid where the value creation takes place, and an appreciation of the Code of Conduct – group – to name but a few.

name: Ivana MALETIĆ
text: - Madam Chairman, I would like to thank all the rapporteurs who have worked on these important reports and strengthened the European Parliament's messages on how important it is for us to ensure transparency and fairness in taxation at EU level. We want a system where taxes will be paid where economic activity and value creation takes place.  We will not equalize tax rates, but we want systems where tax avoidance is prevented. Tax systems must be simple, stable, safe predictable. They are part of a stimulating environment for entrepreneurs and this is our constant message. Contributing to a simpler system is the abolition of the Savings Interest Income Tax Directive.  This Directive was the basis for establishing the exchange of information on savings interest paid by payers based in one Member State to natural persons resident in another Member State. It is very important from the point of view of transparency and fairness of the tax system, and this is a common goal for all of us. In the meantime, there has been a lot of work to be done to cooperate with Member States and to exchange tax information in order to monitor all financial flows and tax avoidance.  The Directive on Administrative Cooperation in the field of taxation, which created a legislative framework for the application of OECD global standards in the field of automatic data exchange in terms of taxation, has a greater scope than the Savings Interest Income Taxation Directive and that is why we supported its abolition.  In doing so, of course, care should be taken not to lose information and that some countries do not lose insight into the income of their citizens who have had it so far under this Directive, so I urge the European Commission to take this into account.

name: Hugues BAYET
text: Madam President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, as is often the case, the news is catching up with political time, and the Commission has just shown us that, since it has just experienced this by determining that the tax rulings that had been granted to Fiat and Starbucks by Luxembourg and the Netherlands were in fact disguised state subsidies. So we now know that it's not just immoral, it's also illegal. And very clearly, if this text had been voted on in 2011 or 2012, everything in the text that we are going to vote on soon would not have allowed these tax diversions. And so, clearly, this case shows us that the European Council has not yet understood the importance of the issue. I really think that Parliament's text is much more ambitious than this decision of 6 October, and I would like to thank and congratulate our colleague Markus Ferber and all the shadow rapporteurs. This is obviously a compromise text, and I would like to highlight a few important points.  The first, as has been said, is obviously the scope. All the tax rulings of multinationals, without exception, must be analysed, whether national or international, and without a time limit, otherwise, what is the point? Who do we still want to protect? Second, as we all know, the rules are only effective if there are sanctions. And that is what Parliament is asking for, that there be sanctions if Member States do not want to play the game, or if they are dragging on sending information or sending false information. Thirdly, of course, in this process, we want to strengthen the role of the Commission. We all know that, we cannot be a judge and a party. No system works when you are both a judge and a party, and yet that is what the Council wants to achieve. Fourthly, in order to combat these abuses, we must of course call for more transparency. But real transparency, not cosmetic transparency. You know that too much information kills information, and what we are asking for - and what is in this text - is that there be a clear, accessible and understandable publication by all, and not just for specialists.  Finally, I will end with one last point: all companies operating in several countries will receive a European identification number. I think it is essential to more easily monitor it and reduce administrative burdens.  I therefore hope, Commissioner, that you will support this proposal, because apart from a few multinationals and a few Member States, the whole of Europe is losing out, and this can no longer continue in this way.

name: Bernd LUCKE
text: Madam President, this debate, this report, is about fairness, about tax justice – that every taxpayer is responsible for the efficiency, the burden of which is to be borne by the financing of our community. We know from the LuxLeaks documents and from the European Commission's investigations, the first parts of which were published last week, that this justice has been massively violated and that the European Commission has committed illegal state aid here: in the first cases, Fiat Financial Services and Starbucks. But many other cases will follow. I now have absolutely no sympathy for the fact that the Council has decided not to make the cross-border tax rulings available to the European Commission. Its European competence is to ensure competitive fairness. Its European competence is an obligation to refrain from illegal state aid. But then the European Commission must also be informed. It is not possible that only the suspects are their own judges. We need the competence of the European Union, the competence of the European Commission, to prevent distortions of competition and to achieve tax justice.

name: Michael THEURER
text: Madam President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has It is an important finding in the work of the Special Committee on the Clarification of the LuxLeaks Affair that, in fact, the Member States, and also a whole range of companies, have obviously used tax avoidance schemes that have resulted in billions of dollars in tax losses. Above all, however, there is a negative competitive effect because small and medium-sized enterprises, which are only active nationally or which cannot or do not want to use these tax administration models, have disadvantages that add up to 20 to 25%. In this respect, we in the Special Committee are also calling for comprehensive measures to address this. Automatic exchange of information is an important single aspect of this – a necessary, but not a sufficient condition. We learned, for example, during a visit to Switzerland, that in the 1950s a fair tax competition between the cantons was agreed in a concordat, which also includes the automatic exchange of information between the cantons. In addition, however, a common corporate tax base is also required. We call on the Commission to insist that the derogations that the Council has now requested be put in place. The rule that is now on the table is like a Swiss cheese or a Dutch cheese, and this needs to be corrected urgently.

name: Miguel VIEGAS
text: – Monsieur le Président, un avant-propos en français.  Juncker, en tant que ministre du gouvernement luxembourgeois, a conclu des accords avec des centaines de multinationales, de façon à drainer des profits vers le territoire luxembourgeois, et cela constitue un vol des recettes fiscales des autres États membres. Donc je suis désolé, moi, je me fous éperdument qu'il soit président de la Commission ou pape. C'est un voleur, et il n'a pas ma confiance. Désolé, je poursuis en portugais.  Madam President, in the wake of the tax scandals, the European institutions seem to be engaged in this battle against tax fraud and tax evasion. However, we must ensure that all the measures and proposals in progress are not a mere legislative adornment, and that everything is still the same. The Council's proposal on the automatic exchange of information represents a clear setback. The regulation of the exchange of information with Switzerland contains several subterfuge to its compliance. The work of the TAXE Commission has always been hampered. Thirteen governments, including those in the Netherlands, Luxembourg and the United Kingdom, denied access to the Code of Conduct Group documents. Reservations about making information public are a constant; are indications that lead us to doubt the real political will to attack the problem. For our part, we will remain vigilant and vigilant. (The speaker agrees to answer a question posed under the "blue card" procedure (Article 149(8) of the Rules of Procedure))

name: Bill ETHERIDGE
text: blue-card question. – Thank you and good evening to you. I listened with great interest to your speech, especially the first part. Would you agree with me then that, if you have these feelings about Mr Juncker and therefore his Commission, surely anything that comes forward from there is something we should all treat with extreme suspicion and caution and, really, there is nothing that can be said or done by that Commission or this House on this subject that any of us should have any faith in? Would you agree with that?

name: Miguel VIEGAS
text: response according to the "blue card" procedure. "I didn't hear the initial part of the question. However, I must say that these scandals not only affect the President of the Commission, they affect the President of the Eurogroup, they affect the main parties of this House, which have supported all the governments that have made tax agreements for years and years to make life easier for multinationals and to offer them big-hand tax benefits. This therefore really touches on the credibility of the European institutions and also touches on the economic system itself, in which the private interests of large multinationals systematically overtake political power. This is what is at stake today, increasingly clearly.

name: Patrick O'FLYNN
text: – Madam President, let us be clear, it is the existence of the EU itself which has facilitated multinational corporations in aggressively avoiding the potential tax liabilities that would be justified by their turnover in large European countries. Under EU rules, corporations have been able to choose to pay their taxes in any EU jurisdiction rather than the one where economic activity has taken place. This has given smaller EU nations an incentive to strike sweetheart deals with very large multinational businesses and gives micro-states, such as Luxembourg, the opportunity to enrich themselves while also offering a path for huge businesses to avoid paying a fair share of tax in countries where they record the bulk of their sales. So it would be perverse indeed to accept any proposed solution that involves more Europe or more power to the European Commission. The answer, rather, is for nations to take back full tax sovereignty over economic activity within their own borders.

name: Luděk NIEDERMAYER
text: – Madam President, I welcome the report on the automatic exchange of information as this presents important steps in the area of taxation. This is part of an anti-BEPS initiative that should make tax collection more efficient, fairer and better. Parliament only has a consultative role here, but I hope that the Council will listen to Parliament’s opinion in tax matters, as we are aiming to improve the situation and provide our expertise and our opinion. I hope that the Council members will take decisions that are good for the future of Europe and European citizens. Lastly, we should refrain from the idea that more is always better. Instead of going for the most extensive regulations and decisions, we should try to get the best and the most efficient. So we should remember that more is not always better, not only in other areas but also in the area of fighting against BEPS and tax avoidance.

name: Olle LUDVIGSSON
text: Madam President, I would like to begin by thanking Theresa May for It is very positive that a global standard for automatic exchange of information on account information has been established. It is also very good that this standard is starting to be used in the EU at the beginning of next year. The new standard is an important tool against tax evasion and aggressive tax planning, and it is a major step forward. In this context, it is perfectly logical to phase out rapidly the standard used under the Savings Directive. Maintaining dual reporting systems – i.e. both in relation to the Savings Directive and the new standard – would not be reasonable in this case. It would provide a little more information, but the costs in terms of bureaucracy and duplication would be far greater than the value of the information we receive. Over the next 3-4 years, it is extremely important that the European Commission works actively and transparently to make the transition to the new global standard work. This applies not only to eu countries between them, but also to the five European non-EU countries and the 12 territories that will also move from the savings directive standard to the global standard.  The Commission should monitor developments closely and provide continuous information on risks of loopholes and other problems. It must be obvious that this reporting takes place not only in a narrow circle in the Council, but also is shared with Parliament and a wider public. If deficiencies are detected, any measures must be proposed and taken as quickly as possible.  The transition to the global standard for automatic exchange of account information is an excellent opportunity, which must be made excellent use of.

name: Pirkko RUOHONEN-LERNER
text: – Mr President, honest and honourable citizens and businesses have a tradition of paying taxes and charges according to their ability to pay, in accordance with the common rules of the game. However, the LuxLeaks case shows that this is not always the case. If current expenditure continues, Member States will continue to lose a significant amount of tax revenue and will have to take on more debt in order to continue to safeguard the basic services of citizens.  I believe that the tax administration must have sufficient information, as well as the public, on how much taxes companies pay. We have a completely wrong attitude at the moment. Through many business leaders, this wrong attitude has shifted to the public. So, for example, I take a small advertisement to attract Finnish pensioners to Portugal. The ad says: "Move to portugal's Algarve in retirement to enjoy low living costs as well as zero tax. Your euro in Finland may well be 3 euros in Portugal without sylla and polarity." This is how the Portuguese standard of living paradise is marketed to Finns, and I believe that this is a very dangerous attitude that spreads from businesses to citizens. Something should be done quickly to get rid of this attitude.

name: Sylvie GOULARD
text: Madam President, Commissioner, thank you for being here. I observe that the presidency honours us with its absence. Finally, it is a good thing that you are here so that the Commission continues to push, including against the recalcitrant Member States. Let us not be under any illusions, this is one of the issues - putting some order in tax competition in Europe - on which the confidence of European citizens in the European Union is at stake.  After the revelations, in particular, about the extent of the system of tax rulings in Luxembourg and other Member States, we are in a situation of loss of confidence. Rightly so, the text you are pushing on the exchange of information is welcome. Another point I would like to stress, as chair of the anti-poverty intergroup, is that, as the OECD showed in a study last May, the fight against inequality requires better redistribution. If we continue to evade each other's tax matters, there can be no fight against inequality.

name: Fabio DE MASI
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her The spontaneous exchange of information has not worked for 38 years and the EU Commission has been penalising, up to LuxLeaks. This shows that things only happen in the EU when the dirty laundry is aired. Therefore, the central information on tax rulings must be public, national tax secrets must be adapted. Tax deals with authorities are not a private matter. The finance ministers have protected the tax bazaar as long as only their corporations could impose powerful taxes. In committee, we saw that Mr Juncker was able to tell his fairy tales without the majority of the House here wanting to summon him again. The multinationals have treated us like little schoolboys. We, too, are still not getting sufficient access to the documents. That is why words must be followed by deeds. This is a small step for Parliament, but it is far too small a step for the honest taxpayers in Europe. That is why my group will not let up until the tax cartel in Europe has finally been eliminated.

name: Theodor Dumitru STOLOJAN
text: – Finally, the European Union is taking an important step to curb the practice of transnational companies to avoid paying taxes in the Member States where economic activity takes place. By automatically mandatory exchange of information each Member State will have the opportunity to react when another Member State adopts tax comfort letters or transfer pricing arrangements affecting the interests of another Member State.  I have one regret: that in this European Parliament, in previous years, colleagues of mine, as well as myself, we have raised the need for such measures and it took an international scandal to reach this draft directive. Thank you to the rapporteurs, thank you to the Commission for that directive.

name: Othmar KARAS
text: Mr President, Mr Vice-President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has said. I would like to thank the rapporteurs, and Mr Ferber in particular, for his report and his demands, and also for today's debate. We must make it clear to the people that, on the one hand, Commissioner Vestager is repealing illegal tax rulings, on the other hand we are discussing tax privileges in LuxLeaks, and on the third side we are debating more justice, transparency and fairness in tax policy in Parliament. And the Member States refuse to send tax rulings. That is unacceptable! We need more justice, more transparency, more level playing field, we need a common tax base, we need country-by-country reporting, and we need the transmission of tax rulings so that we can get more justice and fairness in the European economy.

name: Tom VANDENKENDELAERE
text: – The European Parliament may not have a formal right to decide on this issue, but the consensus with which we call for a truly effective exchange mechanism is a signal that the Council cannot and must not simply ignore it. Only by giving the Commission a central role in this exchange and giving it access to essential information on tax rulings can new tax scandals be avoided. However, the fear with which the Member States try to shield these rulings, for fear of state aid investigations, is at times a painful spectacle. After all, it is the founding countries themselves who have realised that the common market can only flourish if a European authority is to ensure that individual Member States do not grant anti-competitive aid. That is precisely why the Commission was given the task of taking action against illegal state aid. Why, then, exactly now should remain that useful information on granted tax rulings for the Commission remains a mystery to me. The perverse thing is that these convulsive and misguided attempts to 'protect national sovereignty' ultimately lead to member states being played off against each other, that multinationals are shaking the cards and that citizens and SMEs are being presented with the bill.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I have repeatedly appealed here for the principles of transparency, coherence and protection of savings, so that they remain the backbone of any economic reform. And we know how useful the promotion of the exchange of information can be in combating cross-border tax avoidance.  Unfortunately, with regard to tax rulings, the principle of cooperation and the exchange of tax data between Member States have not yet been fully applied, involving prior disclosure of tax regimes and the calculation of taxes on citizens. The exchange of information is too small and the effects are very serious for the proliferation of harmful tax competition, which exploits precisely this divergence and delay in information.  I therefore agree with the rapporteur that the obligation to provide information for rulings issued in the previous ten years should be retroactive and that greater clarity and effectiveness should be applied. Confidence must also be restored in tax matters and the administrative cooperation tasks assigned to the Member States cannot be compulsory.

name: Romana TOMC
text: – The European Union should take the lead in global discussions on combating tax fraud. Today, Member States exchange very little information on tax decisions. They are often not even informed of decisions having cross-border effect, although this is very important. And it is right that automatic exchange becomes mandatory. This, in my view, will significantly reduce the number of tax evasion and, of course, also reduce the attractiveness of tax-advantaged systems. However, the reasons for hiding in tax-advantaged systems should not only be sought in tax avoidance, but may also be the concealment of beneficial ownership under the auspices of a broadly diversified network of subsidiaries. The resolution is, of course, a concrete step forward, and I hope that the tax system will therefore be more transparent.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: ECR). Mr President, tax evasion and avoidance are the modern scourge of euro area economies. Champions in this anti-social sport have emerged as multinational companies, which through the system of intra-group transactions avoid paying taxes of many billion euros. Euro. Their allies are the various tax havens and some euro area Member States engaged in tax dumping and unfair practices, thus giving multinationals vital space not to pay multi-billion euro in taxes. In countries such as Greece, where multinationals make their super-corporations. Luxembourg with the so-called 'Lux Leaks' and the Netherlands give cover to German and other multinationals in order to avoid tax. And all this at a time when Mr. Dijsselbloem is waving his finger at Greece and demanding a new tax-free resalto in the pockets of the impoverished Greek people. Moreover, Mr Moscovici, the troika in Greece is whistling indifferently and obscuring all Greek governments that refuse to take advantage of the Lagarde list and tax Greek oligarchs who have illegal deposits in Switzerland. I wonder why?

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: Mr. President, the basic question is whose interests we want to protect here. If we want to protect the interests of European citizens or multinational companies, where then we have the egotism of individual Member States that ultimately, of course, go at the expense of European citizens.  That is why, in this context I see positively these proposals and I think that automatic exchange of tax information within the European Union is something that is going in the right direction. Because in this way we really want to protect the totality of the European Union and European citizens. In fact, I think there should be some good thought done and a step forward. We have a common market, we have a number of joint projects, we have a common currency, which is not yet in all member states, but in large numbers it is.  And the question experts ask is whether this common currency without a common tax system or at least a well-coordinated tax system can hold out at all.

name: Igor ŠOLTES
text: – The number of tax evasion and fraud has been increasing in recent years and has serious implications for Member States' tax revenues. As a result, billions of euros a year are lost, which means that certain projects in the public and private sectors cannot be financed as a result. We have recently seen the disclosure of hundreds of examples of exploitation of differences in tax systems and insufficient information from countries on the potential cross-border effects of tax rulings. At present, Member States have the right to decide, of course, whether the tax ruling may also concern other Member States.  Coupled with the severe complexity and differences in tax systems, this may be a recipe for a scandal with an international dimension. I would therefore like to point out that we must strive for greater transparency towards citizens, so it is, of course, only right that the register of tax rulings should also be available to the public.

name: Maria SPYRAKI
text: PPE). Mr President, Commissioner Moscovici, it is a common assumption of those on the market that, while we are discussing strengthening the institutional framework here to tackle tax evasion and avoidance, tax evasion and avoidance are finding other avenues and ultimately overtake us. That is why for me the question is how quickly automatic exchange of information can be applied to the tax system; how quickly it can be made compulsory in practice; how quickly we can have a single business tax register; how quickly we can know where and who has deposits, real estate and movable property, not only within the European Union, but also outside it. The European Union cannot function as an island, and the example of the famous Lagarde list in Greece, the Falciani list, which so many myths cultivates and creates so many problems, only increases the lack of confidence that European citizens have in our ability to tackle tax evasion and tax avoidance.

name: Doru-Claudian FRUNZULICĂ
text: –  Mr President, I welcome the agreement, signed on 27 May 2015, between the European Union and Switzerland on the automatic exchange of financial account information, which will improve international tax cooperation and compliance. Switzerland is a key player, and the agreement is a significant step in our efforts to clamp down on tax fraud and tax evasion. I believe that the automatic exchange of financial accounts between the European Union and Switzerland, starting from 2018, will address situations where a taxpayer seeks to hide capital, representing income or assets for which taxes have not been paid. Also, I think it is very important that the agreement gives the ability to tax administrations in the Member States and in Switzerland to identify correctly the taxpayers concerned, as well as to administer and enforce their tax laws in cross-border situations. At the same time I hope this will help authorities to better assess the likelihood of tax evasion being committed and, in some cases, stop unnecessary investigations.

name: Pierre MOSCOVICI
text: Member of the Commission. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, a few remarks, perhaps, of a political nature, before a few points of precision. Firstly, I absolutely share the rather consensual feeling that emerges from this debate, which is expressed by Mrs Goulard in particular, that we were dealing with an absolutely major question of confidence. It is true that our citizens tend to distrust the public word. It is also true that there is this sense of injustice that can be felt by many Europeans who were called upon to contribute heavily during the crisis, while multinational companies, because they have extensive legal services, can use inequalities, holes, in the tax legislation of a particular Member State to evade tax, pay little or no taxes. where they make a profit. Yes, what we do - I say us - together is essential to the newfound trust. I would add that it is also a question of reducing inequality and, finally, a question of efficiency. With regard to tax evasion, we do not have the figures, because they are extremely difficult to come up with — we will have more data, by the way, after the transparency process has come to an end, because, by definition, there is a lot of data that is unknown. Tax evasion, I believe, is a significant source of revenue for public finances at a time when fiscal consolidation remains an imperative in the European Union, particularly in the euro area, but not just in the euro area.  From day one, this Commission has placed tax justice, transparency, the fight against tax evasion as one of its priorities, and I mean here - the authors of these interjections are no longer present - that I believe that, as much criticism and democratic debate are justified and legitimate, so much we must avoid populism, amalgamations and stigma. We need institutions. We cannot be content with anti-elite reflexes, or the denunciation of a particular personality. And the Commission is acting on this issue in a way, believe it, quite determined, in good faith. I am here naturally as Commissioner for Taxation, because this is my place, but I have the total confidence of President Juncker and carte blanche to move forward in a determined way, and I am working hand in hand with my colleague Margrethe Vestager; that's how we have to work.  I would like to take this opportunity to respond to Mrs. Joly, whom I am pleased to see here. She often exchanges with me indirectly, but I can tell her that the battle against tax evasion should not be confused with the battle against the Commission. In this case, I am convinced that the Commission and the European Parliament have a job to do together, and I would even say side by side. In fact, since you were talking about cooperation between us, in the context of the TAXE committee, I would like to make it clear here that an agreement has been reached with the chairman of this committee so that European parliamentarians can have access to the documents they want. Last week we made 89 documents available to MEPs: the transparency process is total on the part of the Commission, and we must also take into account the Member States and the need for confidentiality of certain data that companies have. Finally, I want to say a word about the Member States. I have heard them here criticised and I have said to Mr Ferber myself earlier how much I can share his regrets and how much I would have liked - that was the meaning of the Commission's original proposal - to go further on this or that subject. I'll get back to that.  But, at the same time, the Member States, they exist. And I see this agreement on tax rulings, this compromise, which I repeat to be of good quality, as an important signal that The Member States too are ready to commit to achieving these objectives, and I welcome that. I am starting to have a little experience of European affairs. I first sat in this Parliament in 1994. I was a member of the Council for seven years, including the 1990s. I have never, ever seen a tax text passed unanimously in seven months with a quality maintained in this way. It is proof that what you, the Members of the European Parliament have been doing, and indeed Mrs Joly have been doing for a long time, what the Commission is doing - and what it is doing in a determined way - is making a difference. So I understand the criticisms, I understand the regrets, but I also say that we must consider that today is an important day and that the report you are about to adopt must also highlight, if you do decide, that we are going in that direction. I would like to thank Parliament for its contribution to what I consider to be a success. I also thank Parliament for its support for The European measures to combat tax evasion and for the attention paid to preventing the use of techniques to evade these measures.  Some answers, now, a little more detailed on some of the questions posed by European parliamentarians.  Firstly, the question of the scope, which I believe is, at this stage, the most important point raised by Mr Ferber's report. The rapporteur believes that the directive should cover all tax rulings and not just cross-border tax rulings. It is true that, in this regard, the Commission itself had proposed to limit the scope of the compulsory exchange of information on cross-border tax decisions and transfer pricing agreements. The Council's compromise text also targets these cross-border decisions covering a wide range of such decisions.  Why would you do that? I would start by saying that the extension to non-cross-border decisions would have had, and would have the effect of significantly increasing the administrative burden of public authorities, without perhaps allowing the tax authorities to focus or focus their attention on the main issues. In addition, we have acted on the legal basis offered by the treaty, which is the legal basis of the internal market. The question is whether the other rescripts could be affected by this legal basis. However, I do not think, Mr rapporteur, ladies and gentlemen, that we should be considered to have reached the end of the story. I think it is quite relevant that the European Parliament continues to insist on this dimension, since in a later phase we may have to go further on an appropriate legal basis; that is the position that the Commission, through me, is defending here. On retroactivity, another important point made by Mr Ferber, the Council's compromise text provides for a five-year retroactivity, which is shorter than the ten years suggested by the Commission. But I draw your attention to a point that you will not have missed: we are faced with a wider field that covers not only all the rescripts still valid issued since 2012, but also those that are no longer valid if they were made between 1 January 2014 and 31 December 2016. The compromise also provides an exemption for SMEs with annual net sales of less than 40 million euros, with the exception of those that mainly carry out financing and investment activities.  That is what led us, which led me, in the discussions in the Council, to take into account the arguments that have been presented to us, and I think in the end that a five-year period, in combination with the exemption granted to SMEs, with the wider scope of the rescripts, allows for a balanced and solid compromise, and that is why the Commission has gone in the direction of this compromise.  In particular, Mr. Bayet asked me about a tax identification number. The Commission's proposal does not include a provision on the use of a European tax identification number. What for? For a simple reason: because such a number does not yet exist today. Nevertheless, this is a technical but also a political issue on which the Commission has been working since its 2012 action plan to combat tax evasion and evasion. That is a modality that I think is important, but we could not, and we cannot, wait for such a number to start exchanging rescript information. Finally, two final points: firstly, the issue of sanctions which has been raised by many of you and which had already been raised, I remember, at my first hearing before the TAXE Committee. The mechanism we have chosen is a mechanism that addresses the impact that transparency can have on the behaviour of multinationals. I'm betting here - and I think he'll be a winner - that's what it's going to be. Transparency will have the effect - contrary to the Law of Gresham, which, as you know, drives the right currency in favour of the bad - to, I am sure, to remove the bad rescripts, that is, those who lend to abusive or aggressive uses in favour of techniques of forecasting, anticipating the position of companies, which are not in themselves reprehensible. We did not choose to ban rescripts, we chose transparency. As for the Commission's presence in the scheme, I can assure you that it is a battle that I delivered, on foot, in front of those who thought it was superfluous. The presence of the Commission ensures that there is an arbitrator somewhere who can then initiate proceedings. And that is why the work that we are going to do together, together with my colleague Margrethe Vestager, is proof that there can be such mechanisms, and we will obviously have a stronger basis with the new directive, which I believe will be adopted as a result of the Commission's proposal, the Council's agreement and your own report. Finally, I would like to remind you that the fight for transparency is a fight that will not stop. I have spoken here of the revolution of transparency, and I can assure you of our political determination, that of the Commission, of my personal political determination, to go all the way. I repeat here what I said in our introductory remarks, namely that this Commission wants to take over the ACCIS or CCCTB project, including the consolidation that is necessary for companies for reasons that are both transparent and effective. I repeat that this Commission wants to show what the principle of effective taxation can bring. We are in an absurd situation where too many multinational companies, for the reasons you know, do not pay, or pay little tax where they make a profit. Again, it is a question of trust that will have to be resolved. Finally, the Commission is working on the publication of country-by-country information. I ask the European Parliament for a little more patience and a little more confidence. My colleague Jonathan Hill and I wanted to put in place an approach which, it is true, starts with a consultation and will have to continue with an assessment, a test, an evaluation. It is not a question of evacuating the question, but of seeing under what conditions the publication of country-by-country information can reconcile transparency and economic efficiency without penalising the business investment that is necessary for employment. For my part, I have expressed a very clear political preference, namely that, which said advertising, means public access. But we also have to take economic realities into account.  So we are at the bottom of an alternative: either we will follow what the OECD says, which, I remind you, to stick to exchanges between administrations, or we go further - I repeat, it is rather my personal preference, provided that it does not penalise companies. That is why, ladies and gentlemen, I thank you for your participation in this debate, I thank the rapporteurs and the shadow rapporteurs for their work. I think that beyond the differences or the nuances, we all agree that there is a new political approach that allows us to go further, to go harder and to go faster. You're contributing to it.

name: Markus FERBER
text: Rapporteur. Mr President, I would like to thank the Commissioner, i would like to thank you for this policy speech on taxation, which, of course, goes far beyond the issues that we have to decide today or tomorrow. I would like to thank you for your good cooperation on my report. I very much regret, and I would like to make this very clear, that the Council bench is empty. After all, much of what has been criticised today by my fellow Members was not addressed to the Commission, but to the right-wing side of the Council, which I see as a right-wing, and which shines with great emptiness. It is very regrettable, because the Council has to learn that the European Parliament is also a serious partner in tax matters. I have also tried to make this role clear in the reporting. I would like to thank my shadow rapporteurs very much for their good cooperation. We have managed to deal with this complex topic here in a very short time. I hope that tomorrow we will send a clear signal to the Council by a large majority in plenary. Now I would like to say once again that we are sending this signal to the Council, not to the Commission. The Commission has done its homework with the Tax Rulings. The Council, on the other hand, should reconsider its political agreement of October and take up some of the things that we as a Parliament are calling for. This would be a great asset for tax honesty, tax justice and transparency in Europe. That should also be in the interest of the Member States.

name: Peter SIMON
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to make a special Mr President, I would like to thank the On behalf of the unfortunately prevented rapporteur, as coordinator of the Socialists in the TAXE Special Investigation Committee, I would like to say a few words to the Commission. I agree with Mr Ferber's words that we are working together with the Commission on this construction site, that we are happy about many of the things we have achieved, but that, conversely, we are also putting our finger in the wounds where we think we are far from far enough. As far as the work of the TAXE Special Investigation Committee is concerned, I have just received a message today which confuses me somewhat and which will perhaps also affect our future work. I would like to thank the Commission for its efforts, in the interests of transparency, to provide us with the documents requested by Parliament, within the framework of what is possible under the interinstitutional agreement. Today I learned that the same documents, some of which were not blackened or only made available to us and made available only in the reading room, were issued for the purpose of research to research institutions that would have asked for public documents as normal as part of the access of European Union citizens. If that is the case, then we have a problem! I know that you will certainly not be able to respond explicitly here today, but we will come to you in writing. It is already very difficult for us to work in full on the basis of the documents submitted. We accept the interinstitutional agreement. However, if there is already a public beyond this, I can already announce at this point that we will insist on being treated in the same way as third parties. That is what the dignity of this House demands.

name: Molly SCOTT CATO
text: rapporteur. – Mr President, in winding up this debate I would like to note that it has demonstrated very well the amount of common ground there is across the House. There has been really good cooperation on all the files we have been considering and I found great support from my shadows on my file.
