There has also, I have noted, been quite a lot of movement amongst Members of this House on the issue of tax, partly as a result of citizen outrage at multinational tax avoidance, but also as they have learned more – as they have gathered more information as a result of the TAXE Committee – and in my mind that is one of the main achievements of the TAXE Committee. To do our job properly we need information and we need evidence. How else can we make good policy? I welcome the statement from the Commissioner that more documents have been made available, but I am afraid that having documents in a reading room where they are effectively behind lock and key is simply not good enough. It does not feel like transparency and we need to have better access to information than that. We also need to protect whistleblowers who are acting in the common good. We do not always see eye to eye across the different political groups in this Parliament, but we have cooperated to protect public tax revenue and to ensure that there is a level playing field between the corporations who can arrange to reduce their tax contributions and the SMEs that are the backbone of our European economy. This issue of tax is of great concern to citizens, and I join with my colleague, Mr Ferber – who I know has now had to leave for the TAXE Committee – in calling for Member States to work with us on this. We appreciate the support from the Commission, but we also need Member States to work with us on ensuring that ending tax avoidance is treated as an urgent priority, because it is an urgent priority for all our citizens.

name: Antonio TAJANI
text: The joint debate is closed. The vote will take place on Tuesday 27 October at 1.00 p.m. Written declarations (Rule 162)

name: Birgit COLLIN-LANGEN
text: Writing. I support the agreement signed in May 2015 and hope that it can be implemented as soon as possible. We need a legally secure basis on the basis of which effective measures can then be taken against tax evasion. With the abolition of banking secrecy, we are taking an important step in the fight against tax evasion. Only with greater transparency and fair rules will we be able to ensure that tax evasion is a thing of the past in the not too distant future.

name: Isabella DE MONTE
text: in writing. Harmful tax competition and cross-border tax avoidance are unacceptable practices that the European institutions face in order to build a more honest and supportive model of the Union among all the citizens of the Member States.  It is unacceptable that there should be tax planning between the Member States of the Union with market players in order to create competitive disadvantages between the States themselves. The report on the compulsory automatic exchange of information in the tax field is therefore the way to solve some of these problems by building stricter European tax standards. In addition, information exchange practices on tax rulings between Member States are encouraged. In fact, tax rulings from instruments designed to provide legal certainty for taxpayers have become agreements to the detriment of other Member States.  For this reason, Parliament has taken strong action in this area, strengthening the text on a number of points, such as the frequency of the exchange of information and the information to be provided, and extending the scope also to preventive tax rulings and agreements on price fixing.

name: Paloma LÓPEZ BERMEJO
text: in writing. – The Ferber report is aimed at improving transparency in the exchange of information in the tax field, so we voted in favour. It is a text that would not see the light if it were not for Mr Deltour's courage to ensure that Europe could know the complicity of Juncker and European governments in large-scale tax avoidance. However, we should not confuse this proposal with the possibility of genuine public scrutiny or as an automatic brake on tax avoidance. The mechanisms with which large multinationals avoid their taxes, among which the tax agreements covered by this proposal remain in force and are known and covered by the various governments. Clear and transparent rules are not enough: we also need to commit ourselves to a fair and progressive fiscal system. In this regard, we lack political confidence in the Juncker Commission to expect it to use the new instruments at its disposal to effectively control and regulate tax avoidance. Europe is still a long way from responding to the LuxLeaks scandal.

name: Evelyn REGNER
text: Writing. Mr President, I would like to thank the president for his excellent work and for the work he has done unfortunately, the Commission's proposal on the automatic exchange of information has been watered down by the finance ministers on many important points. This is despite the commitment of the finance ministers to work for fair tax competition! The decisions on Starbucks and Fiat show us how important it is to apply retroactively to existing ones. In both cases, the period is longer than the five years required by the finance ministers. We want such illegitimate cases to continue to be declared illegal. Even if they are longer behind! That is why we are calling for all valid rulings to be exchanged for legal persons, whether they are cross-border or not. We demand that more information be exchanged, such as tax identification numbers, or that the exchange of rulings be done immediately and not only after months! If the finance ministers are committed to fair tax competition, then they must act accordingly and take their decisions too! This report contains a number of good measures to bring more transparency into the jungle of the rulings.

name: Antonio TAJANI
text: The next item is the recommendation for second reading by the Committee on the Internal Market and Consumer Protection on package tours and related tourist services (09173/3/2015 - C8-0281/2015 - 2013/0246(COD)) (Rapporteur: Birgit Collin-Langen) (A8-0297/2015).

name: Birgit COLLIN-LANGEN
text: Rapporteur. Mr President, Commissioner Moscovici, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the commissioner for his excellent work and for the work she has done. I am pleased that we can vote tomorrow on the recasting of the Package Travel Directive. Changes in the travel market and the growing trend towards online travel bookings have made it urgently necessary to modernise and adapt the 1990 Directive. In the meantime, a wide range of new and online booking models have emerged which are not covered by the current directive. Today, there is no longer only the classic package tour, but different elements of a trip can be put together according to the wishes of the traveller. The revised rules will strengthen the rights of travellers in Europe as a whole. New booking models are now covered by the scope and travellers will be more comprehensive and better informed about their rights. However, we have also succeeded in taking into account the economic interests of the providers – e.g. tour operators, travel agencies or hoteliers – so that the result found takes into account both their and the interests of the travellers in a balanced way.  For Parliament's negotiating team, the inclusion of click-through bookings within the scope of the directive and its equality with the classic package holiday was mandatory. Click-through bookings are such bookings on the Internet where certain data of the booker is automatically transferred. Therefore, if you book a flight first and then a second travel service, i.e. a hotel, the name of the traveller and the payment methods are automatically transferred. We want the same liabilities to be granted here and the same insolvency protection as for a package holiday, because this type of booking gives the impression that you are booking a package by clicking on the next website. In the beginning, the Council had spoken out against the equality of click-through bookings. This would have meant that in such a case there would have been no liability and no insolvency protection for the entire package. It would have been just the reduced form. The booker, the traveller should have contacted the respective provider in order to get his rights. We were then able to reach the compromise by adding the e-mail address in addition to the name and payment methods. We have had a very difficult time for Parliament on this issue, because we cannot rule out the possibility of circumventing the way in which the very narrow definition of click-throughs is now possible. That is why we could only agree to the compromise if, after three years, the Commission – as it has promised – carries out a review to see what the outcome of the click-throughs is, if it is recorded, if it is not covered, if necessary, it needs to be adjusted or extended to the definition. Overall, we have managed to make the text clearer and more comprehensible and to enforce many of the European Parliament's first-reading points. For example, we have introduced the definition of ancillary services which are not intended to justify a package holiday. We have been able to make it clear that it makes no difference whether you rent a car or a motorbike; together with a flight or booked accommodation, this combination automatically becomes a package holiday. We have introduced a uniform right of withdrawal, whereby the consumer can withdraw from the contract free of charge if the price increase is more than eight percent. In addition, we were able to enforce better conditions for the consumer in exceptional and unavoidable conditions on site. If, in the event of exceptional unavoidable circumstances, the tour operator is unable to transport the package traveller back, the tour operator will now have to cover the costs of the extended stay of up to three nights. Against the background of the ash cloud in 2010, such a regulation was important to us. Parliament had asked for five nights, and the compromise was then three, but with the caveat that if, for example, the Passenger Rights Directive were to be enforced for five days, that would also apply here. I would like to take this opportunity to express my special thanks to the Latvian Presidency and the negotiating team in the Council, to the colleagues of the Commission, to our staff on the IMCO Committee, who have been effectively available at all times, to my shadows and their staff and to the staff of our political groups. The negotiations were very intense. Nevertheless, despite the initially very different positions, we were able to reach a satisfactory agreement. I would like to ask you to read your report tomorrow To give your approval - thank you very much!

name: Pierre MOSCOVICI
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, tourism is an important sector of the European economy. The 1990 Package Travel Directive gave consumers important rights regarding pre—arranged packages and established a legal framework for the package travel sector. I am speaking now on behalf of Mme Jourová, who cannot be here, and I wish to applaud her for the job that has been done. Digital technologies have changed the way in which we organise our travel. Today, consumers are increasingly seeking customised combinations of travel services online instead of ready-made products from a travel brochure. This is increasingly tending to mean that travellers are either not protected by the directive or else the protection is unclear. That is why it was necessary to modernise the existing EU rules on package travel so as to make them fit for the present digital age. The new directive on which you will vote tomorrow will offer protection not only for pre—arranged packages, but also for customised combinations of travel services, known as dynamic packages, especially if they are booked online. At the same time, the new directive will provide a minimum level of protection for linked travel arrangements which are looser combinations of travel services. There will be clear information for travellers on whether they are being offered a package with full protection or a linked travel arrangement with limited protection, including compulsory standardised information. These changes will double the share of protected trips in the EU from 23% to 46% and will bring almost 120 million additional trips a year within the scope of the directive. Furthermore, the right of travellers who buy a package will be improved and clarified. There will be clearer rights for travellers when something goes wrong during the trip and improved termination rights. Travellers will be entitled to extended accommodation for at least three days if the return journey cannot be carried out on time because, for example, a natural disaster. There will also be explicit rules on liability for booking errors.  As agreed during the interinstitutional negotiations, I would like to confirm that when revising the 2009 guidance on the application of Directive 2005/29/EC on unfair commercial practices, the Commission will also address the issue of commercial practices whereby travel services providers who market their services online offer additional services in an unclear or ambiguous manner, such as hiding the option of not booking any further services, and the Commission will inform Parliament on how its views have been taken into account when the revised guidance is adopted, which is fast. Travel businesses will also benefit from the new directive. Outdated requirements for travel brochures will be abolished and managed business travel will be exempted from the directive. Finally, increased harmonisation, for instance with regard to precontractual information requirements, in the light of the rules, as well as the mutual recognition of the insolvency protection obtained in other Member States will facilitate cross–border transactions, thereby enhancing consumer choice. Ladies and gentlemen, the text that is now presented to you for adoption is the result of very intensive and, I must say, sometimes difficult negotiations and compromises between the Council and Parliament. I would like to extend my thanks in particular to Mrs Birgit Collin-Langen, the rapporteur on this file, the shadow rapporteurs, and Mrs Vicky Ford, the Chair of the Internal Market and Consumers Committee who all were instrumental in coming to an agreement with the Council.

name: Andreas SCHWAB
text: Mr President, i.e. the Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has I too, of course, would like to begin by thanking all those who have been involved in this dossier, which has been negotiated for years, very warmly. That was the case with Mr Hans-Peter Mayer in the last parliamentary term, and it then passed into the really excellent hands of Birgit Collin-Langen, who made this dossier a truly acceptable compromise. Because we in the European Parliament talk so often about compromises and end up not getting to the point, I would like to use my remaining speaking time to present this compromise. It is true that, with this revision of the Package Travel Directive, we are adapting to the digital age, with more and more tourists booking their journeys via the Internet, entering into a cascade of links with which they are linking more and more services that they accept as related services, and the break-up of which would ultimately mean a really difficult situation for them in the time of travel.  With this directive, with the restrictions that the rapporteur has mentioned, we are really taking this into full account. However, it is true that when defining the package holiday as we have now done, it is also possible for small tourism companies, such as small Alpine hotels or small hotels in the Black Forest – a region from which I come – that when the customer not only books the hotel for two nights, but also wants to have the visit to the swimming pool opposite the hotel, it is possible to have the hotel handled by the hotel. , in the end, a package holiday could also have been achieved from a legal point of view. It will be important here that we achieve the balance between consumer rights on the one hand and a fair functioning internal market in tourism on the other. However, I am confident that this will succeed. (The speaker agreed to answer a question on the 'blue card' procedure under Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure)

name: Paul RÜBIG
text: Question about the procedure of the "blue card". Thank you very much. I would also like to thank Mr Schwab. For me, the question arises as to what advantage the hotels and small and medium-sized enterprises actually have of this directive. It will certainly lead to more employment, because it will of course be a little more complex to deal with these things. Lawyers will perhaps also earn something from it and, of course, there will also have to be an increase in prices in this area, because of course insurance companies will also benefit here. Can we estimate how this will affect tourism in Europe in general?

name: Andreas SCHWAB
text: Answer to a question about the "blue card" procedure. Thank you very much, Mr Rübig, for this question. I believe that, in the end, in a large market dominated by many consumers, legal certainty is always the best way to promote growth in this market.  That is why I believe that it is possible to say first of all that legal certainty will benefit everyone. However, I do not want to hide the fact, mr President, that, of course, in individual cases, the importance for small and medium-sized travel agencies will increase the importance of taking out an insurance policy, the costs of which, to my knowledge, must not be overestimated. It may, of course, be difficult in one case or another for hoteliers who continue to operate their business under national tenancy law to bring this into line with European rules. However, I believe that hoteliers in Europe are all men enough to meet this challenge, and I wish them all the best.

name: Sergio Gaetano COFFERATI
text: On behalf of the S&D. – Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I too would like to thank Mrs Collin-Langen, the chairman of the committee and the other Members who have worked on this measure for many months. It was essential for Europe to change the plan of rules that affect not only the tourism sector, but even before that people who decide, in their lives, to take part in trips, and sometimes do so for leisure and sometimes even do so for work. A great many things have changed over the last 25 years, starting with the new services offered online, and the lack of legal certainty, as Andreas Schwab mentioned a moment ago, has caused harm to users. The people and consumers who decided to move for the reasons I mentioned earlier have always been penalised. We have now broadened the scope of assisted tourism services and this is an important step forward. We have excluded specific sectors from the directive with a positive compromise such as the one on business travel or on the packages put together by non-profit-making associations. The text has also been significantly improved with regard to contractual and pre-contractual information, and I consider this to be at the heart of the measure. People and users are strong when they know, when they have the opportunity to know and when, on the basis of knowledge, they can possibly resort to a third-party judgment which, however, is based on elements of certainty that we did not have before. Consumer rights are a major problem for Europe. I believe that this directive, on a specific issue, has made progress in the right direction. We must now ensure that the rules are properly transposed and applied. But this is a task for each country.

name: Anneleen VAN BOSSUYT
text: on behalf of the ECR. – In the package travel dossier, it was important to strike the right balance between protecting the rights of consumers and those of the tourism sector. I think we have succeeded in this, thanks to the good leadership of our rapporteur. Consumers who book online will be protected at the same level as those who do so through a travel agency. They will also be protected against price increases, bankruptcies of service providers and unforeseen and unavoidable situations such as natural disasters, as we have seen with the eruption of the volcano in Iceland. Clear rules are also laid down on the termination of the contract and on the information that traders must provide before, during and after the conclusion of the contract. On the other hand, we have also succeeded in ensuring that we do not destroy the sectors concerned due to unnecessary or bad regulation.

name: Dita CHARANZOVÁ
text: on the alde group. – Mr President, Commissioner, many consumers in the EU now live online – shopping, searching for travel services over the Internet. In the Czech Republic, for example, 2 million trips a year are made, more than half of them. So I am happy to support today this proposal for a directive that takes into account the digital revolution and seeks to make life easier for us, citizens who are composing our travel packages over the Internet. The holiday is, or should be, a moment of rest and relaxation for us, but unfortunately many of us have already experienced situations where not everything develops according to our needs. These feelings are doubled at the moment when we do not know who to turn to, from whom to get help. For this reason, I welcome the fact that the new directive answers these questions, clearly gives the rights and obligations of consumers, we will know who is responsible for what, and we can also know who to contact and claim compensation for. I also welcome the fact that once this directive enters into force, each of us will have the opportunity to transfer our travel packages to someone else if we cannot travel for any reason. We will not lose our money in case of illness or when the work will not allow us to do so. This directive, in my view, represents a good compromise between the defence of consumer rights, on the one hand, but also the possibilities of small and family-owned tourism businesses, which my colleague Schwab referred to. We have managed to prevent attempts to charge passengers with additional costs, while ensuring that every traveller is given services at the high level they rightly expect. I believe that this new directive will benefit all travellers, that it will kick-start even more tourism. We can only regret at the moment that it cannot enter into force earlier.

name: Igor ŠOLTES
text: Mr President, commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, i would like to thank the rapporteur for his excellent work. – First, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her good cooperation and, above all, for the effort we have made to negotiate with the Council. I would like to emphasise the following, that tourism in Europe plays an important role, because the sector, together with the related sectors, accounts for as much as 10% of European GDP. That is why, of course, it is all the more important that we have such a directive. Mainly because it at the same time allows consumer protection and does not impose too much bureaucratic burden on small and medium-sized enterprises, but also, of course, also allows for a fairer position for small and medium-sized enterprises, especially since, at the outset, large companies, which are stronger players in the market for package insurance providers, have also been kind of favoured. And most importantly, here consumers are protected, they just need to be sufficiently well informed.

name: Margot PARKER
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. – Mr President, enhancing consumer protection and consumer rights is something I will always advocate for as long as I remain a politician. I cannot, however, support these proposals. Fundamentally, I take issue with the fact that this directive allows little or no scope for Member States to make changes that diverge from its provisions. By imposing this ridiculous level of harmonisation, you are simply presuming that all changes to this directive will be suitable for all 28 Member States. Well, I can tell you something today, that is not the case. For my country, the United Kingdom, these changes are not entirely suitable. If I may reference a UK government report directly, the proposal is far from perfect. Why should the UK Government be bound to abide by something it does not fully support? Once again, this is just another example of the EU enforcing a one—size—fits—all policy with total disregard for the individual needs of Member States. What I say is let us increase protection for consumers, but let us allow national government to regulate that protection.

name: Franz OBERMAYR
text: Mr President, I would like to like to take a iendled with the ENF Group. Mr. President! In fact, the recasting of the directive will make holidaymakers better off in the future by asking them for easier recourse, central contact points and simple help even in emergencies. But at first too little consideration was given to the tour operators. Especially in a tourism country such as Austria, the plan to substantially increase the liability of small and medium-sized hotel companies, as well as travel agencies, met with considerable criticism.  In some respects, this criticism was also received positively, so that travel agencies can now offer certain services in the package without automatically becoming liable for the organisers. Nevertheless, the bureaucratic burden on tourism companies will increase in the future, which will inevitably lead to additional financial burdens, as shown by the example of the obligation to safeguard their own insolvency. On the other hand, the directive could well have gone further in favour of holidaymakers. For example, click-throughs, i.e. the click-through offers, are now covered by the policy. However, only cases are recorded in which the holidaymaker's name, e-mails and credit card details are transferred from one page to the next, which is completely unusual in practice. In this context, I also welcome the introduction of a revision clause to respond to further developments in the online sector. The directive is therefore a step in the right direction, in particular improving the legal protection of holidaymakers. But if we look at them in their entirety and with the consequences, there is still a lot of discomfort and concern for our small and medium-sized tourism enterprises.

name: Ildikó GÁLL-PELCZ
text: – The original travel package directive dates back to the mid-1990s, but much has changed since then. Low-cost flights, online ticket purchases and what appear to be packages have led to a new situation. I would like to thank Mrs Collin-Langen, who has reviewed this directive superbly and adapted it to the requirements that we face every day. I believe that this amendment is a very serious step forward in making sure that consumers do not find themselves in a grey area and are not able to make costly changes. I think that this definition, which we will now address, will be used to give consumers greater certainty. Therefore, Mr President, we will certainly support this proposal not only on my behalf, but also on behalf of the delegation.

name: Evelyne GEBHARDT
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the With the revision of this directive, we have taken a very important step forward by taking into account the way in which citizens organise their journeys online today. That is an important question. I very much welcome the progress that has been made in this area. However, there is still a problem: the definition of the journeys that are envisaged here is very open, so there are many loopholes for those who do not want to take our law very seriously. That is why it is right and proper that we have said that, by 2018 at the latest, we must re-examine whether we are really up to date or whether we do not actually need to adapt the law, especially for these click-through orders.

name: Daniel DALTON
text: – Mr President, we will also support this. The last time the package travel rules were updated was in 1990. That was before the internet started transforming every industry, and so we need to bring these rules into the digital age. This will allow click-through holidays to have the same protection as those bought through high street travel agents. Twice as many people will be covered, and that is vital. If an operator goes bankrupt, or if a natural disaster or a terrorist attack disrupts a holiday, people will not be stranded just because they booked online. They will also be protected from last-minute hikes, allowing them to cancel if the price goes up by more than 8% after purchase. These safeguards are good not just for holiday-makers, but also for the travel industry; they will give people more certainty and confidence to book in the first place. This makes the legislation fit for the digital age and, in the context of the digital single market, that is vital. It allows consumers to have the protection they expect without constraining new business models. That is something we should bear in mind when looking at other sectors.

name: Carlos COELHO
text: – Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, the current rules on package packages are obsolete in the face of a paradigm shift in the travel market and the new realities of the digital age, where consumers are increasingly booking personalised journeys over the Internet, either from an operator or from various commercially connected operators. European consumers are therefore less protected because existing standards were designed for traditional package travel, where everything was pre-organised by the travel agency. For us, consumers must be at the heart of the internal market. The dispersed legislation of some Member States to fill this legal vacuum and the wide margin of manoeuvre that has been given to the transposition of the Directive are also not a solution. There is a fragmentation of the internal market, harmonisation is needed and therefore it was so important to amend the Package Travel Directive. The Commission, Parliament and the Council have been well in agreeing to update this important sector for the European economy. A word of praise for the work done by Mrs Birgit Collin-Langen, as rapporteur, who has made it possible to reach the agreement between the European Parliament and the Council in this dossier, achieving a necessary balance between a high level of consumer protection and the protection of a free space without borders for the movement of goods and services and freedom of establishment.

name: Catherine STIHLER
text: – Mr President, thanks are due to the rapporteur and the shadows. Twenty-five years ago, when the original Package Travel Directive came into being, few of us in this room had an e—mail address, never mind a mobile phone, so fast—forwarding to 2015 and making this directive fit for purpose for our digital world are vital to ensure that consumer rights are protected. I welcome the inclusion of click-through, a linked arrangement which some people call dynamic travel, the new insolvency and liability coverage, the improved consumer information, which will ensure that a consumer will know exactly who to go to and how should unforeseeable circumstances arise, and also the protection of three days’ coverage if something bad happens, as this will ensure that the traveller is much better protected. I know that this deal was hard fought for, and I welcome the review in 2018. Now it is up to the Member States to put this directive into law and I would like to see that happen sooner rather than later to ensure that consumers can benefit from these new rules as quickly as possible.

name: Maria GRAPINI
text: – Mr President, I want to stress from the outset that Europe has an excellent opportunity for tourism, but unfortunately there are still many barriers, and one of the barriers was also this outdated directive. I believe that what has been achieved now, of course, is not ideal, but the proposal that I have heard here, also from the rapporteur, and from colleague Evelyne, to review in three years' time is welcome. I very much believe that a piece of legislation must be adapted to the newly created situation. I believe that a balance must be achieved, and a large deal, has been achieved between consumer protection and the possibility of small agencies, small hotels developing tourism activity; and I also believe that subsidiarity and proportionality must also be respected. I would like to congratulate her, because it was a very difficult report, a long-awaited report by the tourism industry, and I think it is very necessary to explain some terms that now appear in this legislative amendment, terms that created confusion and which often made travellers unable to defend themselves in cases created by non-compliance with the conditions of the contract. I congratulate her and hope that in three years' time we can have an even better report.

name: Bogusław LIBERADZKI
text: – Mr President, I am a member of the Committee on Transport and Tourism (TRAN) so, on its behalf, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent job indeed. The objectives of the TRAN Committee were as follows. First, that the new directive should ensure that consumers’ benefits from the higher level of protection when purchasing a combination of travel services are guaranteed. Secondly, at the same time, it is necessary to establish a level playing field between market players and selling travel packages. Then, removing legal obstacles at cross-border level and reducing compliance costs for business people.  Concluding the outcome of the negotiations between the Council and Parliament, we welcome the fact that the Committee on Internal Trade and Consumer Protection in good co—operation with the Committee on Transport has achieved the following: a strong insolvency protection for travellers which would cover all reasonably—foreseeable costs and clarification of travellers’ rights. Let me be very clear, it responds to the challenges related to internet development in travel arrangements.

name: Othmar KARAS
text: Mr President, Commissioner, I would like to thank the commissioner for her work and for the work she has We must not turn a blind eye to the fact that the joy we feel here, the joy of consumers, has not yet reached all entrepreneurs, because they feel restricted in their entrepreneurial activity, in their entrepreneurial freedom, and as a service provider to their customers. I therefore call for all companies to be fully informed, that we allow a more appropriate solution for transposition into national law, that we take the evaluation seriously in three years' time and also that we also offer that we are prepared to build on the experience. What are the reasons for these concerns? On the one hand, there is legal uncertainty in SMEs because of the unclear definitions. It is complained that travel can only become a package holiday after the booking has been completed. It complains that the threshold of 25% of the total price of additional tourist services is too low, and there are fears that the bureaucracy is burdensome because, depending on the occasion, it is necessary to assess which legal regime is applied. We must ensure that bureaucracy is not excessive. We must ensure legal certainty and we must remove the uncertainties that exist in companies. This can only be done with open access to implementation and more information.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the updating of the 1990 directive on travel, holidays and package packages responds to the demands of the tourism industry and consumer organisations. It is necessary, in fact, to revise some important provisions of the directive which, out of obsolescence, end up not meeting the needs of a globalised market, creating unnecessary obstacles to the market, such as the obligation to inform brochures and the inclusion of professional travel managed by specialised agencies.  Consequently, the key principles on which legislation must be based are, in my view, those of amplifying choice, lowering prices for consumers and removing obstacles to cross-border trade, for a benefit that also benefits companies in the sector. Furthermore, the legal fragmentation of legislation not harmonised by the Member States also generates additional costs for companies that want to operate across borders due to the lowering of the level of consumer protection. In short, the directive should be revised in order to improve the functioning of the internal market in tourism and to ensure fair competition and consumer protection, including through the imposition of adequate guarantees of repayment of advance sums and the return of travellers in the event of insolvency.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: ECR). Mr President, the tourism sector plays an important role in the completion of the internal market, while at the same time being a pillar of growth for the economies of the European Union and especially for Greece. Although millions of EU citizens prefer package travel and package holidays, different national practices nevertheless create obstacles to competition and, above all, to the freedom to provide services relating to package travel. Measures are therefore needed to protect consumers who buy package packages, in particular in relation to the insolvency of the organiser and especially tour operators. On the other hand, tourism packages must be structured in such a way as to contribute to the development of local economies in a balanced way and at the same time to enhance the creation of domestic added value. On the contrary, the much-publicised 'all inclusive' packages, especially in Greece, lead to the weakening of small and medium-sized tourism enterprises, marginalise local products, increase unemployment and operate only for the production of super profits for tour operators and large hotel units, and this practice must be stopped immediately.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: Mr. President, we certainly need a change in the regulation of the directive from 25 years ago. We certainly need consumer protection and we certainly need to increase the number of protected travel and all that we really have in this new proposal for a new directive and new regulation. However, the basic question is is is it possible that today after 25 years we are talking about needing to adapt something because we live in a digital time? We've been living for a decade. And I say all this because I am deeply convinced and I have convinced myself in this year and a half that we practically never talk about tourism here in this Parliament. Tourism is 10% of Europe's GDP. I ask Mr. Commissioner to take this fact into account and to start talking more about tourism in the European Parliament, for the Commission to talk more about tourism, as this is the key for many Countries of the European Union, especially in the Mediterranean, the key to the development and future of the economies of these countries.

name: Dubravka ŠUICA
text: – Mr. President, the fact is that the directive needs to be modernised and the fact is that we need to bring it in line with the digital age in which we live. We also know that low-cost companies have been domesticated with the market today and we need to protect the interests of our consumers. We are primarily here for our citizens and therefore it is very important to us to protect their interests.  At the same time, however, I think there needs to be a balance between consumers, i.e. clients, but also travel agencies and hoteliers who also need to be protected.  I want to thank Mrs. Collin-Langen for making good compromises. I believe this directive is going in the right direction. It is good that it has several years to comply with national legislation, but in any case a balance needs to be found between protecting consumers, but also travel agencies and hoteliers.  Since I come from Croatia where tourism is 17% of GDP, it is very important that we put this topic on the agenda and I agree with Mr. Jakovčić that we need to talk more about this topic because it is a big part of the European economy.

name: Doru-Claudian FRUNZULICĂ
text: – Mr President, the travel package proposal represents a positive solution for consumers and businesses. I strongly support more effective rules on insolvency protection for travellers in case of the trader’s insolvency, stricter liability of traders in case of the under—performance of their package, improved pre—contractual information requirements and termination rights, and better protection in cases where the traveller’s return is impossible because of unavoidable and extraordinary circumstances.  I believe that the compromise reached after a difficult negotiation regarding the definitions of linked travel arrangements and travel packages represents a satisfactory result. It is very important that the definition of linked travel arrangements has been widened in order to ensure adequate protection for travellers. Moreover, I welcome the obtainment by Parliament of an appropriate review process, by 2018, of these definitions by the Commission, accompanied if necessary by legislative proposals, in order to verify ‘whether an adjustment or broadening of the definition of travel packages is appropriate’.

name: Pierre MOSCOVICI
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, I agree with all Members who believe that we should speak more about tourism and adapt the supply and demand to the new digital era in which we live now. I am grateful for the support for the new directive which, as far as I understand, has been expressed during this debate. Bearing in mind the divergent expectations and concerns of the different stakeholder groups and the different aspects we had to take into account, I am convinced that we have achieved a more-than-respectable result. Following tomorrow’s vote by the European Parliament, the Commission’s next task will be to ensure the timely and correct transposition of the new directive by the Member States. You may be sure that the Commission will take this duty very seriously and will offer its assistance and support to the Member States.

name: Birgit COLLIN-LANGEN
text: Rapporteur. Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur. First of all, thank you very much for your comments. Let me briefly summarise. Firstly, in view of the changes in the travel market, in particular the trend towards online booking, a recast of the Package Travel Directive is essential. Secondly, the present recast of the directive sets a new and sound basis for the balancing act between the interests of consumers on the one hand and the interests of suppliers on the other. It is balanced and meets the interests of both sides.  I am of course aware of the concerns of the smaller hoteliers, especially from Austria and partly also from Germany, and also of travel agencies in Germany. We have included very, very many suggestions made by the organisations there in the directive, and we have been in regular contact with very, very close contacts, particularly with HOTREC in Austria.  I firmly believe that the remaining problems of transposition into national law must be resolved. But we have managed to open up everywhere that we can work on it.  This directive shows once again the importance that the European Union attaches to consumer protection. Many directives in this area of law have already been transposed into national law. The EU is now taking another target, the importance of which must not be underestimated in practice. Once again– and this is really particularly important to me in the end, I would like to express my sincere thanks to all those who have contributed to the drafting of this directive as shadow rapporteurs, assistants and staff. It was difficult at times, but there was always a friendly, constructive way of working, so I think that is certainly a reason for the result. Tomorrow we will vote on the directive as early second reading. I would like to ask you, ladies and gentlemen, to vote in favour of the directive.

name: Antonio TAJANI
text: The debate is closed. The vote will take place on Tuesday 27 October at 1.00 p.m. Written declarations (Rule 162)

name: Urmas PAET
text: Writing. – Travellers who book a package online must receive the same legal protection as those who make a reservation at a travel agency. Under the added amendments, travellers are entitled to terminate the package holiday contract if their price is increased by more than 8% of the total price of the package before departure. The traveller is also entitled to an explanation of the offer and who is responsible if something goes wrong before the package contract or offer becomes binding on the traveller. The changes are important given that the number of trips purchased online, including package travel, is steadily increasing and people's direct contact with the travel agent is decreasing.

name: Claudia ȚAPARDEL
text: in writing. – The joint economy and the use of online commerce have transformed the way travel is planned and purchased. Despite these trends, European Union legislation, which dates back to 1990, does not reflect the behaviour of today's consumer. Failure to adapt the legislative framework entails the creation of "grey areas", in which many travel packages will no longer fall within the scope of the rules. The proposal for a directive seeks to update the rules on the scope of the protection of passengers. A further attempt shall be made to clarify the definitions of packages of services and the information made available to the consumer at the time of booking and purchase of such services.  As co-chair of the Intergroup for Tourism Development and as a member of the European Parliament's Committee on Transport and Tourism, I can only support the new rules, which will increase transparency in the market and strengthen consumer protection in relation to packages of travel services sold online. We must continue our efforts to maintain the competitiveness of the tourism industry at European level. The adoption and implementation of this directive will bring us one step closer to this objective.

name: Marc TARABELLA
text: In writing. 67% of EU citizens believe they are protected when they buy package trips online; that is not the case. Indeed, the legislation in this area dates back to 1990 and does not take into account this new type of online service, which today accounts for almost one in four trips to Europe. Through this afternoon's vote, we wanted to better protect the 138 million consumers using these combined trips and to avoid, for example, the inconvenience of an unjustifiable price increase, the bankruptcy of their operator, exaggerated hourly changes or unforeseen events. Nearly 200 million European citizens visit an internet travel website every month. It was time to dust off European legislation. We wanted to ensure that holidaymakers who combine their own "packages" holidays from travel services sold online are better protected, as they do not have the same coverage as those who go through traditional travel agencies. This is a step towards better protection of European consumer rights.

name: Janusz ZEMKE
text: I would like to write to the Commission. – I welcome the proposal to adapt tourism services to the realities of the digital age. Customers are increasingly renting hotels, cars or buying airline tickets online. These services should be subject to the same protection as those purchased directly from travel agents. In addition, the rules on withdrawal from the contract should be simplified and which trader is responsible for the performance of all travel services. This would undoubtedly strengthen the rights of travellers in Europe – both those who use several services on the same journey, so-called related services, and those who use single services. It is important that travel providers clearly inform travellers about their rights and which service provider is specifically responsible for the performance of the service. However, The Member States of the European Union must incorporate the new rules into national law, which should happen within two years at the latest.

name: Antonio TAJANI
text: The next item is the report by Marietje Schaake, on behalf of the Committee on International Trade, on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council amending Council Regulation (EC) No 1236/2005 on trade in certain goods which could be used for the death penalty, for torture or other cruel, inhuman or degrading treatment or punishment (COM(2014)0001 - C7-0014/2014 - 2014/0005(COD)) (A8-0267/2015).

name: Marietje SCHAAKE
text: rapporteur. – Mr President, the debate today on the tools and services that can be used for capital punishment reminds us once again that trade policy is an integral part of the EU’s foreign policy. It is vital that we continue to develop values-based trade policies, as is very much the theme of the new trade policy of the Commission. I would like to thank the shadow rapporteurs for the collegial cooperation during which we focussed on updates needed to close the loopholes in the current EU regime. The anti–torture regulation combines prohibitions of goods on the one hand with licensing requirements for trade in listed goods on the other hand. It governs a ban on trade in so–called single-use torture and execution items and related technical assistance under Annex 2. But it also looks at an authorisation system for multi—purpose items that could be misused for torture and executions: for example, lethal injections. We see this in Annex 3. The overhaul of the existing EU controls of trade in torture instruments has been long overdue. In this update we must ensure a correct mix of EU legislative, administrative, judicial and external measures. The absence of a multilateral export controls regime does complicate this task. Still, we seek coherence of the EU’s export controls, including military, dual use, firearms and torture goods lists, without subjecting items to duplicate controls and making things more complicated. The Commission proposes to strengthen the controls of torture goods to include certain medical substances and to broaden the scope to include brokering. I support this kind of approach of necessary and proportionate controls without creating unnecessary burdens for legitimate trade. In this regard it is also key that we seek a more level playing field in Europe. At the same time as we act now, our policies and systems should be future–proof and flexible, so as to be able to adjust to changing technologies or changing realities elsewhere in the world. Specific item lists can provide clarity for exporters and importers to make it easier for them to comply. We have also made sure that it is very clear and that there is no doubt about legitimate access to medicines and pharmaceuticals which, of course, for the EU is an important market, and it must not be hindered by measures to curb the abuse of lethal injection. While we observe that foreign trade transactions are becoming more and more complex, we have to look for an effective set of enforcement measures, and this should also include the marketing and financial services that do take place and are related to this industry.  We have asked for reporting and exchange of information between Member States via a secure encrypted system, so that rejected licences and other notifications or important information can be shared and can help states coordinate.  As the Commission can more flexibly adapt the regulations and the items that are at stake, we do ask, as a Parliament, to be duly informed and involved. Finally, we look to industry to take its own responsibility to make sure that the EU does not trade, broker, transfer or otherwise get involved with goods or services that are used for the death penalty or torture. I believe – and I think all of our colleagues believe – that in this text we put forward concrete proposals for improvement in this file, all with the goal to make sure that the EU acts as a values–based global player and that this specific, quite technical, aspect of trade is upgraded and implemented in a way that is both flexible and effective.

name: Cecilia MALMSTRÖM
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, I want to start by thanking the rapporteur, Mrs Schaake, for the excellent work that she has done on this, of course with input from other colleagues as well. As was said, we will be discussing some very technical elements, but let us not forget that we are talking about highly politically—sensitive issues such as ending the death penalty, torture and ill-treatment, which are key priorities for all the work of the European Union. It is in fact an anomaly that so many countries still have the death penalty and that so many thousands of people are still waiting in death row all over the world, but the fact is that it has actually decreased. One hundred and forty countries do not apply the death penalty today and 98 have legally abolished it, compared to 59 twenty years ago, so this is going in the right direction, but that does not mean that we should rest – there is so much to do. We have different tools at our disposal in foreign policy, but trade also can play a very important role and that is why this report is so important. Trade can be a leverage to promote, around the world, European values such as human rights, sustainable development, fair and ethical trade and the fight against corruption, and those values are the pillars of the newly proposed trade strategy by the Commission. The regulation we are talking about, Regulation (EC) No 1236/2005, takes account of this – the role of trade – to restrict foreign trade in goods that could be used for executions, torture or ill-treatment, and we welcome very much the effort done by the European Parliament to amend the regulation. We largely share the spirit and the approach taken by the Committee on International Trade (INTA), the rapporteur and Parliament, although some of the amendments in the report call for measures without precedent in export-control legislation and could be a bit difficult to implement in practice. We support several amendments, such as Amendment 6 extending the proposed definition of ‘broker’ to cover nationals from Member States not resident or established in the Union. This is acceptable in principle, but it could be difficult to enforce, so the inclusion of foreign subsidiaries of legal persons incorporated in the EU should of course not go beyond what is compatible with international law. Amendments 9 and 10 on the transport of transiting goods whose export and import is prohibited by the regulation are also acceptable for the Commission if Amendment 10 does not cover more than non-union goods. It is related to Amendment 15, and that can also be accepted; we just have to make sure that it is formulated in compatibility with WTO requirements. Amendment 21 referring to the transmission of information to human rights oversight bodies is also acceptable. Of course, here, companies requesting an export authorisation that submit information to competent authority have a legitimate interest in not giving certain data and making them public, so we need to make sure how the text is drafted here. Furthermore, we can accept Amendments 18 on best practices for technical assistance, 19 on guidelines and 26 on the report published by the Commission on the implementation, if you can agree that this is not an obligation for the Commission. We can also accept Amendment 2 adding human dignity and then several other more technical amendments that I will not go into now. I mentioned that some of the proposed measures are without precedent in export-control legislation. Last spring, Members approved here in Parliament Regulation 479 on common rules for exports, which confirmed the basic rule of trade policy: that exports are to be free unless trade restrictions are necessary to achieve an accepted objective, such as the protection of public morals. Torture, ill treatment and the death penalty are, of course, never acceptable, but we just make need to make sure that trade restrictions to promote respect for human rights meet the necessary trust. In this regard, while we fully understand the rationale of a view to propose an end-use or catch-all clause, we think it could lead to the introduction of restrictions going beyond what is necessary and preventing a level playing field for exporters. This could present a challenge to the uniformity of the Union’s trade policy, and for this reason the Commission had instead proposed the urgency procedure, which would help us to deal with most of the cases that could be addressed in a more proportionate manner. But we are willing to see if those objectives, which are basically the same, can be reconciled in a formula that we can agree upon. Regarding the amendment on the definition of brokering services, number 5, it would make the regulation cover a range of activities, financial services and insurance related to goods that are outside the Union, and that would be very difficult to monitor and control. But rather than amending the definition, we could identify which restrictions on which services need the necessity test and then use of specific drafting to regulate those activities. We recognise the usefulness of the Coordination Group and we share the objective behind that amendment. We just need to be very careful to make sure that that article is not at odds with the agreed arrangement for delegated powers in the treaty. We would need to find an appropriate formula to create a forum for consultations between Member States, stakeholders, civil society and the Commission. As you know, the EU works towards the abolition of the death penalty in all countries. The countries that are included in the proposal, in the authorisation of the annex, have ratified the second optional protocol to the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights without reservation, so they agreed to abolish the death penalty. When controlling exports to prevent EU involvement in executions in third countries, we should focus our efforts on countries that have not abolished it, and therefore we disagree with Amendments 33, 35 and 37 because there is nothing to show that these countries concerned would have applied the death penalty, despite the ratification of the protocol. Let me conclude – it has become rather technical – by expressing my conviction that this report, by the rapporteur and many of you, is a very good basis for further work to make the regulation into a more robust export—control regime that promotes respect for fundamental rights without unduly restricting foreign rights. I express here the full commitment by the Commission and me, personally, to work with you and with the Council to achieve that objective and a good final product.

name: Barbara LOCHBIHLER
text: Rapporteur for the opinion of the Committee on Foreign Affairs. Mr President, Commissioner Malmström, I would like to thank commissioner for her excellent work and for the work she has done. Exports of torture tools, medical-chemical products for so-called poison cocktails for executions – many citizens in the EU cannot even imagine that such goods are exported from the EU today. Unfortunately, however, the Council regulation regulating these horrible exports still has gaps, and that is precisely what we want to close. I therefore call on the Commission to take up the European Parliament's proposals, in particular to ban the promotion and promotion of these goods at trade fairs and on the Internet, not to allow further training for the use of goods intended to carry out the death penalty and torture. Above all, however, we need a clause on the intended end-use clause, the so-called targeted end-use clause. This would allow Member States to stop the transfer of torture tools that are not explicitly listed. This would close loopholes, including for products that will be developed in the future for torture and executions.

name: Santiago FISAS AYXELÀ
text: PPE Group. – Mr President, Commissioner, the European Union, through this Regulation, reaffirms its policy of eliminating the death penalty in the world, as required by Article 2 of the Charter of Fundamental Rights of the European Union. The abolition of the death penalty and inhuman and degrading treatment is part of the high priorities of the Union's human rights policy, and the European Union is the first institutional player in the fight against the death penalty. Since the European People's Party, we are flatly against the death penalty and any kind of torture and do not want to be complicit in these practices. That is why we defend the importance of controlling exports of products that can serve to impose capital punishment or to torture. And this Regulation is an instrument that ensures respect for and protection of human dignity, the right to life and the prohibition of torture. In addition, it allows, in turn, under strict surveillance, that these products can be used for a legitimate purpose, such as for medical purposes. Therefore, tomorrow, from our group, we will vote in favour of this report, because it seems to us to be a balanced proposal which contributes to the protection of human rights and makes the European Union a pioneer in the regulation of trade in such products.

name: Inma RODRÍGUEZ-PIÑERO
text: on behalf of the S&D Group – Mr President, the European Union is committed to eradicating the death penalty and torture in the world, but this commitment would be of no use if it were not accompanied by strong and rigorous actions, such as the one we are discussing in plenary today. The European Union already took a big step in 2005, when it adopted the first Regulation; but unfortunately, it was quickly obsolete in the face of market dynamism and the sophistication of companies' ability to manufacture and design instruments to inflict the death penalty and torture. That is why, in 2010, the Council, then chaired by the Socialist Government of José Luis Rodríguez Zapatero, urged the Commission to carry out a reform of the Regulation. Five years later we can be here today debating; a long time has passed. But fortunately, we are already here, we have the regulation we are asking for, and the truth is that I believe that it has been improved in the Committee on International Trade, thanks to the amendments of the groups and, of course, to the excellent work and consensus effort of the rapporteur, whom I congratulate from here. We are satisfied with this proposal because it extends controls to lawful products that could be handled at destination; because it also expands the list of products that can be used to inflict the death penalty; and, of course, because it introduces more agile and effective mechanisms to review the list of controlled and prohibited products. We believe that with this proposal no national, any European company, nor its subsidiaries abroad, will be able to profit from this trade. As I said at the beginning, and as the Commissioner and all those who preceded me pointed out very well, Europe needs to show that it is committed to human rights, that it will not allow trade to be a profit instrument for inflicting the death penalty and torture, and, of course, that trade policy is a fundamental instrument for aiding the defence of human rights. And finally, Mr President, I would like from here to congratulate and thank all non-governmental human rights organizations for their invaluable work and collaboration.

name: Sander LOONES
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. I condemn the death penalty. I condemn torture. I am therefore very pleased that today we are taking a serious step forward in the monitoring of products that can be used for these purposes. I am also pleased that we are doing so in a sensible, clear, flexible and proportionate way. For example, by working with a number of specific lists of goods that can be quickly adjusted, we provide clarity to in- and exporters and ensure flexibility on the ground. And by, for example, regulating medicines specifically and not in a general safety net provision, I believe that we can also ensure the lawful use of those medicines. That is a good thing. Correct checks without unnecessary burdens, that is what this text says. In so doing, we are ensuring a proportionate model, and I believe that we are once again taking an ambitious and at the same time realistic step forward in promoting our values.

name: Lola SÁNCHEZ CALDENTEY
text: GUE/NGL Group. – Mr President, it is common sense that we do not allow our companies to trade with third countries with materials which we have banned in Europe because they are related to inhumane practices or torture. We can't sell to others what we ourselves have outdified. In this respect, we think that the Regulation is positive and that it is on the right track. However, the European Commission needs to establish an effective surveillance system to ensure that all Member States comply with this Regulation. And we must also ensure that these goods are banned through the European Union. However, I think we need to be more ambitious. We are making in-efficient use, for example, of our official development aid, which builds schools and hospitals in Palestine, if, at the same time, we are selling weapons to Israel with which they will destroy those same schools and hospitals. We must also review our economic partnership agreements with States that systematically violate human rights and therefore veto military weaponry, arms sales.

name: Ska KELLER
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. – Mr President, I would like to thank the rapporteur from the Committee on International Trade (INTA) as well as from the Committee on Human Rights (DROI), who I think have been doing really tremendous work because, in this file, we can see that trade policy can actually do something good; that it can contribute to the coherence that we need to have with respect to our values in the world. Torture, indeed, is a main human rights violation, and we need to do everything we can inside the European Union to stop torture and also executions from happening elsewhere – and goods being produced here can be used elsewhere for those purposes. With this update of the laws, I think we have taken a very good step, and this is mainly due to the work of the European Parliament, which has been very insistent. But I also think that we could have done even better, because we should still forbid advertising for those goods outside the European Union – that must be the next step. What is very good is to have the catch-all clause to have the possibility to prevent new goods going out and being used for torture or execution. I think now we, as Parliament, have set the right pace, and I ask the Council and the Commission to be constructive partners in the trilogue to achieve better legislation that is coherent with our values.

name: Tiziana BEGHIN
text: Mr President, president, ladies and gentlemen, i.e. the european Union, the European Union and its Member States are Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I too welcome this legislative report. I would like to thank the rapporteur. This is the latest version of one of the greatest successes of THE EU's trade policy, a regulation that prohibits the sale of instruments to torture or impose the death penalty. The previous law needed to be modernised to meet the challenges of new materials, new technologies, and to fill the gaps left by the dual-use goods regulation. When the new regulation is in force, there will be tighter controls, because in 2015 it is not possible to tolerate torture tools being on sale online or in trade fair halls in Europe. The regulation was widely supported in committee, and for this reason, in addition to the rapporteur, I would also like to thank my fellow shadow rapporteurs. The Five Star Movement is at the forefront of the fight against respect for rights and life in the world, and for this reason, ladies and gentlemen, we will support this report unreservedly.

name: Georgios EPITIDEIOS
text: NI). Mr President, with our vote we must prevent trade in certain items which may be used for killing, torturing, severe and cruel and inhuman punishment. The issue is neither legal, nor economic, nor commercial, nor formal and procedural; it is primarily a moral issue. The death penalty and torture violate human rights, offend the individual's personality and lead humanity centuries if not thousands of years back. In particular, torture, in addition to the above, is a sign of the repulsive of the subconscious, is satisfying animal instincts and is also a sign of cowardice, and directly offends the principles, customs and customs of the civilized peoples of Europe. We cannot say that we are Christians, that we are humanists, that we are democrats and that we tolerate all these things happening.  Each state individually, and the European Union as a whole, must control trade in these objects and not allow human dignity to be trampled on for economic and commercial purposes.

name: Jarosław WAŁĘSA
text: – Mr President, I would like to congratulate the rapporteur for her report. I welcome this proposal as important and much needed because it is essential to control the export of goods which are used for the death penalty and torture. In order to prevent such degrading treatment from happening, it is important to use all available tools that are specifically designed to act as anti—torture solutions. However, we must not forget to find a proper balance between the genuine interests of companies and the potential use of certain goods for capital punishment. Moreover, we need to come up with a thorough monitoring mechanism in order to prevent the abuse of restrictions imposed on exporters of medical products. That being said, I can fully support the report voted in the INTA Committee.

name: Alessia Maria MOSCA
text: – Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the legislative action that the Commission has proposed to improve the existing regulation on usable goods in order to inflict torture and corporal punishment until the death penalty is a step forward, which Parliament can only welcome, and we have worked constructively for further progress precisely for this reason. The new trade strategy, which the Commission presented a few days ago, insists precisely on the need to link the economic and value aspects of our relationship with our trading partners, both in bilateral and multilateral negotiations. And this initiative is a concrete example of this. Clearly, this is only a small step, if we look at the overall design, but we are convinced that even through small steps it is possible to be the architects and protagonists of great changes.  Specifically, we are in favour of the inclusion of an annex specifying more specifically which goods should be subject to control and possible bans, and we welcome the establishment of a general AUTHORISATION at EU level for exports to those countries that have not at present proved to be irreproachable in this area. We also take this opportunity to strongly support the Commission in the will expressed by the Commissioner, for which we thank her, not to stop at this regulation, but on the contrary to continue in all the necessary forums in the work of conviction necessary to prevent them from being accepted in too many countries of the world even before corporal punishment and torture are carried out.

name: Pedro SILVA PEREIRA
text: – Mr President, the fight against torture and the death penalty is a decisive battle of the European Union and humanist culture, and must be fought on all fronts, and also mobilising the European Union's trade policy. It is our duty not only to ensure an effective ban on the marketing of products intended for torture and execution, but also to control so-called dual-use products that are susceptible to misuse, whether for torture or executions.  This proposal for a regulation is a positive initiative that deserves the clear and constructive political support of the European Parliament. Updating the lists of products subject to special authorisation, creating a general export authorisation for countries that comply with international commitments, but also creating a general clause which makes the authorisation of the lack of reasonable grounds to suspect misuse of these goods, would be important steps and a good opportunity for a trade policy more faithful to the European human rights commitment.

name: José Inácio FARIA
text: – Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, the European Union has pioneered the introduction of rules aimed at preventing and eradicating forms of torture and ill-treatment, as well as abolishing the death penalty worldwide. In this regard, I am pleased that Portugal was the second European nation to abolish capital punishment in 1867. The European Union is now strengthening the legal framework it already has, expanding and updating the list of prohibited products and technologies, to prevent our companies from promoting, interspersing and providing technical training in the use of devices and technologies for acts of torture, executions or cruel, inhuman or degrading treatment and punishment. I hope that this effort will effectively contribute to the abolition of the death penalty in the countries that still apply it, as well as to the reduction of torture practices around the world, in particular with regard to the violation of human rights and freedom of expression.  And because this is a citizenship forum par excellence, I end by urging the Government of Angola to immediately and unconditionally release Luaty Beirão and the other human rights activists who are illegally detained in Angola. Freedom, now!

name: Doru-Claudian FRUNZULICĂ
text: – Mr President, I fully support the revision of this regulation, which aims to contribute to the elimination of the death penalty worldwide and prevent torture through EU—wide controls on the export of torture goods and drugs used for lethal injections. The revision includes adding export licensing controls for lethal drugs and prohibiting trade in new items which have become regularly used for torture by certain regimes, for example spiked buttons, electric shock sleeves and cuffs. The so—called catch-all clause will make it binding for customs authorities to seize any goods, whether or not they are listed in the regulation annexes, if there are reasonable grounds to believe that their final use will be for the purpose of torture. Finally, I welcome the establishment of a Union general export authorisation for countries that have undertaken international commitments and the use of the urgency procedure to amend the list of banned controlled items, which will allow the EU to react more quickly to emerging threats and human rights crackdowns in the future.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: ECR). Mr President, the death penalty, torture, cruel inhuman and degrading treatment and punishment are prohibited by international and European treaties. In this context, the European Regulation against Torture is an effective instrument for the protection of human rights, as it imposes effective controls on species and activities used for the execution of the death penalty or for torture. But there is a need for an immediate reorganisation of the European Union's controls on the trade in torture instruments, and this has been delayed by many. Thus, advertising and sales of these products on the internet should be prohibited. In particular, control of exports of dual-use items included in the lists of military equipment which may also be used for torture should be intensified. At the same time, the bilingualism of the European Union, which is attempting by the regulation to be adopted to legalise the export of medicinal products of which the European Union is a key manufacturer, must also be stopped, even though they may be used for torture or the execution of the death penalty .

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Europe must reaffirm its leading role in the fight for the abolition of the death penalty and for a moratorium on executions throughout the world. But it is also necessary for the Member States not to be involved in the trade in goods that could be used for the death penalty, for torture and for practices that violate human rights, such as cruel, inhuman and degrading punishments.  We must preserve the absolute ban on torture and ill-treatment provided for in the Charter of Fundamental Rights. We must do this in order not to be complicit in those who still apply these odious punishments. That is why it is necessary to ban in the most decisive way all exports or imports of goods that can be used to impose cruel penalties and to increase monitoring of export authorisations for goods that could be used for this purpose.  Europe is an area free of the death penalty, but it must also be an area free from torture and odious, inhuman and degrading practices, and the Member States must in no way be complicit, even indirectly, in those who still impose inhumane punishments in the world.

name: Cecilia MALMSTRÖM
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, it is good to see that there is such strong unity on these important issues. It sends a strong signal to the rest of the world, and shows that we are determined to use all possible tools that we have at our disposal – today we are talking about trade – to abolish the death penalty along with torture and ill—treatment.  Let me thank again the rapporteur and all the shadow rapporteurs and the Committee on Foreign Affairs, which has been involved as well, and reiterate the Commission’s determination to have an ambitious regulation in place to restrict foreign trade in goods that could be used for executions or ill—treatment or torture.  We will, as many of you said, make sure with this amendment that we close the loopholes and also, in response to some of your questions on the catch-all clause, we have an open position so let us see how we can find a solution to this. On the implementation and monitoring, I think that the coordination group – or whatever we call it in the end – can have a very important role there. Also, the Commission has, via delegated acts, the powers to regularly modify the Annex to make sure that it is kept up to date. We will also present next year a review of the export control system for dual use – many of you have referred to this, this evening, as well – in order to make sure that we have an even better regulation on items that can be misused in violation of human rights, which would be another very important milestone.  I am sure that with such a strong agreement to really have a good regulation updated here, we can find a way to overcome the remaining difficulties and find a way to amend them in the right way so that we have a workable and efficient system that is proven for the future and equipped to ensure rapid reaction when a risk arises. This Commission will certainly play its part in this.

name: Marietje SCHAAKE
text: rapporteur. – Mr President, I would like to thank the Commissioner and my colleagues.
