On a slightly lighter note, I thought it was a pleasure – and a bit of a relief – to hear that we can actually talk about trade and agree from one side of the House to the other side of the House, and even see that trade policies can advance values directly, so I note that with a smile.  Commissioner, thank you for your very detailed reply to the text that we have worked on together in this House. I note many points of overlap – if not literally, then at least in spirit – and that is a reason for optimism. I think that it has been well established by everyone who spoke that we share the goal of ending the death penalty and torture, and this is one way to contribute to that. It is not as widely shared a goal in this House. Unfortunately, it is not entirely unanimously shared, but at least by a large majority.  On the implementation: yes, of course measures must be feasible and even agile. That is our goal too, but I think we are being both ambitious and realistic, as my colleague Loones also said. It has been 10 years since this regulation has been updated, so we feel very strongly that what we do now has to be future—proof and solid and should be able to last for quite a while, so what we do now we must do well and make it a robust mechanism that deals with all the loose ends.  I also want to end by saying thank you to civil society and human rights organisations that have been very involved in helping us to push for these much—needed reforms. I think this highlights the importance of civil society also for us here in the European Parliament.

name: Antonio TAJANI
text: The debate is closed. The vote will take place on Tuesday 27 October at 1.00 p.m. Written declarations (Rule 162)

name: David MARTIN
text: in writing. – I welcome the strengthening of this legislation designed to ensure the EU is not complicit in torture, and to fulfil the EU’s commitment to standing against the death penalty and torture throughout the world. Updates to this legislation will ensure EU companies do not profit from torture in oppressive regimes, and send a strong signal that those who trade in execution and torture goods, including technical assistance and supplier services, that they cannot access the EU market. In particular I welcome new measures to improve the speed and efficiency of reacting to suspected transactions. I strongly stand behind the EU ban on trading drugs intended for the death penalty, which Labour MEPs and the European Union stand firmly against.

name: Antonio TAJANI
text: The next item is the report by György Schöpflin, on behalf of the Committee on Constitutional Affairs, on the European Citizens' Initiative (2014/2257(INI)) (A8-0284/2015).

name: György SCHÖPFLIN
text: rapporteur. – Mr President, I would like to begin by thanking the shadow rapporteurs with whom I worked together on this report on the European Citizens’ Initiative (ECI). Cooperation was exemplary and, a pleasant surprise for me, the vote in the Committee on Constitutional Affairs (AFCO) was unanimous. I hardly have to note how rare this unanimity is and that is in itself a message, an indication that the ECI is properly regarded as a key instrument in the framework of the institutional structure of the European Union. Now the underlying idea is both straightforward and subtle. The citizens of Europe should have the means to launch legislative initiatives on issues of concern at the European level. Everyone is aware of the reality of the remoteness between the EU and its citizens, and the ECI is one way of bridging it. Let me add here immediately that the right of legislative initiative by citizens does not undermine the representative democracy that is the core value of any democratic system – ourselves in other words. No, the ECI enhances European democracy by introducing a form of civic action that communicates in parallel with what we are doing.  Nor is the ECI a form of direct democracy where citizens foregather to take legislative action. That may have worked in the classical Greek city states but is nonsense when 500 million citizens are involved. What the ECI can do is to adopt a single issue and mobilise a sufficient number of individuals in a form of collective action. The mobilisatory element should not be underestimated. The process of collecting a million signatures in a year demands organisational skills, enthusiasm and commitment to doing something political in Europe. From that perspective the ECI is a way of bringing citizens into the European political field in an unmediated fashion.  Ultimately there will always be some tension between the politics of representation and political involvement from below. The idea that a given number of citizens can act together on a single issue of concern adds something new to the political palette of Europe and, let it be noted, is already available as a form of political action in some EU Member States. What differentiates the European political field from that of a Member State is that legislation is initiated by the Commission. The ECI changes this by adding the citizens to those with the right of launching legislation. This shift therefore changes the equation in European politics by adding a new actor. So much for the underlying theory behind the ECI; practice to date has not really fulfilled the promise of the instrument. Over 50 initiatives have been organised and none, not one, has reached the statute book. By anyone’s failure criteria this is 100%. Indeed, in my consultations with civil society I have detected a clear sense of disappointment with the way in which the Commission has handled the ECIs that it has received. There have been complaints of bureaucratic dilatoriness – the ‘insolence of office’, the ‘law’s delay’, to quote Shakespeare – and a general sense that while the Commission has dealt with the instrument with complete correctness legally, it has rather missed the political point, that of civic involvement. So the burden of my report is intended to address these shortcomings and to urge the Commission to respond to the voice of the citizens with greater flexibility than hitherto. I have every hope that the promised reform of the ECI will make it a genuinely effective instrument. (Applause)

name: Frans TIMMERMANS
text: First Vice-President of the Commission. – I very much welcome today’s discussion on the European Citizens’ Initiative (ECI) and I welcome György Schöpflin’s report, which I think is an excellent contribution. This is a good basis for me to discuss something that already came up during my hearing and that is something we really want to build on.  We, the Juncker Commission, have said that we would act on big things and concentrate our efforts there. That is what we do, but we also need to change how we do it. In that context, I believe the ECI can be a valuable contribution. It is a tool with which citizens can directly try to influence policy. It allows citizens to influence the agenda at European level and to bring to the fore the concrete issues which most concern them. It is therefore a tool to initiate political dialogue. As a member of the European Convention, when I represented the Dutch Parliament, I was myself involved in the design of the Citizens’ Initiative. Today, it is part of my responsibilities to ensure that it works properly and thus works better.  It is still a young tool, but we already have some experience. Last March the Commission reported on the Initiative’s first three years. It has started to show its potential. Some 33 initiatives were registered, and collected signatures. Three successfully gathered over one million signatures each. Overall, about 6 million citizens gave their signatures – impressive numbers of people. All these efforts have succeeded in forging links among like—minded people across the continent. They helped spark genuine pan—European debates and brought new ideas into the European public space. This is promising for European participatory democracy and the emergence of a European demos. But, at the same time, we need to work to make the Citizens’ Initiative more user—friendly. I note that several points put forward in your report, Mr Schöpflin, converge with our report’s conclusions. We are already implementing a number of these measures. Let me just mention a few.  The Commission has established a dedicated point of contact, which has already replied to around 1 200 questions in all EU languages on rules and procedures. We are also providing more specific support directly to organisers once their ECI has been registered, including on legal requirements and logistical or technical aspects. Going beyond our obligations on the regulation, we also provide ad hoc online hosting on Commission servers free of charge. Data requirements have sometimes been flagged as an issue. Here we will continue our efforts to encourage Member States to simplify their data requirements so that all citizens can actually exercise the right to sign an ECI, should they wish to do so. We should also be open to do more if that is needed. I am therefore here today to listen very carefully to Members’ assessment of how the instrument is working and discuss their ideas on how to improve it. The Commission takes very seriously indeed Parliament’s call for a legislative revision of the ECI Regulation. We are currently in the process of assessing the need, scope and objective for such a revision. We are collecting factual evidence and are listening widely to stakeholders. The Commission would like to thank Parliament for its constructive approach towards improving this important tool. I would like to personally thank and congratulate Mr Schöpflin for a job very well done in analysing the implementation of the ECI, reflecting on possible improvements and building consensus across political groups and committees. He is not trying to make party political work with us; he is trying to help citizens reconnect – or, sometimes, connect for the first time – with our European level of political dialogue. I think the Commission should be prepared to do whatever is needed to make that easier, more accessible and more successful.

name: Sylvia-Yvonne KAUFMANN
text: Rapporteur for the opinion of the Committee on Legal Affairs. Mr President, Mr Vice-President of the Commission, I would like to thank the Commissioner for his work and for his work We absolutely want and need more citizen participation in the European project of unification. It is therefore essential to draw conclusions from three years of the citizens' initiative. In order for the citizens' initiative to have the effect we want, more than beauty corrections are needed. What is really needed is a major overhaul of the ECI Regulation. The organisers of citizens' initiatives need comprehensive support, including legal advice from appropriate contact points in the Member States. After registering their ECI, they must be able to decide for themselves when to start the campaign. The signature of a citizens' initiative should no longer be linked to the delivery of a personal identification number in any country. And, Mr Vice-President of the Commission, we need a clear signal to young people. They should be allowed to support a citizens' initiative anywhere in the EU at the age of sixteen.  The report before Parliament is very good, and I hope that the Commission will indeed take up our proposals quickly, because, Mr Timmermans, the citizens' initiative must now get out of its infancy, it must become a truly citizen-friendly instrument.

name: Beatriz BECERRA BASTERRECHEA
text: drafts member of the Committee on Petitions. – Mr President, Mr Vice-President, the European citizens' initiative — the first instrument of transnational participatory democracy — was created to enable European citizens to engage directly with the institutions and influence the governance of the Union with their proposals. Three years after it's launched, what the data tells us is that it hasn't worked the way it should. And, since what is not working must be fixed, we call on the Commission to review it immediately. The tools should serve the purpose for which they were conceived. Users must have all the facilities and support to use them. We need to harmonize the different national requirements and simplify the required documentation, including by creating a common identification system. And we must certainly establish a one-stop shop by taking advantage of the headquarters and staff of the European institutions already in each Member State. But, moreover, from my group, ALDE, we believe that the European citizens' initiative should serve to change aspects of primary law. A full review is needed as soon as possible and the problems are addressed, because by improving the European citizen initiative we will improve democracy.

name: Pál CSÁKY
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. – I believe that this report is a major milestone in the subject of the citizens' initiative, and it has not been addressed by three commissions for nothing. It can also be felt that Parliament's view on this issue is different from that of the Commission. We may appreciate the citizens' initiative more positively, but we are clearly more critical of the application so far. However, I am also pleased that the positions have come close in the debates of recent months. As Vice-Chairman of the Committee on Petitions, I also appreciate and appreciate this. In the work that awaits us, we must ensure that the institutional balance is ensured in the decision-making processes for initiatives. I also trust that, in cases before the Court of Justice of the European Union, the court will answer the dilemma between us and the Commission as to whether the European Commission has applied the rules on the admissibility of initiatives too rigidly. And finally, Mr President Timmermans, I would like to ask the Commission for generosity. It would be good if we could report on other successful citizens' initiatives in the near future.

name: Mercedes BRESSO
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, first of all, I too would like to thank the rapporteur, Mr Schöpflin, for his excellent work, so much so that the report was adopted unanimously, and our shadow rapporteur Sylvia Kaufmann, for the commitment she has put in on this issue for a long time.  Mr Timmermans, we have noted with great pleasure the commitment you have made on behalf of the Commission. However, there is no doubt that these first three years have shown many difficulties in the practical functioning of the initiative. In particular, I would like to point out that the procedure needs to be made clearer: not the registration procedure, but how, in practice, groups of citizens assess the possibility of obtaining registration by presenting an initiative that is consistent with the Treaties. Secondly, we need to facilitate collection, and here we have proposed a whole series of points which, if accepted, can make it easier to collect and thus facilitate citizens' initiatives: age, methods of filing, the separate times between registration and the start of collection, online signatures... are many things. But then there is a fundamental point, and that is that of the Commission's proposal. That is what we expect the Commission to do more: a proposal. If there is registration and there are signatures, there must be a proposal from the European institutions.

name: Kazimierz Michał UJAZDOWSKI
text: On behalf of the ECR Group. – Thank you, Mr President. We thank Mr Schöpflin , not only for building consensus, but above all because he immediately presented a draft report aimed at reviving the institutions. We have immediately observed in the first phase that the proposals put forward by the rapporteur have served to remove bureaucratic constraints, all that serve the good implementation of the institutions, and the report also includes those solutions that concern the most sensitive points.  And you have to talk about them. This is, above all, a question for the European Commission: will it be ready to reduce its own arbitrariness, to limit its arbitrariness, because that is the essence of things? What has happened to the One of Us initiative – supported by huge crowds of citizens and rejected by the European Commission – should not happen in the future. I believe that any initiative supported by the required number of signatures should be the subject of real legislative work. And a big question for the European Commission: will this call in the report be answered in the form of a new proposal amending the Regulation on the European initiative, because it will be a real test? The report is very good – thank you again to the rapporteur – but now it is up to the Commission to decide. It is up to the Commission to continue. I also call for this political law to be real, not fictional. Thank you very much.

name: Charles GOERENS
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. Mr President, the European Citizens' Initiative is one of the most innovative ways of the Lisbon Treaty to enhance the democratic legitimacy of the European Union. Indeed, who would not welcome the greater involvement of the citizen in European affairs? However, we consider it appropriate, after a period of four years, to evaluate its operation, without questioning the very principle of the European initiative. Indeed, many initiatives have faced various obstacles to the point of having to abandon their project for good.  Our colleague, Mr Sch-pflin, has given a good account of the work of the Committee on Constitutional Affairs, and I would like to congratulate him on that. The Committee on Constitutional Affairs was almost unanimous in its desire to make improvements to the functioning of the citizens' initiative. We support proposals to ease procedures. In the same vein, it would be wise for us to see the Commission register only the part of an initiative within its scope and to pass on the remaining parties or parties to the competent, national or regional authorities. If we share the essence of the views expressed by the rapporteur, we would like to make it clear, however, as an ALDE group, that the Commission should also accept initiatives that concern the primary law of the European Union. From this point of view, it is obvious that the functioning of the European Union is often paralyzed by the limits imposed on it by the Treaty. The Commission, having the right to initiate a treaty change, could thus become the custodian of proposals from European citizens. To that end, we have tabled, together with the Green Group, an amendment to extend the citizens' initiative to treaty issues.

name: Barbara SPINELLI
text: Mr President, president, ladies and gentlemen, i.e. the european Union, we must not Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the Eu ropean Union has discovered participatory democracy after a crisis: Ireland's 'no' to the Treaty of Nice. The citizens' initiative, now in the Treaties, was a response to that crisis. Today the crisis has worsened and participatory democracy is moribund. No initiative that gathered sufficient signatures was followed by legal action.  The Schöpflin report is not perfect, unfortunately it does not allow the Treaties to be amended, but it has received unanimity in the AFCO Committee because it greatly facilitates the legal follow-up of initiatives. I solemnly ask this Parliament not to vote for Amendment No 4 to paragraph 30, which would turn ice into a bow without arrows. I am asking the Socialists in particular who have tabled it. The amendment requires the Commission to propose a legislative act in favour of a successful ECI, but only after a positive opinion has been delivered. To date, 29 out of 49 initiatives have been admitted, 3 have been signed, only the right to water has received a vague positive opinion, none have been followed up.  Commissioner Malmström responded to petitions against TTIP by saying: 'I do not receive my mandate from the People of Europe'. I would also like to hear from you, Mr Timmermans, who the Commission has now been mandated to do.

name: Josep-Maria TERRICABRAS
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. – Mr President, the Greens/EFA Group has taken part with interest, even with enthusiasm, in the reform of the European Citizens’ Initiative (ECI) since we believe that this is an important tool of correction between European Union citizens and their institutions, which much too often are considered distant and arrogant. The final result of the report, shared by my colleague and friend György Schöpflin, is in general terms good. It includes elements of renovation. No wonder that it was unanimously approved in our meeting of the Committee on Constitutional Affairs (AFCO).  In spite of this positive view, I have to mention a point which should have deserved more courage from all of us. I am referring to the necessary amelioration of the follow–up to any successful ECI after its submission. This would be a clear signal of our readiness to reinforce also the European initiatives. This follow–up demands that steps forward be taken, preparing corresponding legal acts in agreement, of course, with the principles and rules of the Commission and Parliament. There are some amendments which have been presented and which do not, in my opinion, express with enough clarity the goal we would all like to achieve. If I am completely honest, I have to say that those amendments run to some extent in the opposite direction to what is demanded and has to be achieved. That is why our Group has presented its own amendments with the intention of giving the Commission and this House the opportunity to play a major and positive role in the undertaking of those who, moved by democratic impulses, try to construct a better, friendlier, closer Europe. I still hope that our amendments can win the approval of a majority of our colleagues.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: Mr President, president, ladies and gentlemen, i.e. the european Union, the European Union and its Member States are – Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, ICE: a word, many expectations – so many expectations for the main instrument of direct democracy introduced by the Treaty of Lisbon, a fundamental pillar for the 5-star Movement.  Colleagues have mentioned the number of initiatives taken, of which only three have been declared admissible. This is due to bureaucratic difficulties and delays, lack of information, lack of uniformity between Member States, including for the data collected, the correct identification of the legal basis.  Well, this report gives important answers from a logistical point of view, and I congratulate the rapporteur, György Schöpflin, but we must take more important steps, political steps. And the political steps are to resolve the conflict of interests of the Commission, which finds itself on the one hand the person who has the legal eligibility check and on the other the same person who decides whether or not to follow up an ICE, once it has completed its journey.  Following up cannot be an optional option, it must be an obligation if we are to give credibility to the institutions and bring them closer to the citizens. Their efforts, their thirst for democracy, cannot be frustrated. In addition, this will must be saved by also allowing it to revise the Treaties through the ECI. Get out of the EU's immobility in order to give new impetus and impetus: the people can do so, the citizens can do so, in order to revive the dream of the founding fathers – other than the words of Commissioner Malmström!

name: Gerolf ANNEMANS
text: on behalf of the ENF Group. Even if the European Citizens' Initiative were to function perfectly, it cannot be expected to solve the democratic deficit that is so characteristic of the European Union. I support the principle and spirit of this initiative, not because of the so-called European idea of integration, but because it is a means of drawing the attention of the European Commission and the European elected representatives to certain issues and social problems, large or small. The more than meritorious Schöpflin report notes that the success of the European Citizens' Initiative is waning. The finger is placed on the wound. Many initiatives are lost and the few initiatives that survive the complexity of the procedure are not followed up on the legislative front. That is why our group advocates not only the removal of practical obstacles and the user-friendly use of the instrument of initiative, but also an obligation for the Commission to follow an appropriate proposal on a successful European citizens' initiative. In this sense, we are submits our amendments.

name: Zoltán BALCZÓ
text: – The European Citizens' Initiative would be the instrument to ensure that citizens can participate directly in EU decision-making. However, this tool is very weak. With one million signatures, it is possible for the Commission to submit a proposal on this issue. 3 out of 51 initiatives have succeeded and none are legis acted on. The reporter is trying to improve this system. However, this is not enough today. The migrant crisis has demonstrated how far away the Union's political elite is from the opinion of its own population, respect for the exception. A large number of opinion polls show how differently the public sees this important issue than the decision-making political elite. It would therefore be necessary to introduce the institution of the EU referendum. That would mean real, direct democracy. (The speaker agrees to answer a blue card question under Article 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure).

name: David COBURN
text: blue-card question. – I would just like to ask a simple question to see if you agree with me. Do you agree that, if people in this House can make no dent in terms of having an initiative or things pushed through this Parliament, how in the name of goodness are ordinary citizens able to do this? This is just a waste of time. Would you agree with me, Sir?

name: Zoltán BALCZÓ
text: Blue card answer. "The question is, if we cannot transfer something here, is it a waste of time to give direct decision-making to the population? It is not a waste of time if we create a clear and decision-making framework that is not like the citizens' initiative we are discussing. Just as there may be a referendum in your country that makes a concrete decision, it is the means to do so in the European Union.

name: Dubravka ŠUICA
text: – Mr. President, the Lisbon Treaty has enabled the European Citizens' Initiative and I believe that contrary to Mr. Coburn, I think it is a very good initiative that allows citizens to engage directly.  Of course, we know that there were 33 launched, that 15 were registered, 15 were launched, that only 3 experienced the light of day in this Parliament and none of them ended up with a positive result. That's why I thank Mr. Schöpflin for this work he's done on this file. I believe that the Commission may understand and become more propulsive, will make it easier to collect signatures, to more easily register signatures, and that this initiative will encourage the European Commission to act.  I consider this to be a very important instrument. It exists as a form of political action in some Member States, but national legislation needs to be harmonised and the ECI positive and propulsive should be made positive and propulsive.

name: Claudia ȚAPARDEL
text: – Direct democracy, on the Athenian model, is not as archaic as you might think. The European Citizens' Initiative, I could say that it is our modern tool to increase citizens' participation in decision-making. 51 initiatives have been put in place, amounting to no fewer than six million European citizens involved, informed and willing to fight to change the Europe in which they live. However, we do not have to maintain a false image. Only three initiatives were considered admissible and not even one produced applicable legislation to date. Now, what we need to do is increase the success rate of these initiatives. Thus, by upgrading the online signature collection system and raising public awareness of the problems, we can increase the success rate. In addition, the solution is young people. Young people are more aware of the society in which they live than we think. Their participation in the decision-making process could be the pleasant surprise that the younger generation is making to Europe. That is why I support reducing the age limit for participation from 18 years of age to 16 years. We can transform the experience of the past into the success of the future, including by using the potential of young people to participate actively and decisively in European decision-making.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: ECR). Mr President, the European Citizens' Initiative, established by the Treaty of Lisbon, is an important conquest of the peoples of Europe and strengthens participatory democracy within the Union. At the same time, it is a form of broad cooperation between citizens and movements, at EU level, thereby strengthening the bonds of solidarity and social action. As coordinator of the ECR in the Committee on Petitions I have repeatedly highlighted the weaknesses of the existing legal framework of Regulation 11/79, 2011, which needs to be amended in order to: 1) ensure the widest possible participation of citizens, especially in the current period of economic crisis, 2) to enhance transparency and efficiency. Everyone must therefore understand that the European Citizens' Initiative is a primary exercise of the very democratic function, which could be used by the citizens and movements of the European South to create a broad front against austerity and poverty, against the promiscuity of the European Central Bank and the Europe of banks, and we anti-monumental citizens will take an initiative in this regard.

name: Pascal DURAND
text: Mr President, Mr Timmermans, in 2009 the Lisbon Treaty tried to create a direct link between citizens and Europe. Reality forces us to recognize that this is a total failure. That was said earlier, we are talking about fifty-one, in truth, there were fifty-three - two new initiatives were tabled in October. Fifty-three initiatives in reality, three that have more than a million citizens who support them, and nothing happens behind them. Nothing!  So I still have a problem, because the citizens are no more stupid than the Commissioners or ourselves, so there is a time when they feel that what they are doing is useless. These campaigns require considerable energy, considerable budgets. Citizens believe in it, they have invested, and what do they see? They see that now nothing works, and we have gone from a lot of initiatives to a ridiculous number. So, listen, I think we have to be clear: you have a possibility, you have an alternative, either you give legislation or ... (The President withdraws the floor from the speaker)

name: Milan ZVER
text: – I would like to thank Mr Schöpflin for his excellent report on the European Citizens' Initiative, which allows citizens to co-design European legislation under, of course, known conditions. The report seeks to improve the functioning of this new original instrument of European democracy, which greatly reduces the democratic deficit. The report proposes removing some of the barriers that are causing problems, particularly for the organisers of initiatives. European civil society has responded surprisingly positively to the implementation of the European Citizens' Initiative. In the three years since, we have heard this many times today, over 50 have accumulated, but the Commission has failed, with only three initiatives being labelled admissible, but not a single initiative has so far been followed by a legislative proposal. That's not right, of course. Today, democracy is vulnerable. There are thesis on the widespread inefficiencies of democracy and the assessment of its decline. I believe, however, that such direct forms of codecision make European democracy more vital, and it strengthens the European Citizen Institute and mobilises civil society. I therefore support the call in Mr Schöpflin's report that the institutions of the European Union and the Member States should promote the European citizens' initiative, thus strengthening citizens' confidence in this instrument. The unresponsiveness of the European institutions will, of course, not work.

name: Marlene MIZZI
text: – Sur President, The European Citizens' Initiative hija l-ewwel għodda li tagħti setgħa liħa liħa-ikeittadin li jieħu rwol attiv fit-tfassil tal-Unjoni Ewropea. name: Arne GERICKE
text: Mr President, Commissioner Timmermans, I would like to thank the Commissioner for his excellent work and for the work she has done. I have been an MEP for the constituency of Germany for just over a year. Whenever Possible, I travel between Aachen and Görlitz, between Flensburg and Oberammergau. I often hear that you are the first Member of the European Parliament who is really interested in us, otherwise Europe is so far away, what are we supposed to change? With each of these talks, it becomes clearer to me: Europe needs direct democracy, Europe needs the involvement of its citizens. We must dare democracy! I am all the more pleased that we are discussing this today, initiated by a campaign initiated by 70 000 European citizens. Thank you for that! Their call is clear: the European Citizens' Initiative must become simpler, less bureaucratic and more effective. Please do not think that the citizens are stupid! To involve them, but then to say: quite nice, but we will not implement anything. This won't do! That is why I am calling for democracy, let us create the European referendum, and not just every five years in the European elections.

name: Anna ZÁBORSKÁ
text: – I am very glad that the rapporteur, Mr Schöpflin, has summarised in his report a number of shortcomings of the European Citizens' Initiative. Because only if these shortcomings are remedied will the initiative have a chance of becoming a functioning instrument of democracy. The way in which the Commission has swept the citizens' initiative One of us off the table remains a huge disappointment to me and to the other two million citizens. The revelations, which have shown the trafficking of organs of aborted children and their use for research, confirm the risk of funding such experiments from the European Union budget. By ignoring the voice of citizens, the Commission did not take advantage of the refusal of such funding and also ignored the decision of the European Court of Justice in Luxembourg.

name: Ramón JÁUREGUI ATONDO
text: – Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I believe that there are three conclusions that can be drawn in this debate: first, citizen initiative is very important for democratic participation; Second, the current law does not work; third, we have to improve it. That's how far we agree. I wanted to suggest to Mr Timmermans a solution which I find politically interesting for what may be the reform of the initiative, which is to establish that initiatives that reach one million signatures but are not admitted for competition issues or other legal reasons are given an institutional response. I believe that we cannot forget an initiative which has such a capacity for convocation and which, on a formal or legal issue, cannot be monitored. My proposal is that there should be a response from the Commission, even if it is referring to other initiatives or even pending other legal reforms, but that there be an institutional response.

name: Branislav ŠKRIPEK
text: – Mr President, we have discussed the ECI several times in official and unofficial debates. Since 2012 we have had this instrument in European politics, and the number of successful initiatives demonstrates its success – or, better to say, failure – as not one led to a legislative process. I advocate the ECI in this House, and I am happy to welcome the suggestion of a rapporteur to make this tool more accessible for the European citizens – but I think it is not enough. Mr Commissioner, I ask you please to explain to citizens the lack of transparency in this matter. How come the institution responsible for it also checks the admissibility, and not a neutral body? Will the Commission finally start sending proper reasons for all ECIs which were refused in the past or revise the decisions on those ECIs where the Commission does not have proper reasons? Or is it a question of political correctness – my question – when almost 2 million citizens speak for not killing children before natural birth, or is this not welcomed any more? Will you restore trust in the ECI?

name: João FERREIRA
text: – Mr President, they wanted to adorn the Treaty of Lisbon with this democratic flourish, they wanted to give it the appearance of what it is not: something that is in line with democracy, with the will and with the participation of peoples. From the outset, the so-called European Citizens' Initiative was a puerile but also perverse attempt to legitimise an entire building that is deeply and structurally undemocratic. Let us not forget that the treaty that enshrined this initiative ostensibly escaped the scrutiny of peoples through referendums, and has been approved and ratified on the backs of citizens whose participation it says it wants to welcome. Six years have elapsed, it is clear the discredit in which this instrument, called participatory democracy, fell. More than half a hundred attempts, and only three managed to meet the strict parameters to fit what they defined as citizen participation. Even those are in the Commission's drawer, who knows how long, like the public water initiative.

name: Igor ŠOLTES
text: – The citizens' initiative is an instrument for the direct expression and promotion of democracy and a number of unsuccessful initiatives, as we have heard today, and, of course, the Commission's failure to react to successful initiatives among citizens can also cause confusion and also disillusionment with the EU institutions. Citizens rightly expect what is written to work. If this is enshrined in the Treaty of Lisbon as a form of democracy, let it be used, of course. As we have already heard, even greater political steps need to be taken as regards the admissibility of this initiative and to define more clearly the procedural rules for the submission of the initiative.  The rules must be clear, otherwise they do not work, and if that is not the case, then this citizens' initiative itself only seemingly indicates the possibility of promoting direct democracy.

name: Jonathan ARNOTT
text: – Mr President, the words ‘citizens’ initiative’ sound brilliant, do they not? The idea, in principle, is of more democracy, more power going from us, the often untrusted politicians, back to the people. But the rapporteur is right: it has not yet worked. Just 3 out of 51 initiatives so far have been declared even admissible. I would love for every Member State to have a proper democratic right for citizens to get new legislation onto their statute books. I had to travel today through Switzerland to get here, and actually outside the European Union Switzerland leads the way. It is not just that public petitions are considered, but the people get to have a proper say in a referendum too. What an incredible example of a proper direct democracy Switzerland shows to us all. I believe that every country of the European Union could learn from the example of Switzerland.

name: Franz OBERMAYR
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the The Institute of the European Citizens' Initiative is based on the good idea of including European citizens in legislation, but, as with many things in the Union, it has so far kept full-blown promises. The Institute has been in existence for three years, 51 initiatives have been in place, and no initiative has actually led to a legislative procedure, not even the good, excellent initiative against TTIP. Well, Commissioner, what should the EU citizen think? I also consider this draft, the attempt to give EU citizens a user-friendly instrument and remove small hurdles, to be a mere smear, an unfit attempt. It is only intended to give the Union a democratic fig leaf and is completely toothless in practice. I therefore say that this initiative, as it is now, is a pure placebo. But, Commissioner, the citizens will not continue to be sold for stupidity.

name: Frans TIMMERMANS
text: First Vice-President of the Commission. – Mr President, let me reiterate what I said at the beginning: the Commission is prepared to work very closely with Mr Schöpflin and Parliament to see to what extent we can apply the improvements his report suggests to the Citizens’ Initiative. I look forward to working closely with Parliament to make sure that, where we can, we will improve the Initiative, and probably we will have to look at the regulation at some stage. The Commission will certainly not shy away from doing that if it is considered necessary. At the same time, you can turn the Initiative into something it is not and then be critical of the fact that it is not what you want it to be, but it is in fact quite straightforward: it is based on the Treaty. The Treaty is something all Member States agreed on, signed and ratified in the national parliaments. We cannot go beyond the Treaty, even though it would perhaps be nice to go beyond the Treaty. The Commission is responsible for applying the rules in the Treaty, and the rules in the Treaty say that the European Citizens’ Initiative is an instrument to involve citizens in dialogue. It is not an initiative to give citizens the right of initiative in legal matters: that is a different animal. If you are not happy with that animal, fine, but do not accuse the animal of not being what you want it to be. It was intended to be an addition to representative democracy, to make sure that people get involved in the debate in representative democracy, not an alternative to representative democracy. I am quite sure this Parliament would not want to put itself in an outside position and leave all that to citizens directly.  I think the deal here is that we involve citizens in a dialogue about policies. If the Commission applies the rules – and yes, it happens unfortunately quite a lot – we have to say that the initiatives taken are not within the existing rules. We can change the rules, and we will look into that. We can assist people taking initiatives in overcoming bureaucratic hurdles and other problems, and we certainly want to try to improve that. We have been trying already, and we receive all persons taking an initiative to advise them. Sometimes we also help them amend the questions, saying that if they reformulate them slightly then we can say they are within the rules. We are trying to be very cooperative with those who take initiatives, but you cannot blame the Commission for applying the rules. We would be amiss if we did not apply the rules simply because it would be nice to let people take initiatives. I will have to be firm on this, but I want to reiterate our willingness to work closely with Mr Schöpflin and his colleagues to make sure that we improve the system. I still see a lot of potential in this instrument. It is far too easy after a relatively short period of time to dismiss the instrument because it is not what one wants it to be. Do not make it bigger than it is, but do not disqualify it before we have done everything we can to make it work better, as is the intention of Mr Schöpflin and the others who supported him in making the report.

name: György SCHÖPFLIN
text: rapporteur. – Mr President, I would like to thank everybody who has taken part in this constructive debate. I think everyone has been constructive, perhaps with one or two exceptions. I am particularly grateful for the supportive words from Vice-President Timmermans. There are some issues, which I think have some saliency, that I would like to pick up on (I cannot, obviously, do a summary of everything that has been said). I think the point made by Mr Goerens about the revalorisation of democratic legitimacy is something that we must think about very seriously. Connecting the citizens has come up in a fair number of contributions. Then there is the follow-up problem, on which others spoke (Mr Terricabras notably). Nobody knows this, but actually I have a very old and very rusty degree in law, and one of the things I take away from this is that when it comes to legal regulations applying the rules – to quote Mr Timmermans – there is always some leeway in how one interprets these things. Here I would like to call for more flexibility: apply the rules but, where there is a grey area, think about the million people who have been involved. Finally, three short issues. Treaty change has come up: my own take on this is that yes, Treaty change will happen one day, but not in connection with the ECI, so primary law is not really a part of this. Secondly, as I understand it at the moment, an ECI can call on the Commission to act in particular ways, but as things stand cannot interdict legislation. This could well be reconsidered. Certainly, that is the input I have had from civil society. As I understand it, ECIs cannot affect current processes, even if inputs from stakeholders are widely regarded as a viable part of policy information – and whatever the status of citizens in the European political field, they are stakeholders.  I would like to end by saying that I very much thank Mr Timmermans. As far as the ECI is concerned, the ball is in his court, and I am sure that his team will do everything to make it viable.

name: Rainer WIELAND
text: The debate is closed. The vote will take place on Wednesday, 28 October 2015. Written declarations (Article 162 OF the CRP)

name: József NAGY
text: Writing. – Strengthening participatory democracy is, I believe, the key to Europe's future, the key to development. If we look at the development of democracy, from the ancient Greek example of privileged only to the possibility of participating in public life that is now supposed to be for everyone, I think there is a clear path forward. It's not enough to drag citizens to the polls. They must be given much more power to make their voices heard, and if this does not happen, disillusionment will lead to demotivation, resulting in fewer and fewer people going to vote. This participatory democracy is strengthened by the institutions of the petition and the citizens' initiative. I think the intention of the legislator was clear when regulating the latter. The system isn't working. The European Commission seems alarmed that its convenient bureaucratic system may have a say from the outside, and that one-off citizens may be taking the right of initiative out of their hands. He doesn't like it even when there are almost two million people lining up for an initiative like right to water. This situation is untenable and the solution to the problem will not be delayed. The delay is increasing disillusionment and mistrust of Brussels. I trust that with this report we will take concrete steps in the right direction.

name: Beatrix von STORCH
text: Writing. – involve citizens in shaping policy and legislation: this is not always the intention. In Germany, the Civilian Coalition made material "One-of-Us" possible. I speak from my own experience. Although "One of Us" was authorized as legally watertight, the same Christian Democrat Barroso Commission buckled a year later and refused to present the required acts. "One-of-us" is now pending before the ECJ (T-561/14). Rightly so: if an ECI is authorised on the basis of its legally water-proof reasoning and more than 1 million signatures are submitted, the required acts must also be submitted. Otherwise, the EU will be fooling people by the nose. In the specific case, the Commission refuses to recognise ECJ case law (C-34/10: man is a human being from fertilisation, and the human embryo is a human being). It does not deal with obvious contradictions in its own policies. The Commission is in breach of the procedures by not sending its opinion to the EU Parliament. In this way, the European Commission becomes a leniency witness for the fact that the institutions in Brussels do not really care about the opinion and the will to shape them. The Juncker Commission wanted to be more political than its predecessor. Mr Timmermans: Respect the will of the citizens and implement the demands of 'one-of-us'! Are the Social Democrats creating what the Christian Democrats failed to do on one of their core issues?

name: Iuliu WINKLER
text: in writing. – ICE was considered a triumph of the Treaty of Lisbon because it opened up the chance for European citizens to become legislative initiators and active participants in the development of European policies. 3 years after the entry into force, this tool causes disappointment. The EC's bureaucratic, legal approach risks having the opposite effect to what is desired, helping to remove citizens from Europe. The EP has played an important role in promoting ICE legislation, and now, once again, the EP is taking the initiative to amend the regulation. The EU must become a political construct and therefore must be open to the ideas and proposals of its citizens. This imperative must be understood by EU bureaucrats, but also by Member States who must facilitate the entire ECI procedure instead of putting additional administrative obstacles. I hope that the Schöpflin Report, which contains clear proposals to improve the ECI Regulation, will be adopted by a large majority in the EP. The proposed amendment to the EC and the Council must prove that the EU is at a crossroads. Either we learn to listen to the voice of our citizens and then we will be successful, or we continue to move away from European citizens, thus being destined for failure.

name: Rainer WIELAND
text: The next item on the agenda is the debate on The Report by Charles Goerens on behalf of the Committee on Development on: The Ebola Crisis: Long-term lessons and measures to strengthen health systems in developing countries to prevent future crises (2014/2204(INI)) (A8-0281/2015).

name: Charles GOERENS
text: Rapporteur. Mr President, the first cases of Ebola virus disease in the European Union and the United States quickly caused panic in the respective public opinion. Nothing like this from March to September 2014, when thousands of people infected with the virus had already died in Sierra Leone, Liberia and Guinea, where the crisis hit hard. This crisis is systemic in many respects. First, with regard to systemic lack of global governance, the World Health Organization itself has acknowledged its share of responsibility for the slowness of the alert. Secondly, with regard to systemic poverty in the three crisis-hit countries, there is some eloquent evidence of its particularly acute nature: 80% live in extreme poverty, schooling lasts just four years on average, health systems are less resilient. Thirdly, at European level too, the systems are perfectable, particularly in terms of coordination between the 29 actors that are the Commission and the Member States.  The appointment of Commissioner Stylianides as the European Union's Ebola coordinator has finally led to a change in the search for European solutions for victims in the three African countries. As for the lessons that can already be learned from this crisis, first, the exemplary commitment of humanitarians, particularly MSF and the Red Cross, has contributed to a wide awareness and has aroused unanimous admiration, even though they have paid a heavy price. The fight against Ebola has claimed the lives of some 500 health professionals. Second, when the international community finally woke up, and in particular its pharmaceutical industry, responses to vaccine development could be found fairly quickly. Third, health systems in developing countries cannot be abandoned on the grounds that the recovery of public finances takes precedence over any other consideration. Fourth, there is an urgent need to address systematically the question of who is responsible for research and development in the treatment of rare diseases or that primarily affect only patients living in developing countries.  The political sphere, if acquired by the principle of non-indifference, can no longer rule out this problem. The European Parliament should take the lead in a new report on this issue in close cooperation with the Stylianides coordinator and taking into account the lessons to be learned from the European Parliament's mission in West Africa at the beginning of November. Fifth, there is an urgent need to rebuild the three countries, including not only health systems but also the economy, which have rapidly collapsed since the beginning of the epidemic. Finally, the European Parliament was right to claim and corroborate, year-round, its proposal to have at least 20% of its external official aid devoted to the development of basic social sectors, in particular, including, first and foremost, the health system. In conclusion, let us remember that there is no need to let our guard down in the face of an intelligent virus, alas intelligent, that is still likely to manifest itself in other forms than those already known. We are also aware of our moral obligation to make the right of patients to access treatment around the world a principle of lasting political action. Finally, let us not delay in helping Africa to take ownership of its own development, especially in health research and development.

name: Christos STYLIANIDES
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, the Commission very much welcomes Charles Goerens’ report. I want to commend and thank Mr Goerens for his great work and, of course, for his dedication to the fight against Ebola. During this period we have had excellent and productive cooperation for which I am truly thankful to him.  The European Union has a special responsibility when it comes to promoting universal health coverage, supporting countries to achieve health–related sustainable development goals and to build resilient health systems better able to control outbreaks so we are better prepared when the next big epidemic strikes. The report remains very topical as this epidemic is not over. We have again been getting some new cases, unfortunately, in Guinea in recent weeks. We must remain engaged until we reach a resilient zero, until the affected countries fully recover. The European Union and Member States have pledged over EUR 2 billion. From this amount EUR 900 million comes from the Commission alone for response, recovery and research. We are also fully engaged in learning vital lessons from the Ebola crisis: for example, the October Luxembourg conference on lessons learned, which Commissioner Andriukaitis and I attended, came forward with important recommendations. These will fit into the Health Council conclusions in December. As the EU Ebola coordinator I will also report on the overall lessons learnt to the European Council at the end of this year. We have also been fully engaged in the G7 Health Ministers discussions on Ebola earlier this month, in which Commissioner Andriukaitis participated. We are pleased that the G7 Declaration expresses commitment to, and I quote, ‘strengthening health systems to enable the provision of basic healthcare [...] as well as water, sanitation and hygiene. The aim is to progressively achieve universal health coverage’. This is very important.  As Mr Goerens’ report clearly emphasises, basic healthcare and clean water for all are essential. We can all agree that building and reconstructing a resilient health system is also essential – health systems able to detect, monitor and contain a health crisis. What have been the main lessons for the EU from this crisis? There are many things we could write in our response at EU level. Our rapid and substantial Ebola funding for the emergency response, for recovery, for research; our role in organising the transport of assistance to West Africa; the very positive role of the European Centre for Disease Prevention and Control in deploying epidemiologists; also the crucial role of the four EU mobile laboratories or the EU medivac system that we deployed for all international health workers.  But at the same time there are also lessons from what did not go as well. The first lesson: the international community was and still is ill–prepared for a global health emergency. Global emergency and health governance need strengthening. This includes support to the WHO, the reform of the WHO and the review and implementation of international health regulations. Here our help plays a key role. We also had difficulties in rapidly deploying medical teams. Hence we are now working with Member States to establish a European medical corps using the voluntary pool system of the European Union’s civil protection mechanism.  Secondly, weak health systems in partner countries are a particular concern. The European Union has committed to comprehensive health systems’ strengthening; however, we learned from Ebola that we may not have been comprehensive enough. So we need to do more to strengthen national capacity, as I said, to provide health care for all and for outbreak control in particular. Thirdly, the weakest health systems are severely underfunded. Domestic resource mobilisation will not fill the gap soon. To have good preparedness and to achieve the health SDGs we need a minimum level of public health financing. Forty countries spend even less than USD 30 per capita per year. That is the real figure.  Fourthly, the Commission and Member States have to programme health aid more strategically, leaving no one behind. We have to counteract any tendency to withdraw collectively from the health sector, focusing on those countries falling below minimum public financing. We need to think about how we can deploy our collective EU health aid more effectively and more predictably. Last, but not least, the Commission and Member States should support a globally coordinated research effort to identify, make priorities and address recent gaps against future emergency epidemics. Capacity building through research has an important role to play in strengthening local health systems. We are therefore supporting the global research collaboration for infectious diseases preparedness, an important tool for coordinating research funding.

name: Josu JUARISTI ABAUNZ
text: draftser of the opinion of the Committee on the Environment, Public Health and Food Safety. – Mr President, as with the refugee crisis, the European response to the Ebola epidemic was, in my opinion, late and bad. A few states reacted well, but the response from others was regrettable. Taken together, the Union has no reason to breastfeed. I believe that the lessons we must draw must arise from an honest and rigorous analysis of the European reaction during the first few months, which followed the alert launched by Doctors Without Borders. And global passivity in those first few months explains, in part, that the scale of the epidemic was so great, and its expansion uncontrolled. The Ebola outbreak, an exceptional fact, has brought to light how inefficient and slow health systems are and also humanitarian aid in emergency response. We need a comprehensive strategy to support vaccine and treatment research and development, and a comprehensive and fair development strategy and international aid and reaction.

name: Ioan Mircea PAŞCU
text: I would like to ask your permission not to accept questions put in accordance with the 'blue card' procedure as we are in the advanced process.

name: Maurice PONGA
text: on behalf of the EPP group. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would first like to thank our colleague Charles Goerens warmly for his listening and cooperation in the preparation of this report. This is an important report that draws lessons from the major health crisis that hit West Africa in March 2014 and left more than 11,000 people dead. This Ebola crisis has dramatically highlighted the systemic weaknesses of developing countries in terms of health. It is therefore crucial that the European Union and development actors now and significantly strengthen aid to developing countries so that they can put in place effective health systems. This should be reflected not only in the infrastructure and sanitary facilities, but also in the training of medical personnel. Staff must be trained to respond appropriately to crises that arise.  One point that I also think is important to highlight in this report is the need to strengthen the governance of developing countries. The more disorganized the country is, the less it is possible to come to the aid of the victims. Without good governance and the rule of law, there can be no sustainable development: the two are linked. Although the number of new cases is now limited to Guinea, with Sierra Leone and Liberia declared by WHO Ebola-free zones, we must remain vigilant and work in a coordinated manner with all development actors and affected countries to prevent a new outbreak in the event of a resurgence of the virus.

name: Norbert NEUSER
text: Mr President, I would like to make a mifful son, mr President, I would like to make a ido to the S&D Group. Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has The media calm around Ebola is deceptive. Cases are still being reported in Guinea and Sierra Leone, and so far there are unknown health consequences for Ebola survivors. It is logical and right that Charles Goerens' report goes beyond the immediate disaster. That is an essential element of this report. Thank you, Charles. We therefore call for the strengthening of health systems in the affected countries of Liberia, Guinea and Sierra Leone. But we must also look at similarly fragile states in Africa. As in the refugee crisis, where the EU and the international community have fought far too late and half-heartedly causes of flight in the past, this also applies to the health system, to general and basic care, to the improvements in hygienic conditions in these countries.  When will we finally learn that prevention is the better approach to development cooperation?  This year, the Nobel Peace Prize is rightly awarded to the Dialogue Quartet in Tunisia. This is good! The women and men who, as doctors, nurses, carers at risk of death – many have paid for this with their lives – who fought the Ebola crisis, who, too, deserved the Nobel Peace Prize. Commissioner, thank you for your commitment as coordinator for the fight against the Ebola crisis.

name: Arne GERICKE
text: Mr President, I would like to like to take back from the ECR Group. Mr President, Commissioner Stylianides, I would like to thank the Commissioner for his excellent work and for the work she has done. What do we learn from the Ebola crisis in the long term? How do we strengthen health systems in developing countries to prevent future crises? Mr Goerens, I am looking at a very similar report for the ACP delegation and I have often been in conversation with African colleagues. They think that if there were a new pandemic today or tomorrow, we would be as disastrously prepared as we were before the Ebola crisis. Let us stop lamenting! Let us act together with the states concerned! I advocate the establishment of globally networked emergency centers. No matter where something happens, we need to be able to provide the region with a minimum of infrastructure within 24 hours. But we must also stop the medical brain drain from the developing countries. We need good doctors there and we should promote their training. We need universal care in rural areas, and we need to involve mothers. When they know and say what is important for hygiene, it works a thousand times more than the advice of a European aid worker.

name: Lola SÁNCHEZ CALDENTEY
text: GUE/NGL Group. – Mr President, Commissioner, Mr Goerens, first of all I congratulate you and your entire team on the excellent work done on this report. From the Ebola crisis, which has taken almost 12,000 people with it, we must learn the following: first, that austerity kills. Structural adjustment programmes, imposed by the IMF and the World Bank in the 1980s and 1990s in Africa, deteriorated these countries' health systems, making them powerless in the face of an Ebola-caliber epidemic. Cuts and privatizations in European countries, such as Spain, have also undermined health systems and are responsible for mismanagement of treated Ebola cases, such as nurse Teresa Romero, which was spread out for lack of resources and resources, and not for any other reason. Two, the pharmaceutical industry is guided solely by the benefit and does not investigate the diseases of the poor, as has been demonstrated with Ebola. In short, austerity is urgently needed and robust health systems developed, and alternatives to the current model of drug research are also urgently needed. Only then can we deal with future global health crises.  I just want to end by saying that these 12,000 deaths will help keep this from being repeated.

name: Maria HEUBUCH
text: Mr President, For better, I would like to make a name for my free Mr President, I would like to thank the We Greens, too, thank Mr Goerens for this report and we naturally welcome it very much, because now we really need to learn lessons, lessons for the future, for future crises, because this will not be the last. What we would have liked to see in this report would be the call for a flexible approach to intellectual property, because the Ebola crisis has once again made it clear that health is a public good. We therefore call on the EU to develop a flexible perspective for developing countries on health and access to medicines, and also to promote the right for developing countries to make full use of the margins of the Trips Agreements. We welcome the report's call for all states to address social injustice, including through universal health care, and to draw up a plan in which own financial resources and potential international resources are available for implementation. Nor should we turn the crisis into a forgotten crisis, because it will take many more years for countries to recover from it.

name: Nathan GILL
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. – Mr President, I would like to take this opportunity to thank those NGOs and local organisations who worked incredibly during this crisis for the bravery that they showed. I would also like to take this opportunity to criticise the media for the way that they sensationally took this as an opportunity to increase their ratings – and I know the BBC World News used it as an opportunity to have an ‘Ebola watch’, which was something like looking at criminals. The way that they used the Ebola crisis was just terrible. I am a firm believer that, with situations like this, we can tackle the problems by looking at the causes and not actually just the symptoms and, in the long term, crises like these can be averted by increasing the wealth of the poorest people in the poorest nations. The EU fisheries agreement in Western Africa has deprived the poorest people of their livelihoods, and this is having a huge effect on the poorest people’s ability to earn an income. Remove these ridiculous fisheries and trade agreements that have been imposed on these countries; give the poorest people an opportunity to earn a living and improve the conditions in which they live, and you will see that crises like these will not keep on occurring.

name: Jean-Luc SCHAFFHAUSER
text: on behalf of the ENF group. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Mr Commission representative, we are not afraid of ridicule. If ridicule were to kill, our assembly would be dispersed tonight - given the number of present, I agree, it would not be too serious. But ridiculous, we are. We wake up for Ebola - 10,000, 11,000 killed for 25,000 infected people, and we release nearly two billion, 900 million by the Commission. But malaria, with 500,000 people killed a year, 190 million people affected, we don't talk about it. 120,000 lepers die untreated, and we don't talk about it. And yet, these drugs are easy to access. They exist and do not cost too much, do not cost at all even. But it doesn't concern us, we don't have fear in our stomachs. Here, as everywhere, the list of wishful thinking and recommendations drips. But how, this Marshall Plan for Europe? Who will fund it? A thousand billions of monetary creation for the banks, an illusion of Juncker's plan for recovery, and for Africa, nothing.

name: Bogdan Brunon WENTA
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by Ebola has taken the biggest toll in three West African countries: Guinea, Liberia, Sierra Leone, and has proven sluggy in the response of the international community, with the World Health Organization at the forefront. In addition to the fact that local and national health systems in these countries do not have the means and capacity to prevent and extinguish infectious disease outbreaks, the consequences of this crisis are disastrous for economies and security throughout the region. The role of humanitarian organisations, which have helped the sick and provided basic protections in a more effective way than institutional players, has proved invaluable. As international actors, we need to create a platform for dialogue and cooperation with local authorities and be able to build trust among the communities affected by the epidemic so as to prevent disinformation and that people are not afraid to ask for help and that safety and the necessary medical care are ensured. It is important to involve the Union and the Member States in the field of humanitarian and development aid. EU investment in the health sector in the longer term will certainly contribute to economic development and the distribution of poverty in these countries. Additional funding under Horizon 2020 and the Innovative Medicines Initiative referred to by Commissioner Stylianides can accelerate the development of new therapies for the treatment of infectious diseases.

name: Linda McAVAN
text: – Mr President, I would like to thank the Commissioner for what he has said and Mr Goerens for the report, and I would, of course, particularly like to put on record my thanks to all the health workers and people who worked in those countries in very difficult conditions. The Commissioner was right in saying that the biggest lesson we learned was that where countries did not have a basic health service, they could not cope and they quickly became overwhelmed by the disease. So my question really is: what is going to happen now to build those health systems? You said, Commissioner, what should happen, but what is happening? Has anything changed in the EU programming for the future? What is going to happen in our joint programmes with these West African countries? We built new clinics, what is happening to them? What is happening to the health workers who work there? What happened to the pledges made in Brussels in April at the big conference?  I am asking this because last week I met a healthcare worker from Sierra Leone and he said that some of the health facilities are being dismantled, that there are not enough doctors to staff them. But in Sierra Leone, one of the poorest countries on the planet, only lactating mothers, children under five and pregnant women get free healthcare. There is no free healthcare for the Ebola sufferers who suffer from long—term after—effects of Ebola.  So we need to have a new programme for health and I am not clear whether the Commission and its Member States have got one and how they continue to coordinate because as you said, we all pledged in New York to have universal health coverage but it is not enough to keep pledging it, we have to actually do it. So, we can do something in these countries, and I really want to know what it is the Commission is going to do.

name: Cristian Dan PREDA
text: Mr President, I would first like to congratulate my colleague, Charles Goerens, for writing this report on the lessons we can learn in the long term from the Ebola crisis.  I met last week with the representative of an NGO in Sierra Leone, an organization that originally worked in the field of education, which found itself, in the midst of the Ebola crisis, doing prevention with communities to prevent the spread of the disease. He told me one very fair thing: this crisis served as a sign of all the weaknesses in the health systems of the affected countries. And I would add that it has also served as a sign of the inadequacies of our action.  For this reason, we must support the strengthening of the health systems of the affected countries, and I stress here that our action must be long-term and that we must keep our promises on funding.

name: Cristian-Silviu BUŞOI
text: – Mr President, the 2014 Ebola epidemic has been the largest in history, affecting multiple countries in West Africa. More than 23 000 people were infected and 9 000 are dead. Healthcare workers have been infected while treating patients suffering from the Ebola virus. The EU and its Member States directed EUR 1.2 billion from EU funds for the development of both treatments and vaccines. Good outbreak control and crisis management relies on applying interventions such as case management, surveillance and contact tracing, mobile laboratory service, training for health workers and also social mobilisation. Improving the health system and raising awareness could be an effective way to reduce human transmission. Even though the EU has expressed solidarity and support, we could do much more to save people in West Africa from this tragic disease.

name: Caterina CHINNICI
text: – Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the scale and complexity of the Ebola epidemic, which has hit Sierra Leone, Guinea and Liberia hard since March 2014, raises important issues that place a great responsibility on the Union, within the international scene, for the promotion of the right to universal health care, especially in view of the structural health and education deficiencies in these countries.  The management of the crisis has, moreover, shown a number of negotiations, and that is why it is now all the more necessary for the Union to commit itself strongly to development aid and support for the economic recovery of the three African countries.  In particular, I agree with the report's need to revise the programming of the European Development Fund for the three countries affected: without structural support measures to guarantee access to health and the use of basic social services, it would not be possible to prevent the risk of future epidemics.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: ECR). Mr President, since 2014, Sierra Leone, Guinea and Liberia have been affected by the Ebola virus, while other African countries have been experiencing cases of the virus for years. However, these countries are not only experiencing the Ebola virus crisis but more generally a systemic crisis, since 80% of the population lives in extreme poverty. Of course, the European Union's response to curbing Ebola was not immediate and particularly effective, as were Doctors Without Borders and the Red Cross, which proved more prepared to help African populations cope with Ebola. It is therefore necessary to make better use of the capacities of these humanitarian organisations on the part of the European Union and also to strengthen medical research in order to produce medicines and vaccines for Ebola. In addition, it is necessary to erase the debt of the countries of Africa affected by the virus, so that countries can invest more in their health systems, rather than paying the international loan lenders, because their systems have been literally dismantled by the International Monetary Fund.

name: João FERREIRA
text: – Mr President, looking for lessons in the Ebola crisis, it is important that this report recognises that imf and world bank programmes have destroyed the fragile health infrastructure in the affected countries, destroyed public health services, and not only, creating a situation of inability to deal with the progression of the epidemic. It is necessary to reverse this path, repair the damage, break with this submission; support the construction of universal and free public health systems, the training of specialised health personnel; combat the hegemony of pharmaceutical companies in the development of new drugs, the dictatorship of patents; support the development of essential public services, such as in the field of water and sanitation; cancelling the external debt of these countries and, if it is time to welcome and thank all the international aid that is still needed, it is worth remembering the giant example of a small country, Cuba, which alone sent more doctors and nurses than all the other Western countries.

name: Michèle RIVASI
text: Mr President, first of all, I would like to congratulate our colleague Charles Goerens on both his analysis and his proposals. At present, according to the information I have from these countries - one of my daughters and my son-in-law work in Guinea - there are still two cases of Ebola, including at the Red Cross treatment centre in Forécariah. What we are seeing, however, is that the European Union and the Member States have contributed more than EUR 1.9 billion and that health systems have not been improved much: it is a very long time to implement. I ask the Commissioner that within the framework of the European Development Funds, we should be assured that hospitals and clinics will really be built to keep up with these phenomena.  Similarly, with regard to IMI , these European funds for the clinical studies we have paid , I think we should ask for conditionality with regard to vaccines. There would have to be no more patents, so that there would be access to drugs. The last thing I would like to say is that nothing is won. We were very surprised to find that in a nurse who had been treated, Ebola virus disease was re-established or that the semen still contains the virus six months after a person has been treated. At the same time, and I conclude, we need to restore the confidence of the people on the ground in the health care system because the future of the health of these countries is at stake.

name: Jonathan ARNOTT
text: – Mr President, Médecins Sans Frontières, Samaritan’s Purse – they and other NGOs did a great job. They were on the ground fighting this terrible disease before the politicians even started really talking about it. Then when we did act we did everything in slow motion. We were playing catch-up and so every hospital, every new hospital that was built, was full within hours. Rather than convert buildings quickly into makeshift hospitals, we did the job to a higher standard but it took many weeks, during which time the crisis got worse.  So my message to the EU, to the Member States, to countries around the world is this: next time please understand the urgent nature of emergencies, learn from the NGOs, learn from the people who risked their lives to fight Ebola and let us learn very simply that acting quickly is not only cheaper but also saves lives.

name: Christos STYLIANIDES
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, I would like to thank Members very much for this very rich discussion and their fruitful proposals.
