I would like to say again that this report – the Goerens report – outlines important lessons to be learned from the Ebola crisis. We are all part of this learning process. Once again I say a big thank you to Charles Goerens for his work and for his dedication.  At the same time, I would like to say something – as Linda McAvan mentioned – about the universal coverage system. As I already mentioned, I completely agree and this is why I am already focusing on the issue of the World Health Organization (WHO). The reform of the WHO is essential for future outbreaks in many other countries, maybe in Africa or elsewhere. This is why we need to promote this reform of the WHO. It will be the most important instrument for the next epidemic. Together, the Commission and the Member States should revisit development cooperation in health, where needed and in particular in the three African countries. I saw on the ground the problems in those three countries and I realised that the lessons learned may be the most important basis for the future for us as an international community, and we of course have to support those countries which are most in need. It is very important to achieve the health-related SDGs and, first of all, to build resilient health systems so that they are better prepared for possible future disease outbreaks – because we will, unfortunately, have more outbreaks in the future. We have to do so with a more predictable, targeted and longer—term partnership approach. This is the only way.  I would like to thank Charles Goerens again for his work because we now have a basis for the future as well as a record of the lessons learned.

name: Charles GOERENS
text: Rapporteur. Mr President, first of all, I would like to thank all my colleagues who made an intervention in this report. Thank you for the kind words they have said to me, the same remark applies to Commissioner Stylianides. The theme that has been the subject of this report is very relevant because these are issues of life and death, so we must take them very seriously. Our Committee on Development, for years, has been stressing the need to devote more resources to promoting health sectors in developing countries. It did not miss any opportunity - either in the context of budget discussions or in specific reports on this subject - to stress the need for more efforts to promote research and development in African countries.  When it comes to development, we don't develop others, we have to give others the means to develop themselves. We have not missed any opportunity to insist on improving governance, whether global, international, European or African. There is no fatality in the theme we have just discussed, because there have been results. We have not missed any opportunity to stigmatize the slowness that characterized the reaction of the international community at the beginning, and in particular of institutional actors, and finally, things got under way, in particular thanks to the resolution we voted on in September 2014 which was, in my view, the best resolution we have ever voted here in this Parliament on health issues affecting developing countries.  A colleague said that we are ridiculous, and he opposed malaria and Ebola virus. But listen, ladies and gentlemen, it is not one or the other, it is one and the other, we must treat the Ebola virus and also malaria. It is not tuberculosis or AIDS, it is tuberculosis and AIDS; we must face all the challenges, and that is why we are now calling for at least 20% of the resources of official development assistance to be devoted to the development of the basic health sectors. In fact, the colleague who called this meeting ridiculous on the grounds that the benches were sparse left his seat two seconds after his speech.  Finally, let me stress that there is no need to let our guard down, and Michèle Rivasi has just said so. This virus is a fearsome virus. It arises in other forms, it makes us discover other means of transmission, so we are not at the end of our sorrows, all the more reason to remain vigilant. I believe that after the lesson or lessons we have just learned from the Ebola virus, I am more confident at the end of 2015 than at the beginning of the crisis, especially during the period from March to September 2014.  Thank you, and let me remind you of one last message. The report also stresses the question of who is responsible for research and development of new drugs. The market has an important role to play, but the market should not be allowed to act alone. I say this as a liberal, as a proponent of the development of the market economy. There are also whole beaches where politics has to take responsibility, and I hope that our Committee on the Environment and Health can, together with the Committee on Development, find, or at least initiate, the beginning of an answer to this question, which, I admit, is a difficult question. It was too big a piece to swallow in the context of this report, which is why we are inviting the committees concerned by this issue of our European Parliament to look at this extremely important aspect.

name: Ioan Mircea PAŞCU
text: The debate has been closed. The vote will take place on Tuesday, 27 October 2015. Written declarations (Article 162)

name: Ignazio CORRAO
text: in writing. The report highlights the important role played in the first months of the Ebola crisis by the various humanitarian NGOs, including MSF, the Red Cross, Emergency and others, which have demonstrated not only the ability to interpret the serious situation, but have also been the most effective and operationally experienced actors, tackling the fight against Ebola on the front line.  While NGOs have been shown to be responsive and timely, international institutions and organisations have shown ineffectiveness, inadequacy and slowness in response to the mobilisation of aid, and the absence of who and the lack of research and development on medicines, diagnoses and vaccines have caused millions of deaths.  The aim of the report is to see the experience of the Ebola virus as a lesson that will provide immediate responses from the EU in the future. the preparation and experience on the ground of the various NGOs can be beneficial, as can supporting the emergence of forms of cooperation in the field of training of medical staff between the European Union and developing countries. The report also argues that strengthening national and regional health systems is an integral part of global health governance.

name: Viorica DĂNCILĂ
text: in writing. – Ebola and other epidemics of this kind are transnational border-free threats, which require the closest possible international cooperation to determine the causes of this crisis, the development of new treatments for neglected diseases, as well as to strengthen national health systems and facilitate the transfer of results to the population concerned. On the other hand, appropriate safeguards are needed to prevent public-private partnerships from harming vulnerable people in an unregulated market, which is why I support the World Health Organisation's proposal to revise the International Health Regulation with a view to introducing the idea of interdependent responsibility. Furthermore, we must not forget that there is a risk of a food crisis following the epidemic, which has had devastating effects on small farmers. As such, I support the need for closer cooperation between the Commission, the Member States and the international community and investments in their long-term development, so as not to risk the future of family farms and food security in West Africa.

name: Jarosław WAŁĘSA
text: in writing. – The Ebola crisis, which escalated in spring 2014, is a real challenge, not only for the countries such as Sierra Leone, Liberia and Guinea that have been afflicted by it the most, but for the whole world. Throughout the period of time that has passed since the epidemic started to evolve, I have observed that each government, each organisation had mobilised itself in order to prevent Ebola from spreading. Indeed, that crisis was actually a sort of a natural ‘test’ for the international community, and I am glad to say, that so far, we have passed successfully. However, we must not forget that the fight is still on and we should not surrender. I have already realised that even in such a dramatic event, we have decided to learn from it, rather than let it defeat us. Helping the countries that still struggle with the disease must continue, the same as us making efforts to prevent the outburst of similar future crisis.

name: Ioan Mircea PAŞCU
text: As announced by the President at the opening of the hearing, this evening the Bureau examined the appeal brought by Mr Korwin-Mikke and Mr Buonanno and confirmed the sanctions imposed on the two Members. Those penalties therefore apply from tomorrow.

name: Ioan Mircea PAŞCU
text: The next item is the joint debate on: – Ryszard Czarnecki's report, on behalf of the Committee on Budgetary Control, on discharge for the implementation of the budget of the ARTEMIS Joint Undertaking for the financial year 2013 (COM (2014)0510 - C8-0208/2014 - 2014/2132(DEC) (A8-0283/2015)) and – the report of Ryszard Czarnecki, on behalf of the Committee on Budgetary Control, on discharge for the implementation of the budget of the European Institute of Innovation and Technology for the financial year 2013 (COM (2014)0510 - C8-0201/2014 - 2014/2125(DEC)) (A8-0282/2015) and – Ryszard Czarnecki's report, on behalf of the Commission for budgetary control, on the discharge for the implementation of the budget of the ENIAC Joint Undertaking for the financial year 2013 ((COM (2014)0510 - C8-0211/20142014/2135(DEC)) (A8-0285/2015) and – Ryszard Czarnecki's report , on behalf of the Committee on Budgetary Control, on discharge for the implementation of the general budget of the European Union for the financial year 2013, Section II – European Council and Council ((COM (2014)0510 - C8-0148/2014/2079 (DEC)) (A8-0269/2015).

name: Ryszard CZARNECKI
text: Rapporteur. – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by It's an important debate, it's a bit of a pity that at such a late time when people usually watch movies – sometimes criminals about big money robbery. This is also about big money – money that needs to be controlled so that the European Union, however, the EU institutions have more authority, more acceptance among European taxpayers.  Very specifically, with regard to the European Institute of Innovation and Technology , an institute based in Budapest, it should be said that the Institute has introduced complementary ex post controls on grant transactions and that the quality of the control certificates received for grant transactions has been improved by improving the relevant instructions. The Institute is also now applying (this has changed) a more detailed and consistent certification methodology, and has improved the procurement procedure. So to sum up, there is certainly some progress, some improvement in terms of the level of certainty or legality, the correctness of transactions, especially those related to grants. This level has certainly increased and this needs to be noted. Nevertheless, it should be borne in mind that for the second time in a row the Court issued a qualified opinion to the Institute. It should also be strongly emphasised that the quality of certificates relating to around 87% of grant expenditure has been compromised as they have been issued by audit firms acting on behalf of grant beneficiaries. This is a huge and unnecessary exposure to possible irregularities. The further actions of the European Institute of Innovation and Technology need to be looked at, as two qualified opinions indicate that, however, the Institute is not functioning, or at least has not functioned properly in the past. At the moment, the focus should be on monitoring whether the Institute is following the changes. As far as ARTEMIS and ENIAC are concerned, in my opinion they do not require much discussion. I will not discuss them specifically here, as they have been merged into ECSEL. We will see what the concrete, real actions of this new unit will be. As far as the Council and the European Council are concerned – as I have pointed out on several occasions, both in my many previous reports and in speeches – the Council, as an EU institution, should have democratic responsibility to the citizens of the European Union to the extent that it is the beneficiary of the Union budget. Unfortunately, it is still here invariably – I stress all the time: invariably – many outstanding issues, because the Council persistently, quite predictably – I would say ironically – does not respond to the European Parliament's calls for regular submission of the relevant documents and explanations. Hence the proposal for another (this is no longer a surprise) refusal to grant discharge on our part, on the part of the European Parliament. I think that this match – unsympathic, bad, not building the authority of the EU institutions – between the European Parliament and the Council must finally be concluded. Here, on the other hand, we expect political goodwill from the Council.

name: Christos STYLIANIDES
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, I am here on behalf of my colleague, Commissioner Kristalina Georgieva. The Commission takes note of the proposal submitted by the Committee on Budgetary Control to the plenary to grant discharge to the Joint Technology Initiative on Embedded Computing Systems (the ARTEMIS Joint Undertaking) and the Joint Technology Initiative on Nanoelectronics (ENIAC), the European Institute of Innovation and Technology (EIT), and to refuse discharge to the Council for the financial year 2013. The Commission is happy to note that Parliament’s Committee on Budgetary Control agrees that the ECSEL Joint Undertaking (JU), which is the successor of ARTEMIS and ENIAC, has implemented actions to address the remarks of the budgetary authorities, and that it therefore proposes to grant discharge for the year 2013. ENIAC and ARTEMIS have convincingly demonstrated that public-private partnerships, using a tripartite model that pools together Member State and EU funding with industrial investments, deliver important results such as leading edge low-power electronic chips and worldwide standards for software platforms for cars. These give industry in Europe a clear competitive advantage and increase its capacity to grow, as was illustrated by the high industrial investment in these partnerships. Both initiatives have had a very high leverage factor – every euro from the public side has resulted in an investment of at least EUR 3 by industry in the two initiatives. ENIAC and ARTEMIS therefore provide a unique opportunity and an effective means for industry, Member States and the EU to closely cooperate across Europe. This creates a critical mass for electronic components and systems that is of vital importance for the digital future of Europe. The initiatives have financed more than 3 000 of Europe’s best engineers and researchers in the field every year. Their work helps sustain at least 80 000 jobs in Europe per year. In the Horizon 2020 Framework Programme, ENIAC JU and ARTEMIS JU are merged in a new JU on Electronic Components and Systems for European Leadership (ECSEL). In ECSEL a structural solution is found for verifications and ex-post audits of new expenditure. In the draft resolution, the Commission is asked to carry out an evaluation to assess the activities of ENIAC and ARTEMIS to be considered for the 2014 discharge exercise. The Commission intends to reconcile this request with the ECSEL Regulation. The ECSEL Regulation provides that the Commission will conduct an interim evaluation of ECSEL that will include the final evaluation of ENIAC and ARTEMIS by 30 June 2017. To conduct separate evaluations on the very same projects would put a considerable administrative burden on the beneficiaries and the Commission. Finally, I would like to reiterate that the Commission will provide advice and full support to ECSEL in its continued efforts to address the concerns of the European Parliament. The European Institute of Innovation and Technology (EIT) has made significant improvements in the areas identified in the April Parliament decision. On the legality and regularity of its transactions, the EIT has reformed its audit methodologies, the EIT Knowledge and Innovation Community grant guidelines and procurement capacities and procedures. As a result, the combined error rate for the 2014 grants is only 0.9%. The EIT has also taken extensive measures to improve its planning and monitoring. Finally, we would like to note that the winner of this year’s EIT Change Award, Mr Govinda Upadhyay, was selected as a finalist in the Forbes’ 30 under 30 Social Entrepreneurs competition. This is precisely the kind of impact that the EIT was designed to create. As for discharge to the Council, the Commission regrets that a suitable solution has not been found between the two arms of the Budgetary Authority in this dispute lasting now for six years. The Commission considers that the institutions should cooperate for a smoother functioning of this procedure. The Commission hopes that this issue will be solved in a suitable manner for both institutions.

name: Marian-Jean MARINESCU
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. – Mr President, joint ventures are extremely important for research and development. They have allocated significant amounts of money that need to be managed, both in terms of expenditure and results. ARTEMIS and ENIAC received a qualified opinion from the Court of Auditors three years in a row. Delaying download has produced improvements in the activity. The European Parliament's recommendations have been implemented. I hope there is not yet a qualified opinion for 2014. The EPP Group will vote for the download, but will be watching the 2014 report very closely. I believe that more transparency and a very careful evaluation of the results is needed. I ask the Commission for a preliminary report on the work of ARTEMIS and ENIAC 1, and I welcome here the Commission's commitment to produce this report. The new ECSEL structure already has one year of activity and we need to know exactly where it came from. The long-term implementation of projects should not be a reason to postpone the report. A preliminary assessment of the use of European funds and private contribution is absolutely necessary. With regard to discharge for the Council, I believe that we need to achieve a concrete result. The refusal not to grant the download over a long period of time did not bring any results. We are responsible to the people to reach a solution. Otherwise, it can be said that the budgetary discharge procedure is not serious.

name: Derek VAUGHAN
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. – Mr President, I want to speak on the European Institute of Innovation and Technology (EIT) discharge, as I was the shadow rapporteur for the Agency. I would first of all like to thank the rapporteur for his cooperation on the discharge reports. We initially refused to grant discharge for the EIT for a number of reasons. First of all, there was the 3% error rate detected in knowledge information community grants. Secondly, errors were found in procurement processes, and there were also some issues regarding staff retention. Since then we have had a progress report from the EIT, which shows they have made progress, and also recently I took the time to visit the EIT myself, and I heard and saw the progress which they have made. So, for example, as the Commissioner said, error rates are down to 0.9%, they put in place new procurement procedures, and they have also put in place new staff appraisal procedures, which will hopefully help in a reduction of the turnover in staff. Therefore, when we come to the vote, I will certainly be voting to grant discharge to the EIT, and I also believe, when we get the Court of Auditors report for the 2014 discharge, that we will see the substantial progress maintained by the EIT.

name: Nedzhmi ALI
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Mr President, in April we postponed the decision on granting discharge to the Director of the European Institute of Innovation and Technology (EIT) to the financial year 2013. However, after receiving at the end of June a report from EIT providing information on the progress since the previous one, we can draw the following conclusions about the Institute in several different areas. In the domain of legality and regularity of transactions the Institute has improved the quality of audit certificates. The use of a new methodology has further improved the quality of ex—ante and ex—post verifications. The internal procedures of the Institute already fully comply with the respective public procurement rules. Further to the consultancy performed by the Institute’s internal audit capability, a number of activities have been implemented. In the area of budget and financial management there are positive changes related to improved planning and monitoring procedures, significantly improved absorption capacity of the beneficiaries and actions taken to alleviate the high staff turnover. As a result of the activities of the Commission’s Internal Audit Service we also observe positive developments, especially in the implementation of the elements of the institute’s action plan. By the end of 2015 it is expected the bulk of these actions will be completed. In the coming months we envisage the publication of a special report of the European Court of Auditors which will shed light on the ability of the institute to provide innovation in the EU, where I would like to discuss the distribution within the European Union of the different sectors of knowledge and innovation communities. Having regard to the positive changes, we support granting the Director of the Institute discharge in respect of the implementation of the Institute’s budget and approve the closure of the accounts for the financial year 2013.

name: Igor ŠOLTES
text: Mr President, commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, i would like to thank the rapporteur for his excellent work. – I will focus myself on the issue of discharge to the Council. It has been six months since Parliament postponed the council's discharge, and today we are once again debating whether the Council will finally disclose information about its financial management. The discharge procedure is mandatory for all European institutions and the Council is no exception. The implementation of its budget must be under the same control as for all the European institutions. And how is it possible that Parliament, once again, as has been the last many years in a row, has no insight into the Council's budget? And how is it possible that, as for so many years in a row, there is no debate on the discharge of the Council representative? Today, more than ever, citizens expect spending transparency and accountability. However, key institutions, including the Council, must set an example in order to maintain the credibility of the European Union in the eyes of taxpayers. I am convinced that the call to the Council before members is no longer sufficient before the European public, which is why we in the Greens group for the 2016 budget have tabled an amendment that imposes a budget reservation on the Council for the first time. Because, of course, we cannot change anything in a back, but, firstly, we can definitively refuse to grant discharge for 2013 and, secondly, we also sanction it in the 2016 budget.

name: Jonathan ARNOTT
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. – Mr President, I would like to thank the rapporteur for his courage in proposing that we should refuse to grant discharge for the EU’s budget 2013 in respect of the Council. It is usually so rare to see this place actually criticise an EU institution. We really do have a breakdown in communication, because the Council simply is not responding to questions: questions on spending and commitments, questions on building projects – like the Residence Palace; questions on administrative modernisation. I would also like to say that I praise the rapporteur for his unusual courage – but in this situation it is not actually quite so unusual, is it? Because discharge was not granted in 2009, 2010, 2011 or 2012 and we are still talking about 2013, as we still do not have the answers to the questions. It has been postponed whilst we wait for the Council to give us some answers, but it is not doing this. Either you believe in the European Union and its institutions or you do not. If you believe in it, then it is an embarrassment that this Parliament is being ignored in this way; if you do not, then sadly this is business as usual for the European Union.

name: Tomáš ZDECHOVSKÝ
text: – Mr President, Commissioner, at the beginning of this parliamentary term, we have made it clear that we will not tolerate any error in the agencies and errors in the European Union budget.  In the past, the Institute for Innovation and Technology has had major problems with budget implementation and the legality of grant transactions. The Institute was unable to provide ex ante verification and independent audit, staff turnover at the agency was above average and overall management was very weak. That is why we have decided to suspend the audit of this agency. However, with the advent of the new management, we are observing huge changes, which is why we have decided to grant the EIT discharge for 2013, but on the condition that we continue to observe it. There has been a big shift on the part of the Institute, which is why we support the discharge.  I would like to stress that while the Institute continues to try to address the problem areas, we are dealing with a much bigger problem at the moment, with the Council. The Council has repeatedly failed to obtain a discharge from the European Parliament, and here I think it is the Commission's job to try to resolve the issue as soon as possible.

name: Zigmantas BALČYTIS
text: – Mr President, on the basis of the assurance sought by the SCL, the Joint Undertaking has made good progress in implementing an action plan to remedy the shortcomings identified by the Court of Auditors. In addition to the national funding authorities, the company's ex-post audit strategy has been improved, a specific audit reporting format has been introduced and a systematic quality assessment of these audits has been carried out. At the same time, information on the requirements of the financial programmes and good practices was exchanged, as well as improved policies for the management and prevention of conflicts of interest and the establishment of a comprehensive database covering all information relating to conflicts of interest and actions. As ARTEMIS and ENIAC no longer exist separately, any recommendations relating to improvements to audit procedures will have to be implemented by the already new ECSEL Joint Undertaking, so it is important to give it time and discharge.

name: Tamás DEUTSCH
text: - Dear Fellow Members, Unfortunately, the refusal to grant discharge from the European Council is nothing new. Year after year, the Council ignores Parliament's right to conduct the closure. This year is the fifth year in which parliament will reject the granting of the Council's final report. The Council does not attend the discharge hearing of the Committee on Budgetary Control, refuses to answer questions sent by Parliament during the discharge procedure, does not provide the documents necessary for the discharge procedure and which is made available to the European Parliament by any institution other than it. We do not have any information on the background, costs or outcome of the council's various real estate transactions, nor do we know details of the costs and results of institutional modernisation in the Council. The European Parliament's Committee on Budgetary Control is unable to take a meaningful decision on the Financial Management of the Council. The Council also does not meet the most basic expectations of transparency and accountability. It shall withdraw itself from the rules and procedures which apply to all the institutions of the European Union. For this reason, the European People's Party supports the referring proposal that Parliament should not grant discharge to the Council.

name: Ingeborg GRÄSSLE
text: Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has said. Discharge is a task which Parliament has laid down in the Treaty. This is actually a stellar hour today, because that is exactly what people expect of us, namely that we look at how the money has been spent. That is why, Commissioner, we would like to report the success of the Joint Undertakings, but it would be important for us to have more ownership by the Commission. We need supervision. I am always amazed at the number of problems in these miniature households. They are relatively very small households. That is why I think that these small budgets should actually be much more transparent than what we have seen in our work. I would like to come to the Council. It is scandalous that the Council takes so little seriousness its own duty to assess all European Union expenditure. The Council refuses to even deal with the other institutions in its recommendation, which is also in the Treaty. It is intended to make recommendations on expenditure management. The Treaty states that it should make recommendations to the Commission. But we now have to map the whole range of money spent. It would be nice if the Council could finally get its way to really pull this thorn out of our flesh. It is absolutely ridiculous what problems he is doing.

name: Franc BOGOVIČ
text: – Discharge is a normal procedure both in private companies, where business owners do so, as well as in public institutions, where on their behalf – the people – this is prepared and done by elected people. I am therefore pleased to follow the report of the rapporteur, who noted that artemis, Eniac, as well as the European Institute of Innovation and Technology for the financial year 2013, made corrections, followed recommendations and followed those that give discharge.  For me, too, what is happening with the Council is certainly unacceptable, and as we hear this is happening from year to year, that the Council is somehow defiant and does not want to be held accountable to Parliament on these discharges.  I therefore support the rapporteur's position not to grant this discharge. And I hope that in the future the Council will show more respect for Parliament and, therefore, for the European population.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: ECR). Mr President, in order to ensure transparency and democratic accountability to the taxpayers of the European Union, the European Parliament, on the basis of Articles 316, 317 and 319 of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union, has the right to grant discharge for each part of the Union budget separately, and therefore also for the European Council-Council section.  However, the Council considers it to be a State in state, that it is above all control, which is why for many years it has still not answered the Questions of the European Parliament. Council expenditure must be controlled, as should the expenditure of the other institutions of the European Union. Yet the Council is showing a lack of cooperation; it refuses to give a detailed written explanation of the total amount of credit used to purchase the Residence Palace building. I therefore support the report by Mr Charnieschi, who does not grant discharge to the Secretary-General of the Council for the implementation of the budget of the European Council and the Council for 2013.

name: Christos STYLIANIDES
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, as you know, I am here on behalf of my colleague, Kristalina Georgieva. In this respect I would like to thank you again for the opportunity to take the floor during this year’s joint debate on the discharges for the Council – the joint undertakings and European Institute of Innovation and Technology (EIT) – and welcome the proposals to grant discharge to those undertakings and the EIT. The joint undertakings subject to the discharge today have made major improvements as regards their management and control systems, and the Commission will continue to provide them with advice and support on their continued efforts to address the concerns of the European Parliament.

name: Ryszard CZARNECKI
text: Rapporteur. – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by Commissioner, i would like to thank you for your comments. I am speaking at a special moment in my life, but I will tell you about it at the end.  I am now refering to what I have heard. Indeed, we already had a yellow card, which we showed to the European Institute of Innovation and Technology, and it is good that we have shown it, because it has proved that the institute can function and work better than before. There is some progress, not least because we have forced them to be more efficient, to work more efficiently.  As far as the Council is concerned – indeed, half a year ago we had a situation where we showed a yellow card, but as the old Polish proverb says, "he talked grandfather to the picture, and the picture to him not once". We have a situation where we all, as representatives of political groups, say that we can differ, but this is absolutely unacceptable. For the fifth year in a row, the same problem with the Council. Mr Soltész says that citizens expect – Mr Soltész is right. President Gräßle says that this is a scandal – this is a strong word, but it is in place, because the Council is really stubbornly evading cooperation. That just can't be the case. Mr Arnott is right, of course, to say that it is ' never ending story', speaking in his native language.  In short, we must show determination in this matter. This is a question of a certain honour of the European Parliament, of our responsibility to citizens. I believe that here we cannot forgive and we must use all the pressure to get the Council to engage in dialogue. We just want a partnership dialogue, nothing more.  Thank you very much and I would like to say that I am speaking at a special moment in my life. At this point, I found out just a second ago, my son became a member of the Polish Parliament for the second time.. I make no secret of the fact that I am happy about this.

name: Ioan Mircea PAŞCU
text: The joint debate has been closed. The vote will take place on Tuesday, 27 October 2015.

name: Ioan Mircea PAŞCU
text: The next item is one-minute interventions on important political issues (Article 163 of the Rules of Procedure).

name: Claude ROLIN
text: Mr President, as Commissioner Marianne Thyssen wishes, it is essential to anchor the principle of equal pay for equal work in the same place.  Intra-European wage competition, often referred to as "social dumping", is a real cancer for the development of the European project. I therefore welcome the unanimous decision of the College of Commissioners to support the revision of the Detachment of Workers Directive. This is an essential task, and the Commission will have to act quickly, even though we know that it will not be easy to reach an ambitious agreement. For some Member States, this competition is endangering entire sectors of the economy; for others, the detachment offers a perspective of catching up. The Commission will therefore have to be creative in order to preserve the mobility of workers while putting an end to social competition practices. This also means strengthening national inspection services and setting up a European social inspection.  I therefore call for a win-win solution that will give European citizens and workers a better-life future.

name: Damian DRĂGHICI
text: – Mr President, here in Strasbourg we are far away from the realities of local Roma, far from the day-to-day struggle for survival. Here, we cannot imagine what it is like to gather scrap or plastics in order to afford lunch or dinner on the table for your kid. Oftentimes there is only one choice: lunch or dinner, because a working day will not pay more than EUR 10 to EUR 15 for a family of 3 to 5 persons. Yes, the children also go out to gather scraps. Twelve years ago, when Roma migrated to France and Switzerland, local people were shocked. They did not understand what was going on; people probably thought that Roma or Gypsies lived in huge palaces and did not understand why they left them behind. This is why they sent people to see what can be done in Europe. There is something we can do to make a real change for the Roma. We are focusing too much on the national level and there are too many levels down to the local one. As we all know, the decentralisation process is slow and has not paid off much by now. What we can do is target the regional and local level directly and have the local people as the main funding opportunities managers, because they know best what their needs are and what should be done in order to improve social inclusion for the Roma community.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: ECR). Mr President, next Wednesday, the Greek people will again celebrate the national anniversary of 28 October. October 28, 1940: a timely milestone of the Greek resistance against fascism. At that time, the brave defense of our country by the people was reflected in the phrase "heroes fight like Greeks". Men, women and children resisted, even giving their lives for the freedom of the homeland, vigorously fighting fascism. Today, 75 years later, we are once again called upon to defend our national sovereignty and the dignity of our people, resisting the international loan sharks and the troika, who systematically impoverished Greece.  The Greeks, drawing strength and lessons from our history, will give the historical example of resistance to modern methods of enslavement of the peoples, abolishing the memoranda, erasing the shameful debt and demanding the immediate payment of German war reparations, the forced occupation loan and the compensation of the relatives of the thousands of victims murdered by nazi occupation troops in Greece during the Second World War.

name: Neoklis SYLIKIOTIS
text: GUE/NGL). Mr President, Turkey may have agreed to play the role requested by the Union in order to keep the refugees and to take the title of safe destination country, but at the same time in Turkey the democratic deficit continues to grow dangerously.  Behind the criminal acts against the Kurds are those who want to keep their presence in power, while opposing peace and democracy in the country. In view of the upcoming elections, it is clear who is behind the bombings. How many more have to be murdered in Turkey for the Union to react?  Unfortunately, the delay in the Commission's publication of Turkey's progress report reveals the transaction being made against the people and how flexible the Union's declarations on human rights are.  Our position is clear: Turkey must fulfil all its contractual obligations as a candidate country, respect the human rights of its citizens and also implement all its cyprus obligations.

name: Igor ŠOLTES
text: – Air pollution poses one of the biggest public health risks in Europe. A significant proportion of the European population lives in areas where air quality is greatly reduced – ozone, nitrogen dioxide and, above all, particulate matter. More than 400 000 people are expected to die in Europe every year as a result of these consequences. The european environment agency's data, which predicts high air pollution mortality in the coming years, is also worrying. We should be very concerned about that, of course. However, although new standards in this area have been put into force in Europe, it must be said that these are not sufficient and deviate from the standards set by the World Health Organisation. And I think we underestimate the consequences of this situation in Europe, especially in concentrated cities. And I think we need to do much, much more in this area.

name: Piernicola PEDICINI
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Paupisi, Casalduni, Pago Veiano, Reino, Circello, Solopaca, Cautano, Campolattaro: these are just some of the names of countries in southern Italy that, together with the city of Benevento, were submerged by the flooding of the Calore river on the nights of the 15th and 18th of this month.  Many small and medium-sized enterprises have been completely destroyed by the flooding. The economy of these places is mainly based on agriculture, but now there will be no new harvests for the next three or four years. These people had very few things, yet they could withstand a crisis that is not over there yet. Now they don't even have that anymore, so the population is literally on their knees. Yet they have asked for nothing, they are dealing with this catastrophe with extreme pride and with commendable dignity.  So I will do it for them: I am asking this Parliament and I will ask the Commission to speed up the release of solidarity funds for natural disasters, because there are European citizens here in extreme difficulty and we cannot waste precious time providing them with aid.

name: Laurenţiu REBEGA
text: – Mr President, this month, in the midst of the refugee crisis, the Council of Justice and Home Affairs Ministers of the Union held, a meeting at which Romanians hoped to take the decision to accept their country into the Schengen area. As has happened every time in the last five years, and this time the subject has been removed from the agenda in order not to receive a veto from some Member States. Instead, while Romanians are constantly denied Schengen membership, the governments of the same states, under the pretext of solidarity, are trying to impose on other Europeans the acceptance of mandatory refugee quotas. It is regrettable that the joining of the two events shows that our European partners prefer migrants from the East in the Schengen area and not those who, like them, are based on a system of values, education, culture and European traditions. Please don't think I'm unhuman when I talk like that. Such signals only draw our attention to the fact that the European project must return to the concept of equal and sovereign collaboration between European nations and cease attempts to impose decisions. I have every sympathy and willingness to help those hit in the East by the horrors of war, but until then, I have a duty to ensure that the nation Romanian is treated by its partners as an equal of other European nations. I think so because first, I am Romanian, then a European citizen and, finally, a universal citizen.

name: Krisztina MORVAI
text: "I hold the flag of Szeklerland in my hand and I would like to briefly introduce the Szekler people to you. It's an indigenous national community. This means– many people do not know the term – that they have lived in the same place in the Carpathian Basin for over a thousand years. About three-quarters of a million or a few more in one block, one place. They have two main aspirations at the moment, both of which we would think are absolute natural features in the European Union. One is to use their own language in official procedures, street nameplates, town name boards and, well, usually during contact. The other is that, as often and repeatedly in their history, they can have autonomy and independence, similar to, say, South Tyrol. National self-determination is a fundamental human right, and the Szeklers want to exercise this fundamental human right. I call on the European Union and the European public to support them on this good cause.

name: József NAGY
text: – The Slovak parliamentary elections in the spring are likely to be decided by the real non-existent threat of an influx of immigrants. The forthcoming propaganda of the ruling party with the slogan "We protect Slovakia" might seem like a cheap phrase, because protecting the country is the dog's duty of any government. But the forthcoming Socialist billboard campaign is the political culmination of the deliberate spread of fear of an influx of migrants. However, with this populism, it will have to be reiterated many times that Slovakia is protecting our miserable economic situation and not the government from hundreds of thousands of immigrants. However, we cannot have reservations about the legacy of this campaign if the ruling Smer party regards Slovakia's unfortunate situation as its own merits.

name: Clara AGUILERA
text: – Mr President, I would like to denounce the situation of injustice and defencelessness of people who, in their day, emigrated from my country, Spain, to European countries such as France, Germany or Belgium, who worked and quoted in these countries in the sixties and seventies especially, and who are now required by the Spanish Government to quote their pensions with retroactive effect. The Government of Spain has adopted legislation which is creating serious problems for a good number of Spanish pensioners: 800 000 people are being affected by this legislation, which has not taken into account even the bilateral agreements signed to avoid double taxation. In addition, these are older people, which adds difficulty in addressing these problems. Moreover, the absolute invalidity recognised by Germany or France to these pensioners is also not allowed, requiring, after twenty years, the papers to prove that pension.

name: Marek JUREK
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by A week ago, a young Iranian Converted Christian was shot at a resort in Hamburg. Despite the terrible nature of this act, it is nevertheless not the worst manifestation of anti-Christian hatred that has be met Christians with people pretending to be refugees, as this is undoubtedly difficult to compare with, for example, throwing people into the sea. But what happened to this young Iranian is special. We know neither his face nor his name, and it is the deaf silence of the media, and the deaf silence of the political class that surrounds this terrible case, that shows what the real state of freedom of expression really looks like in Europe today and what the ethical sensitivity of the people who so much like to instruct us about their so-called values looks like.

name: Miguel VIEGAS
text: – The situation of farmers in the European Union is dramatic. Although approved by a majority of this Parliament, everyone recognises that successive revisions to the Common Agricultural Policy have created a permanent crisis in producers. By dismantling all public regulatory instruments and opting for solutions aimed at self-regulation of markets, we are now witnessing enormous price volatility and a steady loss of farmers' incomes. The proposed solution of using derivative financial products to ensure farmers' incomes is well known to the complete omission of policy makers in the face of the challenges facing our agriculture.  At a time when thousands of bankruptcies are being seen across Europe, it is absolutely vital to stop this process of liberalising our agriculture and promoting the big agro-industrial business, either internally or within the framework of the international trade treaties that are in the forge. It is urgent to stop and act in defence of our agriculture and, in particular, of our small and medium-sized family farming, the only one in a position to ensure sustainable production, of proximity and that consumers can rely on.

name: Josep-Maria TERRICABRAS
text: – Mr President, the skepticism about the present and future of the Union is growing in Europe. Recent state elections seem to confirm this. This is a matter of the utmost importance. We must make every effort to improve our social, economic and cultural policies, as well as our interregional relations. Laments are not enough, nor is it enough to be passively waiting for better times for Europe, times that will not come if we do not provoke them. Because the problem is not in bad times, but in bad policies, which we must change to better serve citizens. The growing skepticism of many Europeans is not only the result of the pervivience of selfish nationalisms, but is also the effect of misconceptions and petty approaches on the part of the European institutions. If we defend the well-being of European citizens, we will be combating skepticism and defending Europe.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: – Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to recall the case of corruption in Rome over the Anas procurement round, which led to ten arrests this last week for criminal association, exchange vote and other disputed crimes, and the case of the arrest of the Vice-President of the Lombardy Region, the richest region in Italy, for a round of health bribes.  According to Transparency International, Italy is the last country in the European Union (ranked 69th) in the overall ranking of the most corrupt countries in the world. Here, in this field, Europe can do a great deal: there is the contribution of the CRIM Committee of the last legislature that marks and traces the high road. You can make a global anti-corruption report, a comprehensive strategy. Common EU-specific legislative measures for whistleblowers can finally be invoked to protect those who rightly denounce those who are sucking and draining public resources. The essential agents for flushing out criminals can be introduced across the continent. A common evaluation system can be created.  Let us act, please, because countries like Italy need to be pushed to do the right thing.

name: Anna ZÁBORSKÁ
text: – the arrival of a large number of refugees has divided society in the Member States and throughout the European Union. But the backlash of many of our citizens is often linked to the perceived social injustice. Entitlement to accommodation, food, healthcare and pocket money is not a matter of course for citizens of Slovakia and other countries. Social benefits are sometimes insufficient to provide housing, food or medicines, especially when it comes to families with young children. The obligation to help people in need affects both refugees and our citizens. The refugee crisis is an opportunity to rethink social systems, especially in the new Member States. It is a reason to open a debate on the demands arising from human dignity and on the weight of meritocracy in social systems.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, an entire province of southern Italy, Samnium, has been hit by an unprecedented flood which, like a tsunami, has caused deaths and estimated damage of over EUR 1 billion to infrastructure, the agricultural sector, businesses and housing. This tragedy risks erasing the economic fabric, the history and the future of these lands. I have seen for myself the dramatic nature of the situation by visiting farms and industrial farms that have been completely destroyed. However, the tenacity with which the citizens are responding to this disaster must be a source of pride for the whole of Europe, which must now work to put in place concrete aid to the population and to the economic and productive fabric.  The European institutions must work at a fast pace to speed up the procedure, which the Italian Government is currently initiating, for the immediate adoption of the Solidarity Fund, including with advance payments. And the exception to the automatic decommitment of resources must be authorised, so as to allow an extension in expenditure to the affected territories, which must also have the opportunity to leave the Stability Pact. Samnium does not give up but needs help to start again: Europe does its part.

name: Javier COUSO PERMUY
text: – Mr President, some questions must be asked about the European Union's foreign policy in the Middle East, especially about its regrettable absence from the social transformation taking place today in Syrian Kurdistan in Rojava.  Deeply democratic, inclusive, multi-confessional transformation, with an unreleased presence of women in the area and seeking Confederal lace in Syria. Those same people who began to defeat the Islamic State, who today endure a criminal Turkish embargo that deprives them of the basics, while confronting terrorism on several fronts. We no longer remember the Kurdish Guernica, kobane, destroyed at 70% and still waiting for the six million euros promised by Europe. The European Union prefers to support Turkey and that irresponsible Islamic State-tolerant government, which bombs only Turkish Kurds and represses their opponents. It is time to tell Turkey to stop being a hooligan state and stand next to Syrian Kurdistan in its counter-terrorism and democratic effort.

name: James CARVER
text: – Mr President, I wish to highlight the detention of Gregg Fryett, a British citizen who has been held in Cambodian custody since March 2013 in relation to allegations of a commercial fraud nature. Mr Fryett maintains his innocence and, I understand, at all times before his arrest had made himself available to the investigating authorities. Indeed, when arrested, he had voluntarily returned to Cambodia at the specific request of the judge, who had given him both written and verbal assurances as to his free passage. Whilst the specific issues are, of course, a matter for the Cambodian authorities, the fact that Mr Fryett has now spent 31 months in jail – well in excess of the statutory period for a person who can be held in Cambodia before being brought to trial – raises major concerns for those who champion justice and also questions Cambodia’s reputation by highlighting the systemic problems in the country’s justice system at a time when economic assistance is being afforded to it by both the United Kingdom and the European Union.

name: Marijana PETIR
text: – Mr. President, Mr. Commissioner, to this point, 260 280 refugees and migrants who do not stay in Croatia have entered Croatia because Croatia is not their "promised land". Only five of them applied for asylum. This is understandable, because the beautiful Croatia unfortunately, thanks to poor politics, is not a promised land even for young Croats who go belly after bread in other Member States of the European Union.  Croatia is a transit stop on the migrant route. We hope that last night's deal in Brussels will not lead to Croatia becoming europe's refugee camp. Because how else to interpret the decision that Croatia will be the first country where refugees and migrants will register without having passed almost half of Europe?  As western European countries close their doors, the message that we need more Europe sounds like cheap steam. We need solidarity with those who are fleeing war, but also with each other. What we are witnessing is not solidarity and is not the solution to the problem. The solution to the problem is for everyone to take their share of responsibility and to ensure peace in Syria and the Middle East.

name: Claudiu Ciprian TĂNĂSESCU
text: – Mr President, with the measures taken to solve the refugee crisis, the European Union is in a position to seek solutions to new problems, some of which we are currently addressing, others that we may face in the future. In addition to new situations, created in the economic, social or cultural sphere, we must also lean with the utmost responsibility on the field of public health. We need to rethink and adjust European health policies so that any event in this area, from vaccination schedules to an epidemic, can be treated with the right response as soon as possible.  I would also like to call on the European Commission to allocate funds for the modernisation, retrofitting and optimal functioning of the institutes of microbiology and virology in the European Union, due to the strategic values in terms of research, development and marketing of the serums and vaccines needed in the event of spontaneously triggered epidemics.

name: Cristian-Silviu BUŞOI
text: – Mr President, the scandal concerning the disappearance of a billion dollars from the banking system in the Republic of Moldova, the sincere dissatisfaction of citizens with the still unresolved problems in society, but also the interests of destabilising the situation, coming from the east – all of which put both the government coalition and the European course of Moldova to the test. I hope that the situation created by the detention of the former Moldovan Prime Minister, one of the founders of the Alliance for European Integration, will not lead to the disintegration of the pro-European government coalition, and that people's discontent does not change the pro-European option of the leadership of the Republic of Moldova. At the moment, there is a need to maintain the stability of the government coalition. I also believe that the European Union must continue to support the Republic of Moldova in strengthening the European partnership, and I firmly believe that Romania will remain the main supporter of the European journey of the Republic of Moldova.

name: Péter NIEDERMÜLLER
text: – Several international organisations have recently pointed out that media freedom is not exhaustive in several Member States of the European Union. This is especially the case in Hungary, where public television, which is funded by public money, unscrupulously promotes the government's often anti-European, lying propaganda. Today, Hungary has media poverty, which means that in many areas of the country only government-subsidised taxes can be heard. I must say that, in the past, commercial television had a certain opportunity to counteract this media dominance. But we know that the government has tried to make these televisions and radios impossible with special transmitters. Today we are at the fact that one of the largest commercial televisions is being bought up by pro-government oligarchs. I believe that we MEPs must always and everywhere stand up for media pluralism, because if a single party, a single government, has media power, democracy will end.

name: Milan ZVER
text: – Mr President, I would like to get your attention to underline the difficult situation in Slovenia. In the last few days almost 80 000 refugees have entered Slovenia. On the one side, Croatia is sending refugees to my country, often on the Green Border and, on the other side, Austria and Germany are step by step closing their borders. We are facing a humanitarian catastrophe in Slovenia. It is very well known that the absorption potential of my country is ten times smaller than the number of refugees that have entered Slovenia in the last few days. The Slovenian Government certainly bears a huge part of the responsibility for the situation in the country. Nevertheless, both refugees and Slovenians expect that responsibility must be taken also by the EU Institutions and some Member States. Mr Commissioner, the emergency plan adopted on Sunday’s meeting in Brussels must be fulfilled immediately.

name: Csaba MOLNÁR
text: - Ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank you for your support. In mid-September, first on the Hungarian-Serbian border and then last week on the Slovenian-Croatian border, everyone could see the immeasurable human suffering and chaos that the politics of national selfishness can lead to. However, following Sunday's EU mini-summit on the refugee crisis, there is once again hope that cooperation between Member States will finally be replaced by national arrogrth and specific policies. Perhaps from now on, no national leader can act without negotiating and coordinating with another leader. Perhaps no one can hide from the obligation to register refugees and pass on the burden of the refugee crisis to another Member State. Today, refugees are seen by many as a threat to Europe, to European values. In my opinion, historically, it is the national selfishness that has been whipped up, the surrender of our Europeanism and principles, the closed-door policy, the special national policies that pose a threat. We need to be clear that no state can face the refugee crisis alone, only a common solution is possible.

name: Jaromír ŠTĚTINA
text: – Mr President, three days ago I returned from Syria, where I was at the invitation of the Headquarters of the Syrian Kurdish Armed Forces YPG and the YPJ. I drove about 800 kilometers across Rojava (Syrian Kurdistan). The basic finding I received after the meeting at headquarters is that the Syrian armed forces are the only armed force in the area that is capable and willing to destroy or substantially weaken ISIS. Only the destruction and uprooting of ISIS can prevent new refugee waves from Syria. Syrian Kurds are calling for help. They are directly threatened in their existence and their discharge is genocidal in nature. I found out about that in Kobanê, the city that ISIS destroyed to the last house. We speak too much, ladies and gentlemen, and we do little. The Kurds need weapons and ammunition, specialists in minemining, better coordination with the international coalition in bombing Islamic State positions. We speak too much, ladies and gentlemen, and people die.

name: Neena GILL
text: – Mr President, I rise once again to express my concern as to how we ensure that children born today can see lions, rhinos and elephants in the wild and not just in zoos. We are witnessing an unseen extinction crisis, yet we still allow trophy hunting. We have all heard the incomprehensible story of the demise of Cecil the lion. It struck a chord of revulsion with millions, and yet new permits continued to be issued – for example to a German hunter recently, to kill one of Africa’s largest elephants just for the sheer sport of it. During the decade up to 2013, nearly 27 000 hunting trophies originating from Africa and America were imported into Europe – and that is a conservative estimate.  The EU is the world’s biggest aid donor, which gives us leverage in Africa and elsewhere to stop the issuing of permits that allow trophy hunting to continue. I urge the Commission and Member States to take up a leadership role in CITES and to involve this House in its decision—making to put pressure on states that issue permits for trophy hunting and also to restrict all trophy imports. I will be launching a written declaration on this matter, and I hope colleagues will support me.

name: Franc BOGOVIČ
text: – I come from Slovenia, more accurately from the Posavje, where in the neighbouring municipality of Brežice, five to ten thousand people cross the national border daily. Croatian state authorities bring them to the border, show where the border is, whether through the fields or across the river, and then these unfortunates go to our Slovenian side. I therefore support yesterday's conclusions on the coordinated action of those of us on this journey. It is also – in the face of the urgent solidarity that Europe offers to migrants and refugees – that we are aware that Europe is incapable of accepting, integrating and meeting the expectations of all those who see Europe as a promised land. Therefore, Europe must establish an effective external border with Turkey in the Mediterranean as soon as possible. We must establish this border primarily for the sake of the security and future of our continent. The Europeans have not given anyone a mandate to fully open the border.  Germany and Sweden must say as soon as possible what they can offer people coming to European soil so that there are not too many frustrated and unhappy people. We need to get serious and be responsible.

name: Ivana MALETIĆ
text: - Mr. President, we need to take the issue of accepting and including refugees in the European Union much more seriously. There is constant talk of fewer than the actual number of people fleeing and coming to the European Union. Two plans for the realisation of refugees that we approved stopped at 160 000 people, and more than 250,000 have passed through Croatia since September.  Security and solidarity would reinforce a concrete refugee reception and care plan starting from the realistic expected number. Member States must prepare for this scenario, which means from infrastructure preparation to social and social refugee care programmes. This requires large financial resources.  We need to seriously change the EU budget and respond to the emerging situation, taking into account countries in financial difficulties with high unemployment rates and large debt and deficits such as Croatia, Greece or Spain.

name: Ioan Mircea PAŞCU
text: This item on the agenda has been closed.
